sourceString: Rapidly increasing cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the European Union/European Economic Area and the United Kingdom, 1 January to 15 March 2020
targetString: Omuwendo gw’abantu abafuna obulwadde obuleetebwa akawuka ka corona (COVID-19) ogweyongera ennyo mu Mukago gwa Bulaaya (Eropean Union)/Bulaaya n’Abasuubulagana nayo (European Economic Area) ne Bungereza (United Kingdom), 1 Janwali okutuuka nga 15 Ogwokusatu 2020

sourceString: The cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases is showing similar trends in European Union/European Economic Area countries and the United Kingdom confirming that, while at a different stage depending on the country, the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in all countries.
targetString: Omuwendo gw’abantu abafuna obulwadde obuleetebwa akawuka ka corona (COVID-19) gulaga enneeyisa efaanana wakati w’amawanga g’Omukago gwa Bulaaya /Bulaaya n’Abasuubulagana nayo ne Bungereza nga kino kikakasa nti, newankubadde ekizibu kya COVID-19 kiri ku mitendera gya njawulo mu mawanga ag’enjawulo, kyeyongerera ku misinde gya maanyi mu nsi zonna.

sourceString: Based on the experience from Italy, countries, hospitals and intensive care units should increase their preparedness for a surge of patients with COVID-19 who will require healthcare, and in particular intensive care.
targetString: Okusinziira ku kibadde mu Italy, amawanga, amalwaliro n’obusenge obujjanjaba abali obubi ennyo birina okwongera ku ngeri gye beeteeseteeseemu olw’okweyongera kw’omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 abaneetaaga obujjanjabi, naddala obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi.

sourceString: On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown aetiology was reported in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Nga 31 Deesemba 2019, abalwadde ba lubyamira (pneumonia) atamanyiddwa kimuleeta baazuulwa mu Wuhan, mu Hubei Province, China.

sourceString: On 9 January 2020, the China Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported the causative agent as being a novel coronavirus now referred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Nga 9 Janwali 2020, China Center for Disease Control and Prevention yategeeza nti obulwadde buno bwali buleetebwa akawuka ka coronavirus akatamanyiddwa nsibuko nga kati akamanyiddwa nga severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: Since, the illness resulting from SARS-CoV-2 infection has been named coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
targetString: Okuva olwo, obulwadde obuva ku kawuka ka SARS-CoV-2 bwatuumibwa coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

sourceString: Evidence to date is that ca 80% of individuals with COVID-19 have a mild disease, i.e. a respiratory tract infection with or without pneumonia, and most of these recover.
targetString: Ebizuuliddwa biraga nti ebitundu nga 80% eby’abantu abalina COVID-19 babeera n’obulwadde obutonotono, kwe kugamba, okukosebwa mu mussizo (respiratory tract infection) nga mulimu oba obutabaamu lubyamira, era ng’obisinga ku bwo buwona.

sourceString: In ca 14% cases, COVID-19 develops into a more severe disease requiring hospitalisation while the remaining 6% cases experience critical illness requiring intensive care.
targetString: Mu bitundu nga 14%, COVID-19 afuuka obulwadde obw’amaanyi obwetaagisa omuntu okuweebwa ekitanda so ng’abantu ebitundu 6% bafuna obulwadde obw’amaanyi ddala nga beetaaga okuweebwa obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi.

sourceString: The mortality of patients hospitalised due to COVID-19 is ca 4%.
targetString: Abalwadde abaweereddwa ebitanda olwa COVID-19 ne bafa bali ebitundu nga 4%.

sourceString: In this study, we assess the trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 in each European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) country and the United Kingdom (UK) and compare them to that of Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Mu kunoonyereza kuno, twekenneenya okweyongera mu balwadde ba COVID-19 mu buli ggwanga ly’omu European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) ne Bulaaya (UK) ne tukugeraageranya n’okwa Hubei Province, China.

sourceString: We also compare the current number of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK with that in Italy during 31 January–15 March 2020.
targetString: Era tugeraageranya omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu kiseera kino mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK n’ogwa Italy mu kiseera 31 Janwali–15 Ogwokusatu 2020.

sourceString: COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK
targetString: Abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK

sourceString: Subsequent to China, COVID-19 underwent further geographical spread and the dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic in the rest of the world currently follows that of this country.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lwa China, COVID-19 yasaasaana mu bitundu ebirala era enneeyisa ya nawookeera wa COVID-19 mu bitundu by’ensi ebirala egoberera ey’eggwanga lino.

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, the Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
targetString: Nga 11 Ogwokusatu 2020, Ssenkulu wa World Health Organization (WHO) yalangirira COVID-19 ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi (pandemic).

sourceString: In the 5 March issue of Eurosurveillance 2020, Spiteri et al. reported on the first European confirmed COVID-19 cases according to the WHO case definition.
targetString: Mu lufulumya lwa Eurosurveillance 2020 olwa nga 5 Ogwokusatu, Spiteri ne banne baayogera ku balwadde ba COVID-19 abaasooka mu Bulaaya okusinziira ku nnyinyonnyola ya WHO.

sourceString: In the EU/EEA, the first three confirmed cases were reported by France on 24 January 2020 in persons returning from Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Mu EU/EEA, abalwadde abaasooka baazuulwa mu France nga 24 Janwali 2020 ng’abantu bano baali bavudde mu Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.

sourceString: As at 15 March 2020, COVID-19 cases had been detected in all 30 EU/EEA countries and the United Kingdom (UK), whereby between 31 December 2019 and that date included, 39,768 cases and 1,727 deaths had been reported, with 17,750 cases and 1,441 deaths from Italy alone.
targetString: Nga 15 Ogwokusatu 2020, obulwadde bwa COVID-19 bwali bumaze okuzuulibwa mu mawanga gonna 30 aga EU/EEA ne UK, nga mu kino wakati wa 31 Deesemba 2019 n’olunaku olwo nga luzingiddwamu, abalwadde baali 39,768 n’abafudde 1,727, ng’abalwadde 17,750 n’abafu 1,441 bava mu Italy mwokka.

sourceString: Obtaining cumulative number and cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases
targetString: Okufuna omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 n’abantu abafuna COVID-19 nga bwe gugenda gweyongera

sourceString: At the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the notified COVID-19 case counts in each country worldwide, obtained from only official sources such as the countries’ Ministry of Health, national and regional health authorities and the WHO, are updated each day at 8:00 a.m.
targetString: Ku European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), emiwendo gy’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu buli ggwanga mu nsi yonna, okuva mu mikutu emitongole nga Minisitule y’Ebyobulamu mu mawanga, ebitebe bya WHO ebyobulamu mu mawanga n’amabendobendo, gizzibwa buggya buli lunaku ku ssaawa 2:00 ez’okumakya.

sourceString: These data were used for assessing the trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA and the UK, and comparing them to that in Italy.
targetString: Obubaka buno bwakozesebwa okwekenneenya ebikwata ku COVID-19 mu EU/EEA ne UK, n’okubigeraageranya n’ebyo eby’omu Italy.

sourceString: As a proxy of the prevalence of active COVID-19 cases, we calculated the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases, thus taking into account the natural course of COVID-19, in each EU/EEA country and the UK, during the 1 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Ng’enkola y’okubala omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 abakyajjanjabwa, twabala omuwendo gw’abantu abafuna COVID-19 ogukutuddwakutuddwamu mu nnaku 14, mu buli ggwanga lya EU/EEA ne UK, mu kiseera kya 1 Janwali–15 Ogwokusatu 2020.

sourceString: We also presented the cumulative number of notified cases of each country as at 15 March 2020 8:00 a.m. compared with that of Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Era twalaga omuwendo gw’abalwadde abazuulibwa mu buli ggwanga nga bwe gugenda gweyongera nga 15 Ogwokusatu 2020 ku ssaawa 2:00 ez’okumakya nga gugeraageranyiziddwa n’ogwa Italy mu kiseera 31 Janwali–15 Ogwokusatu.

sourceString: Trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA countries and the UK
targetString: Enneeyisa ya COVID-19 mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK

sourceString: The trends in the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK generally followed that of Hubei Province (China) (Figure 1).
targetString: Entambula y’emiwendo gy’abantu abafuna COVID-19 egikutuddwakutuddwamu mu nnaku 14 mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK okutwaliza awamu gyagoberera egyo egya Hubei Province (China) (Ekifaananyi 1).

sourceString: For the EU/EEA and the UK overall, the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 started to increase around 21 February and then increased sharply around 28 February 2020 (Supplementary material).
targetString: Mu EU/EEA ne UK okutwaliza awamu, omuwendo gw’abantu abafuna COVID-19 gwatandika okweyongera awo nga 21 Ogwokubiri ate era ne gweyongera nnyo awo nga 28 Ogwokubiri 2020 (Enkookero).

sourceString: This was mostly driven by the rapid increase in the number of reported cases from Italy, but all other EU/EEA countries and the UK showed similar increasing trends of the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 (Supplementary material).
targetString: Kino kyali bwekityo olw’okweyongera mu bwangu okw’omuwendo okuva mu Italy, naye ng’amawanga ga EU/EEA amalala gonna ne UK gaalimu okweyongera kw’abantu abafuna COVID-19 okufaanana (Enkookero).

sourceString: Figure 2 shows the cumulative number of COVID-19 cases, in EU/EEA countries and the UK compared with that in Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Ekifaananyi 2 kiraga omuwendo gw’abantu abafuna COVID-19, mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK nga gugeraageranyiziddwa n’ogwa Italy mu kiseera 31 Janwali–15 Ogwokusatu 2020.

sourceString: It highlights that, as at 15 March 8:00 a.m., 15 other EU/EEA countries and the UK had already reported a total number of cases comparable to that of Italy just 3 weeks prior or less.
targetString: Kiraga nti, nga 15 Ogwokusatu ku ssaawa 2:00 ez’okumakya, amawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK amalala 15 gaalimu omugatte gw’abalwadde ogwali gwenkana n’ogwa Italy mu wiiki 3 zokka emabega oba obutawera.

sourceString: Our results indicate that the number of notified cases of COVID-19 is rapidly increasing in the EU/EEA and the UK.
targetString: Bye tuzudde biraga nti omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 gweyongerera ku misinde mingi mu EU/EEA ne UK.

sourceString: The observed trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 suggest that the pandemic is progressing at a comparable speed in all countries.
targetString: Embeera ezuuliddwa mu muwendo gw’abantu abafuna COVID-19 gutegeeza nti ekizibu kino kyeyongerera ku misinde gyegimu mu mawanga gonna.

sourceString: This is despite countries being at different stages, variations in national public health responses, and possibly different case definitions in countries and different protocols for selecting patients that must be tested for confirmation of COVID-19, including catch-up testing.
targetString: Kino kisigala bwekityo amawanga ne bwe gabeera n’ebyobujjanjabi ebiri ku mitendera egy’enjawulo, n’ebisinziirwako eby’enjawulo okusalawo oba omuntu alina obulwadde awamu n’ebigobererwa eby’enjawulo mu kusalawo abantu ab’okukebera okukakasa nti balina COVID-19, nga mw’otwalidde n’okwongera ku muwendo gw’abantu abakeberwa.

sourceString: Early March 2020, doctors in the affected regions of Italy described a situation in which ca 10% of patients with COVID-19 required intensive care and media sources reported that hospitals and intensive care units in these regions had already reached their maximum capacity.
targetString: Ng’Ogwokusatu 2020 gwakatandika, abasawo mu bitundu ebikoseddwa mu Italy bannyonnyola embeera nti ebitundu 10% eby’abalwadde ba COVID-19 baali beetaaga obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi era amawulire ne gategeeza nti amalwaliro n’ebisenge by’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi mu bitundu bino byali bijjudde.

sourceString: Data on admission of COVID-19 cases in a hospital and/or an intensive care unit are currently available at EU/EEA level for only 6% and 1% cases, respectively (data not shown).
targetString: Ebikwata ku balwadde ba COVID-19 abali ku bitanda mu ddwaliro ne/oba mu kisenge eky’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi ebifunika ku mutendera gwa EU/EEA biri ebitundu 6% ne 1% byokka, (obubaka buno tebulagiddwa).

sourceString: They should, however, be collected in a systematic fashion to complement current surveillance data that focus on the number of reported cases and the number of deaths.
targetString: Wabula, bino birina okukuŋŋaanyizibwa mu ntegeka ennungi nga bikkaanya n’obubaka obulagibwa obukwata ku muwendo gw’abalwadde n’abafudde.

sourceString: A study performed in 2010–11 showed a large variation in the availability of intensive care and intermediate care beds in Europe, ranging from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 beds per 100,000 population in Portugal.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okwakolebwa mu 2010–11 kwalaga enjawulo ey’amaanyi mu bitanda by’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’ebyobujjanjabi obusaamusaamu mu Bulaaya, nga mu Germany biri ebitanda 29.2 so nga mu Portugal biri 4.2 ku buli bantu 100,000.

sourceString: This means that countries may have more or less resources than Italy (12.5 intensive care and intermediate care beds per 100,000 population in 2010–11).
targetString: Kino kitegeeza nti waliwo amawanga agalina ebyobujjanjabi ebisinga oba ebitatuuka ku bya Italy (ebitanda 12.5 eby’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’obusaamusaamu ku buli bantu 100,000 mu 2010–11).

sourceString: Modelling scenarios related to healthcare capacity saturation, with estimates for each EU/EEA country and the UK of the prevalence of hospitalised COVID-19 cases associated with a > 90% risk of exceeding intensive care bed capacity, are provided in the sixth update of the ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.
targetString: Ebiyinza okutuukawo nga byekuusa ku kujjula kw’ebikozesebwa mu byobulamu, nga bisinziira ku kugeraageranya abalwadde ba COVID-19 abali ku bitanda mu buli ggwanga lya EU/EEA ne UK awamu n’obuzibu bw’okuba ng’obwetaavu bw’ebitanda by’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi bususse ebitundu 90%, biragiddwa mu mawulire ag’omulundi ogwomukaaga aga ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.

sourceString: Since cases have so far clustered in certain regions in EU/EEA countries and the UK, and hospitals and intensive care units usually serve a defined regional catchment population, information about cases and intensive care beds should preferably be made available at the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2) level.
targetString: Olw’okuba ng’abalwadde bakyali mu bitundu ebimu mu mawanga ga EU/EEA ne UK, so ng’amalwaliro n’obusenge bw’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi gaweereza abantu b’omu bitundu ebimanyiddwa, ebikwata ku balwadde n’ebitanda eby’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi byandibadde bifunirwa mu ngeri ya Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2).

sourceString: The experience from Italy and the current trends in other countries show that the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in the EU/EEA and the UK.
targetString: Ekibadde mu Italy n’ekigenda mu maaso mu mawanga amalala kiraga nti ekizibu kya COVID-19COVID-19 kyeyongerera ku misinde gya maanyi mu EU/EEA ne UK.

sourceString: Countries, hospitals and intensive care units should thus prepare themselves for a scenario of sustained community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an increase in the number of patients with COVID-19 requiring healthcare, and in particular intensive care, such as the one occurring in the affected regions of Italy.
targetString: Noolwekyo, amalwaliro n’obusenge bw’obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi birina okweteekateekera embeera ey’okusaasaanyizibwa kwa SARS-CoV-2 mu bantu b’omu bitundu n’okweyongera kw’omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 abeetaaga obujjanjabi, n’okusingira ddala obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi, okugeza ng’eyo eri mu bitundu bya Italy ebikoseddwa.

sourceString: As pointed out in the recent ECDC rapid risk assessment, a rapid, proactive and comprehensive approach is essential to delay the spread of SARS-COV-2, with a shift from a containment to a mitigation approach, as the anticipated rapid increase in the number of cases may not provide decision makers and hospitals enough time to comprehend, accept and adapt their response accordingly if not implemented ahead of time.
targetString: Nga bwe kyalagibwa mu kwekenneenya kwa ECDC okw’obuzibu okw’amangu, okweteekateeka obulungi okw’amangu kukulu nnyo mu kulemesa okusaasaana kwa SARS-COV-2, nga kw’otadde n’okuseetuka okuva ku kulemesa okusaasaana okudda ku kuwonya, olw’okuba ng’okweyongera okw’amangu mu muwendo gw’abalwadde okusuubirwa kuyinza obutasobozesa ba buyinza na malwaliro kufuna budde bumala okutegeera, okukkiriza n’okutuukiriza enkola zaabwenga bwe kyetaagisa singa ziba teziteereddwa mu nkola nga bukyali.

sourceString: The rapid risk assessment also lists the public health measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.
targetString: Okwekenneenya obuzibu okw’amangu kulaga enkola z’ebyobulamu ez’okulwanyisa obuzibu bw’ekizibu kino.

sourceString: There is a short window of opportunity during which countries have the possibility to further increase their control efforts to slow down the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and decrease the pressure on healthcare.
targetString: Waliwo omwagaanya mutono amawanga mwe galina obusobozi bw’okwongerera amaanyi gaago mu kukendeeza okusaasaana kwa SARS-CoV-2 n’okukendeeza omunyigirizo oguteereddwa ku byobujjanjabi.

sourceString: Failing this, it is likely that the healthcare systems of other EU/EEA countries will face a surge of patients that require intensive care within the coming days or weeks.
targetString: Kino bwe kirema, kisuubirwa nti ebyobujjanjabi mu mawanga ga EU/EEA amalala gunyigirizibwa olw’omuwendo gw’abalwadde ogweyongera ennyo nga beetaaga obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi mu nnaku oba wiiki ezijja.

sourceString: The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has thus far killed over 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 in China and elsewhere in the world, resulting in catastrophe for humans.
targetString: Obulwadde bwa Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), obuleetera severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), bwakwatta abantu abasoba mu 3,000 era ng’abantu abasoba mu 80,000 be baakabufuna mu China n’awalala mu nsi, nga kino kireeseewo akatyabaga mu bantu.

sourceString: Similar to its homologous virus, SARS-CoV, which caused SARS in thousands of people in 2003, SARS-CoV-2 might also be transmitted from the bats and causes similar symptoms through a similar mechanism.
targetString: Nga bwe guli ku kawuka akakafaanana aka SARS-CoV, akaaleeta SARS mu nkumi z’abantu mu 2003, SARS-CoV-2 nako kayinza okutambuzibwa obuwundo era kaleeta obubonero obufaanana mu ngeri efaanana.

sourceString: However, COVID-19 has lower severity and mortality than SARS but is much more transmissive and affects more elderly individuals than youth and more men than women.
targetString: Wabula, COVID-19 si wa maanyi kwenkana SARS era asse abantu batonotono naye atambuzibwa okusingako era akosa abantu abakuluko n’abasajja okusinga abavubuka n’abakazi.

sourceString: In response to the rapidly increasing number of publications on the emerging disease, this article attempts to provide a timely and comprehensive review of the swiftly developing research subject.
targetString: Mu kwanukula ebifulumiziddwa ebingi ku bulwadde buno obubaluseewo, olupapula luno lugenderera okulaga okwekenneenya okunoonyereza okubaluseewo embagirawo mu bujjuvu.

sourceString: We will cover the basics about the epidemiology, etiology, virology, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of the disease.
targetString: Tujja kwogera ku bisookerwako ku bulwadde, ekibuleeta, obuwuka, enkebera, enzijanjaba, okuteebereza eby’omu maaso, n’enneewala yaabwo.

sourceString: Although many questions still require answers, we hope that this review helps in the understanding and eradication of the threatening disease.
targetString: Newankubadde nga waliwo ebibuuzo bingi ebikyetaaga okwanukulwa, tulowooza nti okwekenneenya kuno kujja kuyamba mu kutegeera n’okumalawo obulwadde buno obweraliikirizza abantu.

sourceString: The Spring Festival on January 25, 2020 has become an unprecedented and unforgettable memory to all Chinese who were urged to stay indoors for all the holiday and for many weeks after due to the outbreak of a novel viral disease.
targetString: Ebikujjuko bya Spring ebya Janwali 25, 2020 byafuuka omukolo ogutayinza kwerabirwa eri Abachina abaasabibwa okusigala mu mayumba gaabwe okumala oluwummula lwonna ne wiiki ezaddirira olw’okubalukawo kw’obulwadde obuleetebwa akawuka akaali tekamanyiddwa novel.

sourceString: The virus is highly homologous to the coronavirus (CoV) that caused an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003; thus, it was named SARS-CoV-2 by the World Health Organization (WHO) on February 11, 2020, and the associated disease was named CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).
targetString: Akawuka kano kafaananira ddala aka coronavirus (CoV) akaaleeta severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) mu 2003; noolwekyo, World Health Organization (WHO) yakatuuma SARS-CoV-2 nga 11 Ogwokubiri 2020, era n’obulwadde bwe kaleeta ne butuumibwa CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).

sourceString: The epidemic started in Wuhan, China, and quickly spread throughout the entire country and to near 50 others all over the world.
targetString: Obulwadde buno bwatandikira mu Wuhan, China, era mangu ddala ne busaasaanira eggwanga lyonna n’amawanga amalala nga 50 okwetooloola ensi yonna.

sourceString: As of March 2, 2020, the virus has resulted in over 80,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with more than 40,000 patients discharged and over 3,000 patients who died.
targetString: Mu Gwokusatu nga 2, 2020, akawuka kaali kamaze okuviirako abantu abasoba mu 80,000 abakakasiddwa okuba ne COVID-19, ng’abasoba mu 40,000 bawonye ate ng’abasoba mu 3,000 bafudde.

sourceString: WHO warns that COVID-19 is “public enemy number 1” and potentially more powerful than terrorism.
targetString: WHO erabula nti COVID-19 ye “mulabe w’omuntu nnamba 1” era ayinza okuba nga wa bulabe okusinga obutujju.

sourceString: According to PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), in less than two months, over 200 papers have been published on COVID-19 including its virology, epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and treatment since the first report on January 7, 2020 that determined the sequence of the virus isolated from multiple patients.
targetString: Okusinziira ku PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), mu kiseera ekitaweza myezi ebiri, empapula ezisoba mu 200 zifulumiziddwa ku COVID-19 omuli ezikwata ku kawuka, obulwadde, ekibuleeta, enkebera n’enzijanjaba okuva ku alipoota esooka nga Janwali 7, 2020 eyazuula endagabutonde y’akawuka akaayawulwa okuva mu balwadde ab’enjawulo.

sourceString: This review attempts to summarize the research progress in the new and swiftly developing subject area.
targetString: Okwekenneenya kuno kugenderera okufunza okunoonyereza okukoleddwa mu kisaawe kino ekipya ekikulaakulanira ku misinde emingi.

sourceString: Whenever possible, we will try to compare COVID-19 with SARS and another CoV-caused disease, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, an outbreak in 2012).
targetString: We kinaasokeranga, tujja kugezaako okugeraageranya COVID-19 ne SARS n’obulwadde obulala obuleetebwa CoV, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, eyabalukawo mu 2012).

sourceString: We will also discuss what we have learned so far regarding the prevention and prognosis of the disease as well as some remaining yet urgent questions.
targetString: Era tujja kukubaganya ebirowoozo ku ebyo bye twakayiga ebikwata ku kwewala obulwadde buno n’ebyo ebiteeberezebwa awamu n’ebibuuzo ebitannayanukulwa so nga bikulu.

sourceString: CoVs have been traditionally considered nonlethal pathogens to humans, mainly causing approximately 15% of common colds 4.
targetString: CoVs bwatwalibwanga ng’obuwuka obutali bwa bulabe nnyo eri abantu, ng’okusinga buleeta ebitundu nga 15% ebya ssenyiga owa bulijjo 4.

sourceString: However, in this century, we have encountered highly pathogenic human CoVs twice, i.e., SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, which caused an outbreak originally in China in 2003 and Saudi Arabia in 2012, respectively, and soon spread to many other countries with horrible morbidity and mortality.
targetString: Wabula, mu kyasa kino, tufunye obuwuka bwa CoVs obw’omutawaana eri abantu emirundi ebiri, kwe kugamba, SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV, obwavaako obulwadde okusooka mu China mu 2003 ne Saudi Arabia mu 2012, amangu ddala ne busaasaanira amawanga amalala ne bulwaza awamu n’okutta abantu abawerako.

sourceString: Therefore, the current COVID-19 is the third CoV outbreak in the recorded history of humans.
targetString: Noolwekyo, COVID-19 aliwo mu kiseera kino ye CoV ow’omulundi ogwokusatu okubalukawo mu byafaayo by’omuntu ebimanyiddwa.

sourceString: As shown in Fig. ​Fig.1,1, clusters of pneumonia that had unknown origins were first reported from Wuhan on December 31, 2019 to the China National Health Commission.
targetString: Nga bwe kiragiddwa mu Kifaananyi. ​Ekifaananyi.1,1, abalwadde ba lubyamira eyali tamanyiddwako nsibuko baasooka kutegeezebwa mu Wuhan nga Deesemba 31, 2019 eri China National Health Commission.

sourceString: Seven days later the sequence of the CoV was released.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’ennaku musanvu endagabutonde ya CoV yafulumizibwa.

sourceString: On January 15, 2020 the first fatal case from Wuhan was reported.
targetString: Nga Janwali 15, 2020 omulwadde eyasooka okuyisibwa obubi okuva mu Wuhan yayogerwako.

sourceString: Meanwhile, the epidemic rapidly spread to the neighboring cities, provinces, and countries.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, obulwadde buno bwasaasaana mangu nnyo mu bibuga ebyetoolodde, n’amawanga.

sourceString: On January 20, the infection of health-care providers was reported, suggesting that human-to-human transmission was possible.
targetString: Nga Janwali 20, okulwala kw’abasawo kwayogerwako, ekyategeeza nti abantu baali basobola okufuna obulwadde buno nga babuggya ku bantu.

sourceString: On January 23, the city of Wuhan was locked down with all its public transportation stopped.
targetString: Nga Janwali 23, ekibuga ky’e Wuhan kyaggalwawo n’entambula yaakyo ey’olukale yonna n’eyimirizibwa.

sourceString: On January 24 the first clinical study on the disease reported that, out of 41 patients with confirmed cases, only 21 had direct contact with the Wuhan seafood market that was considered the starting site of the infection from an unknown animal source.
targetString: Nga Janwali 24 okunoonyereza kw’ekisawo okusooka ku bulwadde buno kwategeeza nti, ku balwadde 41 abaali bakakasiddwa, 21 bokka be baatuukako obutereevu mu katale k’e Wuhan ak’ebyennyanja nga ke kaalowoozebwa okuba ng’obulwadde gye bwatandikira nga buva ku kisolo ekitamanyiddwa.

sourceString: On January 30, WHO declared the outbreak a global health emergency.
targetString: Nga Janwali 30, WHO yalangirira ng’obulwadde buno bwe bwali ekizibu ky’ebyobulamu eky’amangu mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: By the time of this report, the disease has already spread throughout China and near 50 other countries all over the world (Fig. ​(Fig.2).2).
targetString: Mu kiseera alipoota eno w’ekoleddwa, obulwadde bumaze okusaasaanira China ne mu mawanga agawera nga 50 okwetooloola ensi (Ekifaananyi ​(Ekifaananyi.2).2).

sourceString: As the situation is rapidly evolving, the final scope and severity of the outbreak remain to be determined.
targetString: Embeera nga bw’egenda ekyuka, ekinaavaamu n’obunene bw’ekizibu tebunnaba kutegeerwa.

sourceString: On February 11, 2020, a multi-center study on 8,866 patients including 4,021 confirmed COVID-19 patients presented a more updated illustration of the epidemic as follows (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 11, 2020, okunoonyereza okwakolerwa mu bifo eby’enjawulo ku bantu 8,866 omwali n’abakakasiddwa okubeera ne COVID-19 4,021 kwawa ennyinyonnyola empya ey’akawuka bw’eti (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 infected people of all ages, but mainly at the age of 30-65.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 akwata abantu ab’emyaka gyonna, naye okusinga emyaka 30-65.

sourceString: Almost half (47.7%) of the infected individuals were over 50 years old, very few were under 20, and only 14 infected individuals were under the age of 10.
targetString: Kyenkana amakkati (47.7%) g’abantu abaalina obulwadde baali basussa emyaka 50 egy’obukulu, batono nnyo abaali wansi wa 20, so ng’abalwadde 14 bokka be baali wansi w’emyaka 10.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 infected more men (0.31/100,000) than women (0.27/100,000).
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 yali mu basajja bangiko (0.31/100,000) okusinga abakazi (0.27/100,000).

sourceString: COVID-19 expanded in clusters mainly in and around Hubei.
targetString: COVID-19 yeeyongera mu bantu okusinga mu Hubei n’okwetoololawo.

sourceString: COVID-19 took an average of 5 (2-9) days from onset to diagnosis.
targetString: COVID-19 yamala ennaku nga 5 (2-9) okuva lwe yatadika okutuuka lwe yazuulibwa.

sourceString: The average incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days.
targetString: Ekiseera obubonero mwe bweyolekera kyali ennaku nga 4.8 (3.0-7.2).

sourceString: The average time from onset to death was 9.5 (4.8-13) days.
targetString: Ekiseera okuva ku kumufuna okutuuka okufa kyali ennaku 9.5 (4.8-13).

sourceString: The basic reproductive number (R0) was 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05), and the adjusted R0 was 2.23-4.82.
targetString: Abantu omulwadde omu b’asiiga (basic reproductive number, R0) baali 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05), so ng’omuwendo gwa R0 ogwakyusibwamu gwali 2.23-4.82.

sourceString: The number of infected people increased exponentially before 23 Jan. 2020, matching the time of massive transportation before the Spring Festival in China.
targetString: Omuwendo gw’abalwadde gwatumbuka nga 23 Janwali 2020 terunnatuuka, olw’abantu abangi ennyo abaatambula ng’ebikujjuko bya Spring Festival mu China tebinnatuuka.

sourceString: The mortality of patients with confirmed cases was 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%), and the adjusted mortality of all the patients was 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).
targetString: Abalwadde abaafa baali ebitundu 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%), so ng’omuwendo gw’abalwadde abaafa ogwakyusibwamu gwali ebitundu 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).

sourceString: Three major risk factors for COVID-19 were sex (male), age (≥60), and severe pneumonia.
targetString: Obuzibu bwa COVID-19 obusatu obw’amaanyi bwali okwegatta (abasajja), emyaka (≥60), ne lubyamira ow’amaanyi.

sourceString: CoVs are a subfamily of large and enveloped viruses containing a single strand of sense RNA.
targetString: Obuwuka bwa CoVs bugwa mu kika ky’obuwuka obunene era obwetooloddwa olububi nga bulina RNA ya luguwa lumu.

sourceString: They can be divided into four genera, i.e., alpha, beta, gamma, and delta, of which alpha- and beta-CoVs are known to infect humans.
targetString: Busobola okugabanyizibwamu ebika (genera) bina, kwe kugamba, alpha, beta, gamma, ne delta, nga ku bino alpha- ne beta-CoVs bwe bumanyiddwa nti bulwaza abantu.

sourceString: The envelope spike (S) glycoprotein binds to its cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, respectively, and then membrane fusion occurs.
targetString: Olububi lwa (S) glycoprotein lwekwata ku butaffaali bwako obwa angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) ne dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) ku buwuka SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV, mu nsengeka eyo, olwo embubi z’amasavu zombi nne zeegatta.

sourceString: The viral RNA genome is released into the cytoplasm; after replication of the viral genome, genomic RNA accompanied by envelope glycoproteins and nucleocapsid proteins forms virion-containing vesicles, which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release the virus.
targetString: Endagabutonde ya RNA ey’akawuka esindikibwa mu kataffaali; oluvannyuma lw’okukubisaamu endagabutonde y’akawuka, endagabutonde ya RNA ng’eri n’olububi lwa glycoproteins ne nucleocapsid proteins ekola obutaffaali obulimu akawuka, nga kano ke keegatta n’akabubi k’omusaayi okufulumya akawuka.

sourceString: The first genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 was reported on January 10, 2020.
targetString: Endagabutonde ya SARS-CoV-2 eyasooka yafulumizibwa nga Jamwali 10, 2020.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 was found to be a new type of beta-CoV with more than 99.98% genetic identity among 10 sequenced samples collected from the original site of the outbreak, the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 kaazuulwa nga kaali ka kika kipya ekya beta-CoV nga bufaanana mu ndagabutonde ebitonde ebitundu 99.98% mu sampolo 10 ezaakeberwa nga zino zaggyibwa mu kifo ekyasookera ddala okubaamu akawuka kano, ekya Huanan Seafood Market mu Wuhan.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 is genetically more similar to SARS-CoV than to MERS-CoV.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 kafaanana nnyo SARS-CoV mu ndagabutonde okusinga MERS-CoV.

sourceString: Through transmission electron microscopy, SARS-CoV-2 particles were found in ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium.
targetString: Mu kukozesa ebyuma ebitangaaza, obutundutundu bwa SARS-CoV-2 bwazuulwa mu bitundu by’ekkubo ly’omukka ogussibwa.

sourceString: Human ACE2 was found to be a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 as well as SARS-CoV.
targetString: Enzyme zi ACE2 zaasangibwa nga zisika SARS-CoV-2 awamu ne SARS-CoV.

sourceString: However, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to human ACE2 more weakly than that of SARS-CoV, which is coincident with the fact that SARS-CoV-2 causes less severe infection in patients than SARS-CoV.
targetString: Wabula, puloteni ya S eya SARS-CoV-2 yeekwata ku enzyme za ACE2 naye nga teyeenweza nga bwe guba ku SARS-CoV, nga kino kikwatagana n’eky’okuba nti SARS-CoV-2 atuusa obulabe butonoko mu bantu bw’ogeraageranya ne SARS-CoV.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 can also form a novel short protein encoded by orf3b and a secreted protein encoded by orf8.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 era asobola okukola puloteni ennyimpi etalabwangako eyinza okutuumibwa orf3b ne puloteni efulumizibwa eyinza okutuumibwa orf8.

sourceString: The orf3b of SARS-CoV-2 may play a role in the viral pathogenicity and inhibit the expression of IFNβ; however, orf8 does not contain any known functional domain or motif.
targetString: orf3b eya SARS-CoV-2 eyinza okuba nga y’evunaanyizibwa ku kulwaza abantu era n’eremesa IFNβ okweyoleka; wabula, orf8 teriimu kirungo kikola.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., reported the cryo-EM structure of the full-length human ACE2 at 2.9 Å resolution in complex with the amino acid transporter B0AT1.
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 18, 2020, Zhou, ne banne, baalaga obuzimbe bwa cryo-EM obujjuvu obwa enzyme ya ACE2 ku bwawule (resoulution) obwa 2.9 Å mu kabubi ka amino acid aka B0AT1.

sourceString: They found that the complex, which had open and closed conformations, was assembled as a dimer and the ACE2-B0AT1 complex can bind two S proteins, which provides evidence for CoV recognition and infection.
targetString: Baakizuula ng’omugatte guno, ogwalimu atomu ez’emirundi ebiri, gwali gusengekeddwa nga molecule eya atomu engatte era ng’omugatte gwa ACE2-B0AT1 gusobola okugatta puloteni za S, nga kino kiraga obukakafu bw’okulaba CoV n’oyo gw’akutte.

sourceString: B0AT1 may become a therapeutic target for drug screening to suppress SARS-CoV-2 infection.
targetString: B0AT1 eyinza okuba nga yeeruubirirwa okujjanjabwa olw’okukebera eddagala ery’okunafuya SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: The origin and intermediate host
targetString: Ensibuko n’ebikatambuza

sourceString: It has been known that both SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV originated from bats and were transmitted to humans via civet cats and camels, respectively.
targetString: Kimanyiddwa nti SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV bwombi bwasibuka mu buwundo era ne butuuka ku bantu nga buyitira mu mafumbe n’eŋŋamiya, mu busengeke obwo.

sourceString: Through a phylogenetic comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoVs, bats were considered the native host of SARS-CoV-2 as the new virus is 96% identical to two SARS-like CoVs from bats called bat-SL-CoVZX45 and bat-SL-CoVZX21.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya SARS-CoV-2 n’obuwuka bwa CoVs obulala, obuwundo butwalibwa okuba nga bwe bunnansangwa mu kutambuza SARS-CoV-2 olw’okuba ng’akawuka kano kafaananya ebitundu 96% n’obuwuka bwa CoVs obulala bubiri obufaanana SARS nga nabwo bubeera mu buwundo nga buyitibwa bat-SL-CoVZX45 ne bat-SL-CoVZX21.

sourceString: However, what intermediate host helped the virus cross the species barrier to infect humans remains unknown, and the transmission route is yet to be elucidated.
targetString: Wabula, ekisolo kyennyini ekyayamba okubuuka omuziziko okutuuka mu bantu tekinnamanyika, era n’ekkubo lye kayitamu terinnakakasibwa.

sourceString: Ji, et al., proposed snakes as a carrier of the virus from bats to humans which involved homologous recombination within the S protein.
targetString: Ji, ne banne balowooza nti emisota gyaggya akawuka mu buwundo okukatuusa mu bantu nga kino kyalimu okuwaanyisiganya endagabutonde za S protein.

sourceString: According to a study, researchers in Guangzhou, China, suggested that pangolins - long-snouted, ant-eating mammals often used in traditional Chinese medicine - are the potential intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2 based on 99% genetic homology in a CoV discovered in pangolins and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Okusinziira ku kunoonyereza, abanoonyereza mu Guangzhou, China, baalaga nti olugave (pangolin) - ekisolo eky’omumwa omusongovu, ekirya ebiwuka nga kitera okukozesebwa mu bujjanjabi bw’Ekichina obw’ekinnansi - lusobola okuba nga lwe lutambuza SARS-CoV-2 okumutuusa mu bantu okusinziira ku bufaanane bw’endagabutonde obw’ebitundu 99% mu CoV obwazuulwa mu lugave ne mu SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, 1% difference spread all over two genomes is still a big difference; thus, conclusive results for concrete evidence are awaited (Fig. ​(Fig.33).
targetString: Wabula, enjawulo ey’ekitundu 1% wakati w’endagabutonde ebbiri eba ekyali nnene; noolwekyo, obukakafu bwenkomeredde tebunnafunibwa (Fig. ​(Ekifaananyi 33).

sourceString: The physicochemical properties of SARS-CoV-2 are largely not yet known.
targetString: Ebikwata ku bukole bwa SARS-CoV-2 ebisinga tebinnamanyibwa.

sourceString: SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV can survive in vitro for 48 hours in a dry environment and up to 5 days under 20 °C and 40%-50% humidity.
targetString: Obuwuka bwa SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV busobola okumala mu ggiraasi essaawa 48 nga nkalu n’ennaku eziwera 5 mu lutuuyo lw’ebbugumo 20 °C ne 40%-50%.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 may possess similar properties.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 ayinza okuba n’embeera zeezimu.

sourceString: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat at 56 °C for 30 minutes; ether, 75% ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peracetic acid, chloroform, and other fatty solvents, but not chlorhexidine, can effectively inactivate the virus.
targetString: Kiragiddwa nti akawuka ka SARS-CoV-2 tekakwatagana na magulu ga njuba (ultraviolet rays) n’ebbugumu eriweza 56 °C okumala eddakiika 30; walagi ebitundu 75%, eddagala eririmu chlorine, peracetic acid, kalifoomu, n’ebiyiika ebirala eby’ekyovu, naye nga si chlorhexidine, bisobola bulungi okutta akawuka kano.

sourceString: The entire human population generally lacks immunity to SARS-CoV-2 and hence is susceptible to the novel virus.
targetString: Abantu bonna okutwaliza awamu tebalina busibage (immunity) bulwanyisa SARS-CoV-2 nga noolwekyo basobola okukosebwa akawuka kano.

sourceString: Currently, no detailed study has been reported regarding the immunological response to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, tewali kunoonyereza kwakoleddwa kulaga busibage eri SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Thus, we can only refer to previous studies on other CoVs, especially SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV (Fig. ​(Fig.4).4).
targetString: Noolwekyo, tusobola kwesigama ku kunoonyereza kwokka okwakolebwa edda ku CoVs, naddala SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV (Ekifaananyi ​(Ekifaananyi 4).4).

sourceString: In general, after a virus invades the host, it is first recognized by the host innate immune system through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) including C-type lectin-like receptors, Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), and RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).
targetString: Okutwaliza awamu, akawuka bwe kalumba ekisolo ekikatambuza, kasooka kuzuulibwa enkola y’obusibage bw’ekisolo ekyo okuyita mu pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) omuli ezo ez’ebika bya C-type lectin-like receptors), Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), ne RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).

sourceString: Through different pathways, the virus induces the expression of inflammatory factors, maturation of dendritic cells, and synthesis of type I interferons (IFNs) which limit the spreading of the virus and accelerate macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens.
targetString: Nga kayita mu makubo ag’enjawulo, akawuka kaleetawo okuzimba, okukula kwa dendritic cells, n’okuleetawo interferons ez’ekika I interferons (IFNs) eziremesa okusaasaana kw’akawuka ne kyongera obutaffaali bwa macrophage okulwanyisa akawuka.

sourceString: However, the N protein of SARS-CoV can help the virus escape from the immune responses.
targetString: Wabula, puloteni ya N eya SARS-CoV esobola okukayamba okutoloka ku busibage.

sourceString: Soon, the adaptive immune response joins the fight against the virus.
targetString: Mu bwangu, obusibage obufunibwa (adaptive immune response) bwegatta ku lutalo lw’okulwanyisa akawuka.

sourceString: T lymphocytes including CD4+ and CD8+ T cells play an important role in the defense.
targetString: T lymphocytes omuli CD4+ ne CD8+ T cells zikola omulimu munene mu kulwanyisa akawuka.

sourceString: CD4+ T cells stimulate B cells to produce virus-specific antibodies, and CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected cells.
targetString: CD4+ T cells zizuukusa B cells okukola abasirikale abalwanyisa akawuka, ate CD8+ T cells zitta butereevu obutaffaali obulumbiddwa akawuka.

sourceString: T helper cells produce proinflammatory cytokines to help the defending cells.
targetString: T helper cells zikola proinflammatory cytokines okuyamba mu kukuuma obutaffaali.

sourceString: However, CoV can inhibit T cell functions by inducing apoptosis of T cells.
targetString: Wabula, akawuka ka CoV kasobola okulemesa emirimu gya T cell nga kaleetera T cells okufa.

sourceString: The humoral immunity including complements such as C3a and C5a and antibodies is also essential in combating the viral infection.
targetString: Obusibage obuyitibwa humoral immunity nga mw’otwalidde ne puloteni nga C3a ne C5a ne antibodies nabwo bwa mugaso mu kulwanyisa akawuka kano.

sourceString: For example, antibodies isolated from a recovered patient neutralized MERS-CoV.
targetString: Okugeza, antibodies ezaggyibwa mu mulwadde eyawona zaasannyalaza MERS-CoV.

sourceString: On the other hand, an overreaction of the immune system generates a large number of free radicals locally that can cause severe damages to the lungs and other organs, and, in the worst scenario, multi-organ failure and even death.
targetString: Ku ludda olulala, obusibage okukola ennyo kireetera okufulumya molekyu ennyingi (free radicals) eziviirako okukosa ennyo amawuggwe n’ebitundu ebirala, olumu ne kireetera ebitundu by’omubiri bingi okulemererwa n’oluusi okufa.

sourceString: The SARS-CoV-2 infection, featured by clustering onset, is more likely to affect elderly people with comorbidities and pregnant women.
targetString: Akawuka ka SARS-CoV-2, akaasangibwa mu bantu abaasooka okukeberwa, kalabika nga kasinga kukosa bakadde abalina ebirwadde ebirala n’abakazi ab’embuto.

sourceString: It is common that for people who are exposed to a large number of viruses or whose immune functions are compromised, they have higher chance to be infected than others.
targetString: Kya bulijjo abantu abalina obuwuka obw’enjawulo oba abalina obusibage obutono, baba n’emikisa mingi okulwala okusinga ku balala.

sourceString: The estimated mean incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 1-14 days, mostly 3-7 days based on a study of the first 425 cases in Wuhan.
targetString: Ekiseera akawuka ka SARS-CoV-2 kye katwala okulaga obubonero kya nnaku 1-14, ebiseera ebisinga ennaku 3-7 okusinziira ku kunoonyereza okwakolebwa ku balwadde 425 abaasooka mu Wuhan.

sourceString: However, a study on 1,099 cases demonstrates that the incubation period was 3 days on average and ranged from 0 to 24 days.
targetString: Wabula, okunoonyereza okwakolebwa mu balwadde 1,099 kulaga nti okutwalira awamu akawuka kano kamala ennaku 3 okulaga obubonero era ng’ennaku ziba wakati wa 0 ku 24.

sourceString: A more recent study, as described above, demonstrates that the incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days based on the demography of 8,866 cases.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okukyali okupya, okwogeddwako waggulu, kulaga nti kamala ennaku 4.8 (3.0-7.2) okusinziira ku bikwata ku balwadde 8,866.

sourceString: It is very important for health authorities to adjust the effective quarantine time based on the most accurate incubation period, thus preventing infected but symptomless people from transmitting the virus to others.
targetString: Kikulu nnyo ab’ebyobulamu okuteeka ennaku za kalantiini nga beesigama ku kiseera ekituufu akawuka kye kamala okulaga obubonero, basobole okwewala abantu abalina akawuka naye nga tebalina bubonero okusiiga abalala akawuka.

sourceString: As a common practice, individuals exposed to, or infected by, the virus are usually required to be quarantined for 14 days.
targetString: Ekitera okukolebwa, abantu ababeera mu mbeera erimu akawuka oba abalina akawuka baba beetaaga okubeera mu kalantiini okumala ennaku 14.

sourceString: Should the quarantine time be extended to 24 days?
targetString: Ekiseera abantu kye bamala mu kalantiini kyetaaga okwongezebwayo kituuke ku nnaku 24?

sourceString: Fever is often the major and initial symptom of COVID-19, which can be accompanied by no symptom or other symptoms such as dry cough, shortness of breath, muscle ache, dizziness, headache, sore throat, rhinorrhea, chest pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
targetString: Omusujja ke katera okubeera akabonero ka COVID-19 akakulu era akasooka, nga gusobola obutagobererwa kabonero konna oba obubonero obulala ng’akakololo akakalu, okukaluubirirwa mu kussa, okulumwa ebinywa, kammunguluze, okulumwa omutwe, amabwa mu bulago, eminyira mu nnyindo, okulumwa ekifuba, okuddukana, okusiikuuka emmeeme, n’okusesema.

sourceString: Some patients experienced dyspnea and/or hypoxemia one week after the onset of the disease.
targetString: Abalwadde abamu baafuna okukaluubirirwa mu kussa ne/oba okubulwa empewo mu musaayi nga wayise wiiki emu okuva bwe baafuna obulwadde.

sourceString: In severe cases, patients quickly progressed to develop acute respiratory syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis, and coagulopathy.
targetString: Mu mbeera enzibu ennyo, abalwadde baayanguwa okufuna obuzibu bw’amazzi okugenda mu mawuggwe, puleesa eya wansi (septic shock), metabolic acidosis, ne coagulopathy.

sourceString: Patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms and acute fever, even without pulmonary imaging abnormalities, should be screened for the virus for early diagnosis.
targetString: Abalwadde abalina omusujja ne/oba obubonero obwekuusa ku kussa n’omusujja ogw’amangu, ne bwe baba nga tebalina buzibu ku mawuggwe, basaana okukeberwa nga bukyali okuzuula oba nga balina akawuka.

sourceString: A demographic study in late December of 2019 showed that the percentages of the symptoms were 98% for fever, 76% for dry cough, 55% for dyspnea, and 3% for diarrhea; 8% of the patients required ventilation support.
targetString: Okunoonyereza kw’ebikwata ku balwadde okwakolebwa mu Deesemba wa 2019 kwalaga nti ebitundu by’obubonero ku buli kikumi byali 98% ku musujja, 76% ku kakololo akakalu, 55% ku kukaluubirirwa mu kussa, ne 3% ku kuddukana; abalwadde ebitundu 8% baali beetaaga ebyuma ebiyamba mu kussa.

sourceString: Similar findings were reported in two recent studies of a family cluster and a cluster caused by transmission from an asymptomatic individual.
targetString: Ebyazuulwa ebifaananako n’ebyo byalagibwa mu kunoonyereza okw’emirundi ebiri okwakakolebwa ku balwadde ab’enju emu n’abalwadde abaasiigibwa omuntu ataalaga bubonero.

sourceString: Comparably, a demographic study in 2012 showed that MERS-CoV patients also had fever (98%), dry cough (47%), and dyspnea (55%) as their main symptoms.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya, okunoonyereza kw’ebikwata ku bantu okwakolebwa mu 2012 kwalaga nti abalwadde ba MERS-CoV nabo baalina omusujja (98%), akakololo akakalu (47%), n’okukaluubirirwa mu kussa (55%) ng’obubonero bwabwe obukulu.

sourceString: However, 80% of them required ventilation support, much more than COVID-19 patients and consistent with the higher lethality of MERS than of COVID-19.
targetString: Wabula, ebitundu 80% ku bo baali beetaaga ebyuma ebiyambako mu kussa, okusingira ddala abalwadde ba COVID-19 era nga kino kigendera wamu n’eky’okuba nti MERS yali wa bulabe okusinga ku COVID-19.

sourceString: Diarrhea (26%) and sore throat (21%) were also observed with MERS patients.
targetString: Okuddukana (26%) n’amabwa mu bulago (21%) nabyo byalabwa mu balwadde ba MERS.

sourceString: In SARS patients, it has been demonstrated that fever (99%-100%), dry cough (29%-75%), dyspnea (40%-42%), diarrhea (20-25%), and sore throat (13-25%) were the major symptoms and ventilation support was required for approximately 14%-20% of the patients.
targetString: Mu balwadde ba SARS, kiragiddwa nti omusujja (99%-100%), akakololo akakalu (29%-75%), okukaluubirirwa mu kussa (40%-42%), okuddukana (20-25%), n’amabwa mu bulago (13-25%) bwe bwali obubonero obukulu era ng’ebyuma ebiyamba ku kussa byali byetaagisa mu balwadde nga 14%-20%.

sourceString: By February 14, the mortality of COVID-19 was 2% when the confirmed cases reached 66,576 globally.
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 14, abantu abaali baakafa COVID-19 baali ebitundu 2% ng’abalwadde abakakasiddwa bali 66,576 mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: Comparably, the mortality of SARS by November 2002 was 10% of 8,096 confirmed cases.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya, abantu abaali bafudde SARS mu Noovemba 2002 baali ebitundu 10% ku balwadde abakakasiddwa 8,096.

sourceString: For MERS, based on a demographic study in June 2012, the mortality was 37% of 2,494 confirmed cases.
targetString: Ate ku MERS, okusinziira ku kunoonyereza kw’ebikwata ku bantu okwakolebwa mu Gwomukaaga 2012, abantu abaali bafudde baali ebitundu 37% ku balwadde abakakasiddwa 2,494.

sourceString: An earlier study reported that the R0 of SARS-CoV-2 was as high as 6.47 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 5.71-7.23, whereas the R0 of SARS-CoV only ranged from 2 to 4.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okwakolebwa emabegako kwalaga nti R0 ya SARS-CoV-2 yali waggulu nga ya 6.47 ng’omuwendo ogwateeberezebwa (confidence interval, CI) gwali ebitundu 95% nga gwali 5.71-7.23, so nga R0 ya SARS-CoV yali wakati wa 2 ku 4 yokka.

sourceString: A comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with MERS-CoV and SARA-CoV regarding their symptoms, mortality, and R0 is presented in Table ​Table1.1.
targetString: Okugeraageranya SARS-CoV-2 awamu ne MERS-CoV ne SARA-CoV ku bikwata ku bubonero bwabwo, enzita yaabwo, ne R0 kulagiddwa mu Mweso ​Omweso1.1.

sourceString: The above figures suggest that SARS-CoV-2 has a higher ability to spread than MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, but it is less lethal than the latter two.
targetString: Emiwendo egyo giraga nti SARS-CoV-2 alina obusobozi bw’okusaasaana bungi okusinga ku MERS-CoV ne SARS-CoV, naye nga si ka bulabe kwenkana obulala obubiri.

sourceString: Thus, it is much more challenging to control the epidemic of SARS-CoV-2 than those of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV.
targetString: Noolwekyo, kizibu nnyo okukkakkanya ekizibu kya SARS-CoV-2 okusinga ekya MERS-CoV ne SARS-CoV.

sourceString: Clustered onset often happens in the same family or from the same gathering or vehicle such as a cruise ship.
targetString: Abantu abalwalira okumu batera okubeera mu maka gamu oba mu lukuŋŋaana lumu oba mu kidduka kimu nga ku lyato.

sourceString: Patients often have a history of travel or residence in Wuhan or other affected areas or contact with infected individuals or patients in the recent two weeks before the onset.
targetString: Abalwadde ab’engeri eno baba baatambula okuva oba nga baabeerako mu Wuhan oba ebifo ebirala ebyalimu obulwadde oba nga baaliko n’abantu abaalina akawuka oba abalwadde wiiki bbiri nga tebannafuna bulwadde.

sourceString: However, it has been reported that people can carry the virus without symptoms longer than two weeks and cured patients discharged from hospitals can carry the virus again, which sends out an alarm to increase the time for quarantine.
targetString: Wabula, kitegeezeddwa nti abantu basobola okubeera n’akawuka naye ne batalaga bubonero okumala ekiseera ekisukka wiiki ebbiri era n’abalwadde abawonye ne basiibulwa mu malwaliro nabo basobola okuddamu okubeera n’akawuka, nga kino kiraga obwetaavu bw’okwongera ku kiseera kya kalantiini.

sourceString: Patients have normal or reduced number of peripheral white blood cells (especially lymphocytes) at the early stage.
targetString: Abalwadde baba n’omuwendo ogwa bulijjo oba ogukendedde ogw’obutaffaali bw’omu mu musaayi obweru mu musaayi ogutambula (peripheral white blood cells) (naddala lymphocytes) mu kiseera ekisooka.

sourceString: For example, lymphopenia with white blood cell count < 4×109/L including lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, and elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia were found in 1,099 COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Okugeza, lymphopenia awamu ne white blood cell count < 4×109/L nga mw’otwalidde ne lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, ne aspartate aminotransferase ayongezeddwa ne viremia byasangibwa mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abawera 1,099 COVID-19.

sourceString: The levels of liver and muscle enzymes and myoglobin were increased in the blood of some patients, and C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation were increased in the blood of most patients.
targetString: Omuwendo gwa enzyme z’ekibumba ne myoglobin gwalinnyisibwa mu musaayi gw’abalwadde abamu, era ne C-reactive protein ne erythrocyte sedimentation nabyo byalinnya mu musaayi gw’abalwadde abasinga.

sourceString: In patients with severe cases, the level of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product present in the blood, was elevated, and lymphocyte count was progressively reduced.
targetString: Mu balwadde abaali obubi ennyo, omuwendo gwa D-dimer, ng’eno fibrin degradation product ebeera mu musaayi, yeeyongera, n’omuwendo gwa lymphocyte ne gukendeera.

sourceString: Abnormalities in chest radiography are found in most COVID-19 patients and featured by bilateral patchy shadows or ground glass opacity in the lungs.
targetString: Waliwo obuzibu obulabwa mu kifuba mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abasinga obungi era nga kino kigendera wamu n’obuzibu mu mawuggwe gaabwe (bilateral patchy shadows oba ground glass opacity).

sourceString: Patients often develop an atypical pneumonia, acute lung injury, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
targetString: Abalwadde batera okufuna lubyamira atali wa bulijjo, okukosebwa okw’amangu mu mawuggwe, n’obuzibu mu kkubo ly’omukka ogussibwa (acute respiratory distress syndrome, ARDS).

sourceString: When ARDS happens, uncontrolled inflammation, fluid accumulation, and progressive fibrosis severely compromise the gas exchange.
targetString: ARDS bw’ebaawo, wabaawo okuzimba n’okufuna amazzi amangi, n’ennyama n’ebikka ebiwundu ekireetawo obuzibu mu kuwaanyisiganya kw’omukka.

sourceString: Dysfunction of type-I and type-II pneumocytes decreases the surfactant level and increases surface tension, thus reducing the ability of the lungs to expand and heightening the risk of lung collapse.
targetString: Pneumocytes ez’ekika I ne II (type-I and type-II pneumocytes) zikendeeza omuwendo gwa surfactant ne zongeza okunyigirizibwa kungulu, ekyo ne kikendeeza obusobozi bw’amawuggwe okugaziwa ne kyongera emikisa gy’amawuggwe okulemererwa.

sourceString: Therefore, the worst chest radiographic findings often parallel the most severe extent of the disease.
targetString: Noolwekyo, ebyazuulibwa ebikyasinze okubeera ebibi mu kukebera ekifuba bitera okuba nga byenkanankana n’embeera y’obulwadde ekyasinze okubeera embi.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, the first pathological analysis of COVID-19 demonstrated the desquamation of pneumocytes, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, and multinucleated syncytial cells in the lungs of a patient who died of the disease, consistent with the pathology of viral infection and ARDS and similar to that of SARS and MERS patients.
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 18, 2020, okwekenneenya obulwadde bwa COVID-19 okwasooka mu ggezeserezo kwalaga okuyubuka kwa pneumocytes, okukolebwa kw’olububi lwa hyaline, n’okwatika kw’olususu, ne multinucleated syncytial cells mu mawuggwe g’omulwadde eyafa obulwadde buno, nga kino kifaanana n’okwekenneenya abalwadde abalina obuwuka ne ARDS era nga kifaanana n’eky’abalwadde ba SARS ne MERS.

sourceString: The detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used as the major criteria for the diagnosis of COVID-19.
targetString: Okuzuula RNA ya SARS-CoV-2 okuyita mu reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) kyakozesebwa ng’enkola eyasinga mu kukebera COVID-19.

sourceString: However, due to the high false-negative rate, which may accelerate the epidemic, clinical manifestations started to be used for diagnosis (which no longer solely relied on RT-PCR) in China on February 13, 2020.
targetString: Wabula, olw’okuba nga waliwo bangi abazuulwa nti tebalina kawuka so nga bakalina, ekiyinza okusajjula ekizibu ky’obulwadde, obubonero bw’embeera y’obulamu bwatandika okukozesebwa mu kukebera (nga tebakyesigama ku RT-PCR yekka) mu China mu Gwokubiri nga 13, 2020.

sourceString: A similar situation also occurred with the diagnosis of SARS.
targetString: Embeera y’emu era yaliwo ne ku kukebera SARS.

sourceString: Therefore, a combination of disease history, clinical manifestations, laboratory tests, and radiological findings is essential and imperative for making an effective diagnosis.
targetString: Noolwekyo, okugatta ebyafaayo by’obuwadde, obubonero, okukebera kw’omu ggezeserezo, n’okukuba ekifaananyi kikulu era kisaanye okukolebwa okusobola okuzuula obulungi obulwadde.

sourceString: On February 14, 2020, the Feng Zhang group described a protocol of using the CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique to detect SARS-CoV-2, which detects synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter of input) using a dipstick in less than an hour without requiring elaborate instrumentation.
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 14, 2020, Feng Zhang group yannyonnyola enkola y’okukozesa akakodyo CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique okuzuula SARS-CoV-2, nga kano kazuula obutundutundu bwa SARS-CoV-2 RNA ku 20 × 10-18 mol/L okutuuka ku 200 × 10-18 mol/L (kkopi 10-100 buli microliter y’ekikeberwa) nga bakozesa akati (dipstick) mu kiseera ekitaweza ddakiika asatu awatali kwetaaga kupima bintu bingi.

sourceString: Hopefully, the new technique can dramatically enhance the sensitivity and convenience if verified in clinical samples.
targetString: Kisuubirwa nti akakodyo kano akapya kasobola okuyamba ennyo mu kukebera singa kaba kakasiddwa mu sampolo ezikeberwa mu mageserezo.

sourceString: Due to the lack of experience with the novel CoV, physicians can mainly provide supportive care to COVID-19 patients, while attempting a variety of therapies that have been used or proposed before for the treatment of other CoVs such as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV and other viral diseases (Table ​(Table2).2).
targetString: Olw’obutabaawo bumanyirivu ku kawuka ka CoV akabadde tekamanyiddwa, abasawo okusinga basobola kulabirira bulabirizi balwadde ba COVID-19, nga bwe bagezaako eddagala ery’enjawulo eryali likozeseddwako oba nga lyalagirwako emabega mu kujjanjaba obuwuka bwa CoV obulala nga SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV n’obulwadde bw’obuwuka obulala (Omweso ​(Omweso2).2).

sourceString: These therapies include current and potential treatments with antiviral drugs, immunosuppressants, steroids, plasma from recovered patients, Chinese medicine, and psychological support.
targetString: Eddagala lino mulimu erikozesebwa mu kiseera kino n’eryo eriyinza okujjanjaba obuwuka, erikendeeza ku busibage, steroids, omusaayi (plasma) okuva ku bantu abawonye, eddagala ly’Ekichina, n’okubudaabudibwa.

sourceString: Even plasma from recovered patients was proposed to be used for treatment.
targetString: Ne plasma okuva ku bantu abawonye naye yateesebwa okukozesebwa ng’eddagala.

sourceString: Pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop antibodies and vaccines against the virus.
targetString: Kampuni ezikola eddagala zikola butaweera okukola antibodies n’eddagala erigema akawuka kano.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 mainly attacks the lungs in the beginning and probably also attacks, to a lesser degree, other organs that express ACE2, such as the gastrointestinal system and the kidneys.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 kasinga kulumba mawuggwe mu kusooka era nga kirabika oluvannyuma ne kalyoka kalumba ebitundu ebirala ebirina ACE2, omwo nga mwe muli omuyungo gw’ebyenda (gastrointestinal system) n’ensigo.

sourceString: Nevertheless, respiratory dysfunction and failure are the major threat to the patients and the major cause of death.
targetString: Wadde nga guli bwegutyo, obuzibu bw’okulemererwa okussa kye kizibu ekisinga mu balwadde era kye kisinga okuviirako okufa.

sourceString: Thus, respiratory support is critical to relieve the symptoms and save lives and includes general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, and invasive mechanical ventilation depending on the severity of the disease.
targetString: Noolwekyo, ebyuma ebiyamba mu kussa bikulu nnyo mu kukola ku buzibu bw’okussa n’okutaasa obulamu era nga kino kizingiramu ebintu nga general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, ne invasive mechanical ventilation okusinziira ku bungi bw’obulwadde.

sourceString: Patients with severe respiratory symptoms have to be supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), a modified cardiopulmonary bypass technique used for the treatment of life-threatening cardiac or respiratory failure.
targetString: Abalwadde abalina obuzibu obw’amaanyi mu kussa balina okuyambibwako ne extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), nga y’enkola ekozesebwa mu kujjanjaba ababa balemereddwa ddala okussa ekiyinza okubaviirako okufa.

sourceString: In addition, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, the prevention and treatment of secondary infection and septic shock, and the protection of the functions of the vital organs are also essential for SARS-CoV-2 patients.
targetString: Ekirala, okukuuma ekigero kya electrolyte, okwewala n’okujjanjaba akawuka akalala akayinza okulumba omulwadde n’akawuka okusaasaanira omubiri, n’okukuuma ebitundu by’omubiri ebikulu ne bisigala nga bikola nabyo bikulu nnyo mu balwadde ba SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: It has been known that a cytokine storm results from an overreaction of the immune system in SARS and MERS patients.
targetString: Kibadde kimanyiddwa nti cytokine storm ava ku busibage okukola ekisusse (overreaction of the immune system) mu balwadde ba SARS ne MERS.

sourceString: Cytokine storm is a form of systemic inflammatory response featured by the release of a series of cytokines including TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1.
targetString: Cytokine storm kwe kwanukula kw’omubiri okulimu okuzimba olw’okufulumya cytokines ez’enjawulo omuli TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, ne MCP-1.

sourceString: These cytokines induce immune cells to release a vast number of free radicals which are the major cause of ARDS and multiple organ failure.
targetString: Cytokines zino zireetera obutaffaali obulwanyisa endwadde okufulumya molekyu ennyingi nga zino ze zisinga okuviirako ARDS n’ebitundu by’omubiri eby’enjawulo okulemererwa.

sourceString: Immunosuppression is essential in the treatment of cytokine storms, especially in severe patients.
targetString: Okukendeeza ku busibage kikulu mu kujjanjaba cytokine storms, naddala mu balwadde abali obubi.

sourceString: Corticosteroids and tocilizumab, an anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody, have been used to treat cytokine storm.
targetString: Corticosteroids ne tocilizumab, ng’eno anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody, zikozeseddwa okujjanjaba cytokine storm.

sourceString: Other immunosuppression treatments for cytokine storm include the modulation of T cell-directed immune response; the blockade of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor of cytokine signaling 4; and HDAC inhibitors.
targetString: Enzijanjaba ya cytokine storm endala ey’okukendeeza ku busibage mwemuli okutuukanya T cell-directed immune response; okuggalira IFN-γ, IL-1, ne TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor of cytokine signaling 4; ne HDAC inhibitors.

sourceString: Steroids, as immunosuppressants, were widely used in the treatment of SARS to reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.
targetString: Steroids, nga zikozesebbwa okukendeeza ku busibage, zaakozesebwa nnyo mu kujjanjaba SARS okukendeeza ku kukosebwa kw’okuzimba.

sourceString: However, steroids at high dosages were not beneficial to severe lung injury in SARS and COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Wabula, steroids bwe zikozesebwa mu bungi tezaayamba ku bulabe obutuusibwa ku mawuggwe mu balwadde ba SARS ne COVID-19.

sourceString: Instead, they may cause severe side effects, especially avascular osteonecrosis, dramatically affecting the prognosis.
targetString: Mpozzi ate, ziyinza okuviirako obukosefu (side effects) obw’amaanyi, naddala avascular osteonecrosis, ekiyinza okukosa ebyo ebisuubirwa okuvaamu.

sourceString: Nevertheless, short courses of corticosteroids at low-to-moderate doses have been recommended to be used prudently for critically ill COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Newankubadde guli gutyo, kiteeseddwa nti corticosteroids akozesebwe mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abayi ennyo mu doozi entonotono.

sourceString: At the time of writing, no effective antiviral therapy has been confirmed.
targetString: Mu kiseera ky’okuwandiikiramu olupapula luno, tewali ddagala lyakakasiddwa kuwonya kawuka kano.

sourceString: However, intravenous administration with remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, has been found to be efficacious in an American patient with COVID-19.
targetString: Wabula, okuweebwa remdesivir ng’ayisibwa mu misuwa, ng’eno nucleotide analog, kyazuulibwa nga kyakola ku mulwadde wa COVID-19 Omumerika.

sourceString: Remdesivir is a novel antiviral drug developed by Gilead initially for the treatment of diseases caused by Ebola and Marlburg viruses.
targetString: Remdesivir ddagala lya buwuka ppya nga lyakolebwa Gilead nga mu kusooka lyakozesebwa mu kujjanjaba endwadde ezireetebwa obuwuka bwa Ebola ne Marlburg.

sourceString: Later, remdesivir also demonstrated possible inhibition of other single stranded RNA viruses including MERS and SARS viruses.
targetString: Oluvannyuma, remdesivir era kyazuulibwa ng’asobola okujjanjaba obuwuka obulala obulina single stranded RNA omuli MERS ne SARS.

sourceString: Based on these, Gilead has provided the compound to China to conduct a pair of trials on SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals, and the results are highly anticipated.
targetString: Nga beesigama ku bino, aba Gilead baawa China eddagala lino okuligezesa ku bantu abalina SARS-CoV-2, era ebinaavaamu birindiriddwa n’amaddu mangi.

sourceString: In addition, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin have been suggested as potential therapies for patients with acute respiratory symptoms.
targetString: Ekirala, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, ne ribavirin nalyo liteeseddwa ng’eddagala eriyinza okujjanjaba abalwadde abalina obuzibu obw’amaanyi mu kussa.

sourceString: Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, liver damage, and other adverse reactions can occur following combined therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir.
targetString: Ekiddukano, okusiikuuka emmeeme, okusesema, okukosebwa ekibumba, n’obuzibu obulala obw’amaanyi busobola okujjawo nga lopinavir/ritonavir agattiddwa n’eddagala eddala.

sourceString: The interaction of these treatments with other drugs used in the patients should be monitored carefully.
targetString: Entabagana y’eddagala lino n’eddagala eddala nga likozeseddwa ku balwadde esaanye okulondoolwa n’obwegendereza.

sourceString: Plasma from recovered patients and antibody generation
targetString: Plasma okuva mu balwadde abawonye n’okukola zi antibody

sourceString: The collection of the blood from patients who recovered from a contagious disease to treat other patients suffering from the same disease or to protect healthy individuals from catching the disease has a long history.
targetString: Okuggya omusaayi ku bantu abawonye obulwadde obusiigibwa okusobola okujjanjaba abalwadde abalala abalina obulwadde bwebumu obwo oba okutaasa abantu abalamu obutafuna bulwadde obwo kibaddewo okumala ekiseera.

sourceString: Indeed, recovered patients often have a relatively high level of antibodies against the pathogen in their blood.
targetString: Mu butuufu, abantu abawonye obulwadde batera okuba ne antibody nnyingi ezisobola okulwanyisa obulwadde obwo mu musaayi gwabwe.

sourceString: Antibodies are an immunoglobulin (Ig) produced by B lymphocytes to fight pathogens and other foreign objects and they recognize unique molecules in the pathogens and neutralize them directly.
targetString: Antibodies buba butaffaali obukolebwa B lymphocytes okulwanyisa obuwuka n’ebintu ebirala ebitalina kubeera mu mubiri era bukenga molekyu ez’enjawulo eziba mu buwuka ne bubunafuya butereevu.

sourceString: Based on this, plasma was collected from the blood of a group of patients who recovered from COVID-19 and was injected into 10 seriously ill patients.
targetString: Nga basinziira ku kino, plasma yaggyibwa mu musaayi gw’ekibinja ky’abalwadde abaawona COVID-19 n’akubwa mu balwadde 10 abaali obubi ennyo.

sourceString: Their symptoms improved within 24 hours, accompanied by reduced inflammation and viral loads and improved oxygen saturation in the blood.
targetString: Embeera yaabwe yalongooka mu ssaawa 24, era n’okuzimba ne kukendeera n’omuwendo gw’akawuka ne gukendeera era n’entambula y’empewo mu musaayi n’etereera.

sourceString: However, verification and clarification are necessary to propose the method for large-scale use before specific therapies are not yet developed.
targetString: Wabula, walina okubaawo okwekakasa n’okutangaaza okusobola okuyisa enkola yonna okukozesebwa ku bantu abangi ng’enkola eyo tennaba kukulaakulanyizibwa.

sourceString: In addition, given the therapeutic effects, some disadvantages associated with the plasma should be considered carefully.
targetString: Ekirala, olw’ebyo ebiva mu kukozesa eddagala, ebibi ebyekuusa ku plasma birina okusooka okutunuulirwa.

sourceString: For example, antibodies can overstimulate the immune response and cause cytokine release syndrome, which is potentially a life-threatening toxicity.
targetString: Okugeza, antibodies zisobola okuviirako obusibage okweyongera ennyo ne kireetawo cytokine release syndrome, nga kino kivaamu obutwa obw’obulabe ennyo.

sourceString: The concentration of antibodies in the blood is usually low, and the demand for the plasma is large to treat critically ill patients.
targetString: Antibodies ezibeera mu musaayi zitera kubeera ntono, ate ng’obwetaavu bwa plasma bubeera bungi okusobola okujjanjaba abantu abalwadde ennyo.

sourceString: It is difficult to develop and produce specific antibodies rapidly enough to fight against a global epidemic.
targetString: Kizibu okukulaakulanya n’okufulumya antibody mu bwangu ezimala okulwanyisa ekizibu ky’obulwadde obuli mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: Thus, it is more critical and practical to isolate B cells from recovered patients and identify the genetic codes encoding effective antibodies or screen for effective antibodies against essential proteins of the virus.
targetString: Noolwekyo, ekiba kisoboka kwe kwawula B cells okuva mu bantu abawonye ne tumanya koodi z’endagabutonde za antibody ezirwanyisa obulwadde oba okukebera ne tulaba antibody ezirwanyisa obulwadde puloteni z’akawuka enkulu.

sourceString: This way, we can readily scale up the production of the antibodies.
targetString: Mu ngeri eno, tusobola okwongera ku bungi bwa antibody ezikolebwa.

sourceString: TCM has been used to treat a variety of diseases in China for thousands of years.
targetString: TCM akozeseddwa okujjanjaba endwadde eziwerako mu China okumala enkumi n’enkumi z’emyaka.

sourceString: However, its effects largely rely on a combination of multiple components in a formula that varies depending on the diagnosis of a disease based on the theories of TCM.
targetString: Wabula, obukozi bwe bwesigama nnyo ku kugatta ebirungo eby’enjawulo mu ddagala ebikyukakyuka okusinziira ku kiba kizuuliddwa ku bulwadde okusinziira ku binnyonnyola (theory) TCM.

sourceString: Most of the effective components remain unknown or are vague as it is difficult to extract and verify such components or their optimal combinations.
targetString: Ebirungo ebikola ebisinga tebimanyiddwa oba tebitegeerekeka bulungi olw’okuba nga kizibu okukenenulamu ebirungo ebyo ne bikakasibwa oba ebibikola.

sourceString: Currently, due to the lack of effective and specific therapy for COVID-19, TCM has become one of the major alternative treatments for patients with light to moderate symptoms or for those who have recovered from severe stages.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, olw’okuba nga tewali ddagala limanyiddwa kujjanjaba COVID-19, TCM lye limu ku ddagala erisinga okukozesebwa mu kujjanjaba abalwadde abalina obubonero obutonotono oba abo abawonye emitendera emingiko.

sourceString: For example, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules and Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules were found to be effective for COVID-19 treatment.
targetString: Okugeza, kapiso za Shu Feng Jie Du n’eza Lian Hua Qing Wen zaazuulibwa nga zikola bulungi ku kujjanjaba COVID-19.

sourceString: Top cure rates in the treatment of COVID-19 patients were observed in several provinces in China that used TCM in 87% of their patients, including Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), and Hunan (50%), whereas Hubei province, which used TCM in only approximately 30% of its COVID-19 patients, had the lowest cure rate (13%).
targetString: Abalwadde bangi baawona COVID-19 province eziwerako mu China nga bajjanjabwa ne TCM mu bitundu 87% eby’abalwadde, omuli Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), ne Hunan (50%), so nga mu Hubei province, eyakozesa TCM mu bitundu nga 30% byokka eby’abalwadde bwa COVID-19, okuwona gye kwasinga okubeera wansi (13%).

sourceString: However, this is quite a rough comparison as many other impact factors such as the number and severity of the patients should be included in the evaluation.
targetString: Wabula, okugeraageranya kuno si kwa bwenkanya olw’okuba nga waliwo ensonga endala nnyingi ng’omuwendo n’embeera y’abalwadde ezirina okussibwa mu kwekaliriza.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, Boli Zhang and coworkers published a study to compare western medicine (WM) treatment alone with combined treatment of WM and TCM.
targetString: Mu Gwokubiri nga 18, 2020, Boli Zhang ne bakozi banne baafulumya ebyava mu kunoonyereza nga bageraageranya okujjanjabisa eddagala ly’ekizungu (western medicine) lyokka n’obujjanjabi obugattiddwa nga mulimu eddagala ly’ekizingu ne TCM.

sourceString: They found that the times needed for body temperature recovery, symptom disappearance, and hospitalization were remarkably shorter in the WM+TCM group than in the WM only group.
targetString: Baakizuula nti ebiseera ebyetaagisa ebbugumu ly’omubiri okuddawo, obubonero okubula, n’okubeera ku kitanda byali bimpi nnyo mu kibinja eky’eddagala ly’ekizungu+TCM okusinga mu kibinja eky’eddagala ly’ekizungu lyokka.

sourceString: Most impressively, the rate for symptomatic worsening (from light to severe) was remarkably lower for the WM+TCM group than for the WM only group (7.4% versus 46.2%) and the mortality was lower in the WM+TCM group than WM only group (8.8% versus 39%).
targetString: Ekisinga okusanyusa, okusajjuka kw’obubonero (okuva ku kubeera obutonotono okufuuka obw’amaanyi ennyo) kwali kutono nnyo mu kibinja ky’eddagala ly’ekizungu+TCM okusinga mu kibinja ky’eddagala ly’ekizungu lyokka (7.4% bw’ogeraageranya ne 46.2%) ate era okufa kwali kutono mu kibinja ky’eddagala ly’ekizungu+TCM okusinga mu kibinja ky’eddagala ly’ekizungu lyokka (8.8% bw’ogeraageranya ne 39%).

sourceString: Nevertheless, the efficacy and safety of TCM still await more well-controlled trials at larger scales and in more centers.
targetString: Weewaawo guli bwegutyo, obukozi n’obulungi bwa TCM bukyetaaga okugezesa okulimu ensonga endala nga kukolebwa ku balwadde abasingako ne mu bifo ebisingako.

sourceString: It would also be intriguing to characterize the mechanism of actions and clarify the effective components of TCM treatments or their combinations if possible.
targetString: Era kyandinyumye nnyo okunnyonnyola ebikolebwa n’okutangaaza ku bikolo bya TCM ebijjanjaba oba ebibikola bwe kiba nga kisoboka.

sourceString: Patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 mostly experience great fear of the highly contagious and even fatal disease, and quarantined people also experience boredom, loneliness, and anger.
targetString: Abalwadde abateeberezebwa oba abakakasiddwa okuba ne COVID-19 batera okuba n’okutya okungi okw’obulwadde buno obusiigibwa ennyo era obw’obulabe, n’abantu abateereddwa mu kalantiini nabo bafuna ekiwuubaalo, ettuulawamu, n’obusungu.

sourceString: Furthermore, symptoms of the infection such as fever, hypoxia, and cough as well as adverse effects of the treatments such as insomnia caused by corticosteroids can lead to more anxiety and mental distress.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, obubonero bw’obulwadde okugeza omusujja, okubulwa omukka mu mubiri, n’okukolola awamu n’obuzibu obw’amaanyi obuva ku ddagala ng’okubulwa otulo ebireetebwa corticosteroids bisobola okwongera ku kweraliikirira n’okutabuka omutwe.

sourceString: In the early phase of the SARS outbreak, a range of psychiatric morbidities including persistent depression, anxiety, panic attacks, psychomotor excitement, psychotic symptoms, delirium, and even suicidality were reported.
targetString: Mu biseera ebyasooka nga SARS yaakabalukawo, waaliwo endwadde nnyingi ezeekuusa ku mutwe omuli okwennyika ebirowoozo okutatadde, okweraliikirira, okutya ennyo, okupakunkana, okulowooza ebitaliiyo, obutassaayo mwoyo, n’okwetta.

sourceString: Mandatory contact tracing and quarantine, as a part of the public health responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, can make people more anxious and guilty about the effects of the contagion, quarantine, and stigma on their families and friends.
