sourceString: Thus far, WIV1 represents the most closely related ancestor of SARS-CoV in bats, sharing 95% nucleotide sequence homology.
targetString: Ne gye buli eno, WIV1 kakiikirira oluganda olusinga okuba okumpi ne SARS-CoV mu buwundo, obugabana ebitundu 95% eby’endabutonde.

sourceString: Albeit the high homology between these two viruses, it is generally believed that WIV1 is not the immediate parental virus of SARS-CoV and bats are not the immediate reservoir host of SARS-CoV.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko endagabutonde efaanana ennyo wakati w’obuwuka buno bwombi, kikkirizibwa wonna nti WIV1 si ke kawuka ka SAR-CoV akazaala obulala akali okumpi ate n’obuwundo si ke kali okumpi ku byekwatako akawuka ka SARS-CoV.

sourceString: Phylogenetic analysis clusters MERS-CoV to the same group as bat CoV-HKU4 and bat CoV-HKU5.
targetString: Enneekenneenya y’enfuukafuuka y’obuwuka eteeka MERS-CoV mu kibinja kye kimu ne CoV-HKU4 wamu ne CoV-HKU5.

sourceString: Bat CoV-HKU4 and MERS-CoV utilize the same host receptor, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), for virus entry.
targetString: Akawundo CoV-HKU4 ne MERS-CoV bukozesa ekibeerako akawuka kye kimu, dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), okuyingiza akawuka.

sourceString: RNA-dependent RNA polymerase sequences of MERS-CoV are phylogenetically closer to counterparts in bat beta-CoVs identified from Europe and Africa.
targetString: Endagabutonde (RNA) ya MERS-CoV yeefaananyiriza n’eyo erabikira mu buwundo beta-CoVs obwalabibwa e Bulaaya ne mu Afrika.

sourceString: Up to now, no live MERS-CoV can be found in wild bats.
targetString: Ne gye buli eno, tewali kawuka ka MERS-CoV kalamu kasobola kusangibwa mu buwundo.

sourceString: MERS-CoV and its closest relative bat CoV-HKU25 share only 87% nucleotide sequence homology.
targetString: MERS-CoV n’abooluganda lwe akawundo CoV-HKU25 bigabana ebitundu 87% byokka eby’endagabutonde.

sourceString: Thus, bats might not be the immediate reservoir host of MERS-CoV.
targetString: Awo nno, obuwundo buyinza okuba nga si bwe bwekwatako akawuka ka-MERS-CoV amangu.

sourceString: On the other hand, studies in Middle East have shown that dromedary camels are seropositive for MERS-CoV-specific neutralizing antibodies, same as camels of Middle East origin in multiple African countries.
targetString: Ku ludda olulala okunoonyereza okukoleddwa mu mawanga agagwa mu kitundu kya Middle East kulaze nti eŋŋamiya ziraga nti zirina MERS-CoV-mu basirikale abalwanyisa endwadde mu mubiri, era nga bwe kiri mu ŋŋamiya eziri mu mawanga ga Afrika ezaava mu mawanga ga Middle East.

sourceString: Live MERS-CoV identical to the virus found in humans was isolated from the nasal swabs of dromedary camels, further indicating that camels serve as the bona fide reservoir host of MERS-CoV.
targetString: Obuwuka obulamu bu-MERS-CoV obufaanagana n’akawuka akasangibwa mu bantu obwayawulwa nga buva mu lunyira lw’eŋŋamiya, ne kyongera okulaga nti eŋŋamiya ze zikola ng’ekyekwatwako akawuuka ka-MERS-CoV.

sourceString: It is also noteworthy that generally mild symptoms but massive virus shedding were observed in camels experimentally infected with MERS-CoV.
targetString: Kikulu nnyo nti obubonero obutonotono naye nga bweyolekeramu obuwuka buyitirivu bwalabibwa mu ŋŋamiya ezaalina MERS-CoV.

sourceString: Notably, infected camels shed viruses not only through respiratory route but also through fecal-oral route, which is also the main route for virus shedding from bats.
targetString: Genderera, eŋŋamiya endwadde ziba n’obuwuka si miyitiro gy’omukka gyokka, ate ng’era gwe muyitiro omukulu ogw’akawuka mu buwundo.

sourceString: However, questions still remain since many confirmed cases of MERS have no contact history with camels prior to symptom onset, plausibly ascribed to human-to-human transmission or unknown transmission routes involving unrecognized animal species that harbour MERS-CoV.
targetString: Wabula, ebibuuzo bikyaliwo kubanga abalwadde ba MERS abakakasiddwa tebalina be bakwatagana nabo mabega na ŋŋamiya ng’obubonero obuliwo tebunnalabika, obwandiba nga bukwanyizibwa na muntu-ku-muntu oba emiyitiro gy’okusaasaanya egitamanyiddwa omuli ebika by’ebisolo ebitamanyiddwa ebirimu MERS-CoV.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 shares 96.2% nucleotide homology with a bat CoV RaTG13 isolated from Rhinolophus affinis bats.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 egabana ebitundu by’endagabutonde 96.2% n’akawundo CoV RaTG13 akaayawulwa okuva mu buwundo buyitibwa Rhinolophus affinis bats.

sourceString: As in the cases of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, the sequence divergence between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is too great to assign parental relationship.
targetString: Era nga bwe kiri ku SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV, enjawulo wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne RaTG13 ya maanyi nnyo mu ngeri nti kizibu okulengera oluganda oluli wakati w’obuwuka obwo.

sourceString: That is to say, bats might not be the immediate reservoir host(s) of SARS-CoV-2 unless almost identical bat CoVs are found in future.
targetString: Kwe kugamba, obuwundo buyinza okuba nga si bwe bwekwatibwako amangu okubeerako akawuka ne busaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 okuggyako nga eyo gye bujja waliwo obuwundo bu-CoVs obubufaanana obuzuuliddwa.

sourceString: Presumably, the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2 should be among the wildlife species sold and killed at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, with which many of the initial cases of COVID-19 were associated, indicative of a probable animal-to-human transmission event.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’okuteebereza, ekisolo ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 kirina okuba nga kimu ku bika ebyo ebibeera mu nsiko nga bitundibwa era ne bittibwa mu katale ka Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, nga mu kusooka obulwadde bwa COVID-19 obwasooka kwe bwakwanyizibwa nga kirabika, waliwo okusaasaanyizibwa kw’obulwadde okuva ku nsolo-okudda-ku-muntu.

sourceString: Several recent studies based on metagenomic sequencing have suggested that a group of endangered small mammals known as pangolins (Manis javanica) could also harbour ancestral beta-CoVs related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okuwerako okukoleddwa emabegako awo nga kwesigamiziddwa ku ntereeza y’endagabutonde kulaze nti ekibinja ky’ensolo eziri mu katyabaga eziyitibwa pangolins (Manis javanica) zandiba nga nazo zirimu obuzadde obwekwanya ku beta-CoVs obufaananako ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: These novel pangolin CoV genomes share 85-92% nucleotide sequence homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Obusolo buno bu-Pangolin obutalabwangako obulimu endagabutonde ya CoV bugabana ebitundu 85-92% ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, they are equally closely related to RaTG13 with about 90% identity at the level of nucleotide sequence.
targetString: Wabula, bufaanaganira ddala ne RaTG13 n’ebitundu nga 90% ku ddaala ly’entereeza y’endagabutonde.

sourceString: They cluster into two sub-lineages of SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the phylogenetic tree, one of which share a more similar receptor binding domain (RBD) with SARS-CoV-2, with 97.4% amino acid sequence identity.
targetString: Zeegabanyizzaamu ennyiriri 2 entonotono ez’obuwuka obulinga SARS-CoV-2 mu neeyoleka y’endabutonde ng’emu ku yo egabana obukole ne (RBD) SARS-CoV-2, ng’ebitundu 97.4% eby’ekirungo ky’endagabutonde bifaanagana.

sourceString: In stark contrast, the RBDs of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 are more divergent, albeit a higher degree of sequence homology genome-wide.
targetString: Mu ngeraageranya ey’enjawulo, obukole bwa RBDs obwa SARS-CoV-2 ne RaTG13 bweyawudde nnyo naye nga bweyawulidde mu busiŋŋanyi bwa ntereeza ya ndagabutonde.

sourceString: An earlier study on diseased pangolins also reported the detection of viral contigs from lung samples, which turn out to be similarly related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okwasooka ku pangolin ezaali endwadde nakwo kwalaga okukengebwa kw’obuwuka obwali mu sampolo z’amawuggwe obulina oluganda ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: This study adopted different assembly methods and manual curation to generate a partial genome sequence comprising about 86.3% of the full-length viral genome.
targetString: Okunoonyereza kuno kwakozesa obukodyo obw’enjawulo omuli n’obwokukyusiriza okufuna entereeza y’endagabutonde erimu ebitundu 86.3% eby’enfaanana y’akawuka.

sourceString: We cannot exclude the possibility that pangolin is one of the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Tetusobola kuggyawo busobosi bwa kuba nti pangolin ke kamu ku busolo obubeerako akawuka obutasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, currently there is no evidence in support of a direct pangolin origin of SARS-CoV-2 due to the sequence divergence between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, tewali bubaka bukakasa buvo bwa SARS-CoV-2 owa pangolin olw’entereeza eyawukana wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne SARS-CoV-2 beta-CoVs owa pangolin .

sourceString: In addition, the distance between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is even shorter than that between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, ebbanga wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne RaTG13 limpiko okusinga ku eryo eriri wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs owa pangolin .

sourceString: The evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in bats, pangolins and other mammals remains to be established.
targetString: Enfuukafuuka y’omuyitiro gwa SARS-CoV-2 mu buwundo, pangolin n’ensolo endala eziringa abantu tennaba kutegeerekeka.

sourceString: Whereas the highest sequence homology has been found in the RBDs between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin, SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 share the highest genome-wide sequence homology.
targetString: Weewaawo entereeza mu ndagabutonde ezuuliddwa wakati wa RBDs ne SARS-CoV-2 ne pangolin, obuwuka obwekwanya ku SARS-CoV-2 beta-CoVs, SARS-CoV-2 ne RaTG13 bugabana endagabutone eyaawamu.

sourceString: It is highly speculative that the high degree of similarity between the RBDs of pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs and SARS-CoV-2 is driven by selectivity-mediated convergent evolution.
targetString: Kisuubirwa nti obufaanane obw’amaanyi wakati wa RBDs mu buwuka obwekwanya ku pangolin SARS-CoV-2 beta-CoVs ne SARS-CoV-2 bufugibwa enfuukafuuka eyeeyawudde.

sourceString: A counter-proposal is in favour of a recombination between a pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoV and RaTG13 in the third wild animal species.
targetString: Ekiteeso ekirala ekyawukana ku ekyo kiwagira engattagatta wakati w’obuwuka bwa pangolin SARS-CoV-2 beta-CoV ne RaTG13 mu kika ky’ensolo ez’omu nsiko.

sourceString: As a driving force in evolution, recombination is widespread among beta-CoVs.
targetString: Ng’amaanyi agasindiikiriza mu kufuukafuuka, okugattagatta kuli nnyo mu beta-CoVs.

sourceString: The jury is still out on the immediate zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Okusalawo tekunnatuukiibwako ku nsolo esibukako SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Besides the highly pathogenic HCoVs, the zoonotic origin of HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1 have also been studied.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko obuwuka obuleeta ennyo endwadde obwa HCoVs, ensibuko ya HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-NL63 ne HCoV-HKU1 ey’omu nsolo nayo enoonyerezeddwako.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence indicated that both HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E might have originated from bat CoVs, while the parental viruses of HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 have been found in rodents.
targetString: Obuvo obukwata ku kunoonyereza ku nfuukafuuka y’ebitonde bulaga nti HCoV-NL63 ne HCoV-229E bwandiba nga bwava mu CoVs mu buwundo, ate nga muzadde w’akawuka ka HCoV-OC43 ne HCoV-HKU1 azuuliddwa mu mmese.

sourceString: It has been reported that a bat CoV termed ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) detected in North American tricolored bat displayed close relationship with HCoV-NL63.
targetString: Kitegeezeddwa nti CoV ey’akawundo eyitibwa ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) kaakengebwa mu Amerika ey’obukiikakkono (North American) nga ka langi ssatu era nga kaalaga nti kalina oluganda olw’okumpi ne HCoV-NL63.

sourceString: On the other hand, HCoV-229E was genetically related to another bat CoV, termed Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana, while camelids have also been suspected as its intermediate host.
targetString: Mu ngeri endala, HCoV-229E yakwanyizibwa n’endagabutonde n’akawundo CoV, akayitibwa Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, akaalangibwa e Ghana, ate nga n’eŋŋamiya nazo ziteeberezebwa okubeera ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya.

sourceString: For clarity, the current knowledge on animal origins of known HCoVs is summarized in Figure ​1 and Table 2.
targetString: Olw’okutangaazamukko, amagezi agaliwo ku nsibuko y’ensolo ku HCoVs obumanyiddwa gafunziddwa mu Kifaananyi​ 1 n’Omweso 2.

sourceString: Phylogenetic analysis has provided evidence for interspecies transmission events of HCoVs in the history.
targetString: Obwekenneenyi bw’enfuukafuuka buleese obubaka obulaga nti HCoVS busaasaana mu bika by’ensolo eby’enjuwulo nga bwe kiri mu byafaayo.

sourceString: When HCoV-OC43 crossed species to infect humans from domestic livestock around 1890, a pandemic of respiratory infection was recorded.
targetString: HCoV-OC43 bwe kaabuka okuva mu kika ekimu ne kadda mu bantu okuva mu bisolo ebirundibwa ewaka eyo mu 1890, ekirwadde ekikwata omuyungo gw’okussa kyazuulibwa.

sourceString: The interspecies transmission history of HCoV-229E is less clear.
targetString: Ebyafaayo by’okusaasaana kw’ebika eby’enjawulo ebya HCoV-229E tebitangaala bulungi.

sourceString: Bat alpha-CoVs closely related to HCoV-229E have been found.
targetString: Obuwuka obuyitibwa bat alpha-CoVs obulina oluganda olw’amaanyi ne HCoV-229E buzuuliddwa.

sourceString: Between them there is an alpaca alpha-CoV.
targetString: Wakati waabyo waliwo ekiyitibwa alpaca alpha-CoV.

sourceString: Several lines of evidence support the transmission of virus from bats to humans directly.
targetString: Obubaka obw’enjawulo buwerako obuwagira okusaasaana kw’akawuka okuva mu buwundo okudda mu bantu obutereevu.

sourceString: First, humans but not alpacas might have contact with bats in a shared ecological niche.
targetString: Okusooka, abantu naye nga si nsolo eyitibwa alpacas birina enkwatagana n’obuwundo mu kugabana ebifo mwe bibeera.

sourceString: Instead, humans have close contact with alpacas.
targetString: Wabula, abantu balina enkwatagana ey’okumpi ne alpacas.

sourceString: Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats, whereas alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.
targetString: Ekyokubiri, akawuka ka HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs kalimu enjawulo ate tekalwaza buwundo so ng’ate alpaca alpha-CoV kaaleeta ekirwadde mu muyungiro gw’okussa mu nsolo endwadde.

sourceString: Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in feral animals.
targetString: Ekisembayo, alpaca alpha-CoV tekazuuliddwa mu nsolo ezaava ewaka ne zidda mu nsiko.

sourceString: Thus, the possibility cannot be excluded that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans.
targetString: Awo nno, obusobozi tebuyinza kuggyibwawo nti alpacas zijja HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV okuva mu bantu.

sourceString: In fact, bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.
targetString: Mu butuufu, obuwundo y’ensibuko y’obuwuka obusaasaanya endwadde mu bantu omwo nga mwe muli n’akawuka rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus ne Hendra virus.

sourceString: It is therefore not too surprising that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.
targetString: Awo nno tekyewuunyisa nnyo nti obuwundo busobola okusaasaanya HCoV-229E obutereevu mu bantu.

sourceString: Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans, exactly as in the case of MERS-CoV.
targetString: Mu ngeri endala, weewaawo bat alpha-CoVs bukola nga ensibuko y’endagabutonde eya HCoV-229E, alpacas n’eŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) ziyinza okukola ng’ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya ekitambuza obuwuka mu bantu nga bwe kiri ddala ku MERS-CoV.

sourceString: MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.
targetString: MERS-CoV kakola ng’ekyokulabirako ekirungi ddala eky’ensaasaanya okuva mu kika ekimu okudda mu kirala okuva mu buwundo okudda ku ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) ate n’okuva mu ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) okudda mu bantu.

sourceString: The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by subsequent findings.
targetString: Ensibuko y’okufuukafuuka kwa MERS-CoV okuva ku buwundo emanyibwa okuva ku ntandikwa eyasooka era okumanyibwa okwo ne kunywezebwa mu bizze nga bizuulibwa.

sourceString: It is obvious that bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic fragments and interspecies transmission.
targetString: Kyoleka lwatu nti obuwundo bulina ebika by’obuwuka bingi ddala ebitambula mu bika eby’enjawulo ebyeyawulayawula mu bika eby’enjawulo ate ne busaasaana mu bika eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: Longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions for bats to be an ideal 'virus spreader'.
targetString: Obuwangaazi, ebibinja by’obuwundo obungi, okukwatagana ennyo wamu n’obusobozi bw’okubuuka ennyo byonna bisobozesa obuwundo okubeera ‘ekisaasaanya akawuka’.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.
targetString: Ku ludda olulala, MERS-CoV kateekeddwa mu ŋŋamiya (dromedary camels) okumala ebbanga eriwera.

sourceString: It is well adapted to these camels that have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host.
targetString: Kabeera bulungi mu ŋŋamiya ezo ezaafuuka okuva ku kibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya okudda ku kitonde ekyekwatako akawuka.

sourceString: MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and maintains a relatively low mutation rate in these animals.
targetString: MERS-CoV kaleeta obulwadde obutonotono era kazaalukuka kitono nga kali mu nsolo ezo.

sourceString: Its sporadic transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV as its transmission cannot be sustained.
targetString: Okusaasaanya kwakwo okw’ebbalirirwe mu bantu kwa ngeri ya kabenje era abantu basigala nga beekwatako akawuka MERS-CoV ako naye ne katasaasaana kubanga okusaasaana kwako tekubeezekawo.

sourceString: In contrast to the role of camels in the transmission of MERS-CoV, the role of pangolins, if there is any, in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is different.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya omulimu gw’eŋŋamiya mu kusaasaanya MERS-CoV, omulimu gwa pangolins, bwe guba nga weeguli, mu kusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 gwa njawulo.

sourceString: Particularly, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.
targetString: Okusinga ennyo, obuwuka bu-pangolin beta-CoVs buleeta nnyo endwadde mu pangolins.

sourceString: They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.
targetString: Buyinza okuba ekibeerako akawuka ekitasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, nga bwe kiri ku ffumbe ku SARS-CoV.

sourceString: Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to be ruled in or ruled out in future studies.
targetString: Obusobozi bwa maanyi obw’okusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 mu bika eby’enjawulo okuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu obulina okukakasibwa oba okusazibwamu mu kunoonyereza okujja eyo mu maaso.

sourceString: First, bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Okusooka, obuwundo buyinza okuba ekyekwatwako ky’obuwuka obwekwanya ku SARS-CoV-2 nga kumpi bufaanagana ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.
targetString: Abantu bayinza okufaananya engeri gye bibeerawo mu ndya ne mu kusima.

sourceString: Second, pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.
targetString: Ekyokubiri, pangolin zisobola okubeera ekibeerako akawuka ekisaasaanya obuwuka obwekwanya ku SARS-CoV-2 kwe bwakateekebwa.

sourceString: Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.
targetString: Abantu bakwatibwa akawuka nga kayitira mu kutta n’okulya ennyama enjigge.

sourceString: It is possible that many mammals including domestic animals are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kisoboka nti ensolo eziringa omuntu omwo nga mwe muli n’ezirundibwa ewaka zisobola okukwatibwa SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is warranted.
targetString: Okunoonyereza ku nsolo z’awaka n’ez’omu nsiko okuzuula abasirikale b’omubiri abazirimu kwetaagisa.

sourceString: Third, as mentioned above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.
targetString: Ekyokusatu, nga bwe kyogeddwako waggulu, okugattagatta endagabutonde n’okumanyiira kwa SARS-CoV-2 kuyinza okuba nga kwagwawo mu kika ekyokusatu ekikwatagana n’obuwundo ne pangolin.

sourceString: The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.
targetString: Okunoonyereza ku nsibuko ya SARS-CoV-2 mu nsolo kukyagenda mu maaso.

sourceString: Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in facilitating CoVs to cross species barriers.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ebika by’ensolo ebyekwatwako obuwuka, ensonga enkulu ssatu ku ludda lw’obuwuka nazo nkulu mu kubeezaawo CoVs okusala ebiziyiza okubuuka okudda mu bika ebirala.

sourceString: First of all, their relatively high mutation rates in RNA replication.
targetString: Ekisookera ddala, okuzaalukana kwabwo okulabika nga kuli waggulu ddala mu kuzaalukana kw’endagabutonde (RNA).

sourceString: In comparison to other single-stranded RNA viruses, the estimated mutation rates of CoVs could be regarded as “moderate” to “high” with an average substitution rate being ~10-4 substitution per year per site 2, depending on the phase of CoV adaptation to novel hosts.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya obuwuka obulala obukozesa endagabutonde (single-stranded RNA viruses), omuwendo gw’obuzaalukanyi bw’obuwuka guteeberezebwa okubeera wakati “w’omusaamusaamu” ne “ogwa waggulu” nga guliko omuwendo omukkati oguli wakati wa ~10-4 buli mwaka buli kifo 2, okusinziira ku mutendera gwa CoV ogw’okumanyiira n’ekyekwatako akawuka ekibadde tekimanyiddwa.

sourceString: CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease, deletion of which results in exceedingly high mutability and attenuation or even inviability.
targetString: Obuwuka bwa CoVs bumanyi okutebuka ekirungo ki exoribonuclease, era nga bwe kisangulwa kivaamu okufuukafuuka okw’amaanyi n’okukendeera oba oluusi n’obutasoboka.

sourceString: Interestingly, the nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Ekyewuunyisa, ekirungo nucleotide analogue Remdesivir kimanyiddwa ng’ekinyigiriza okuzaalukana kwa CoV nga kiyitira mu kuziyiza exoribonuclease n’endagabutonde (RNA) eyeesigamye ku RNA polymerase.

sourceString: Remdesivir is one of most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.
targetString: Remdesivir kye kimu ku birungo ebirwanyisa SARS-CoV-2 ebigezesebwa mu kugezesa kw’ekisawo.

sourceString: Nevertheless, mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.
targetString: Ebyo ng’obiggyeeko, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya CoVs kiri awo nga mu mirundi kakadde nga kiri waggulu w’ekyo eky’ekyekwatibwako akawuka.

sourceString: In addition, mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka kitera okuba waggulu bu CoV bwe buba nga tebumanyidde kintu kwe bwekutte.

sourceString: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.
targetString: Bw’ogeraageranya ne SARS-CoV akalina ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya waggulu, ekigero ky’okufuukafuuka ekya SARS-CoV-2 kirabika nga kiri wansi, era ng’ekyo kiraga nti kati kagenze kamanyiirira ddala abantu.

sourceString: Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
targetString: Kyandiba nga kaamala dda okumanyiira ekintu ekirala ekifaananako n’abantu.

sourceString: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko SARS-CoV-2, kino kikola ne ku MERS-CoV, akaamanyiira edda eŋŋamiya.

sourceString: Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
targetString: Mu kulowooza, kirabika nga enkyukakyuka mu ndagabutonde eyinza okuleetera eddagala erigema n’erirwanyisa obuwuka bwa SARS-CoV-2 obutakola mu bwangu.

sourceString: Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.
targetString: Ekyokubiri, ekirungo kya RNA genome ekinene mu CoVs kinyigiriza enfuula ya genome olw’enfuukafuuka n’engattagatta, olwo ne kyongera omukisa gw’ebika ebyenjawulo okubeerana mu nkula yaabyo, ekintu ekirungi mu kusibuka kw’akawuka ka CoV akatamanyiddwa embeera bw’eba ng’eganya.

sourceString: This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
targetString: Kino kiwagirwa enkola ya copious unique open reading frames n’omugaso gwa puloteyini ebeera mu 3′ end eya genome.

sourceString: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
targetString: Ekyokusatu, CoVs butera ate mu ngeri ya kulabira awo okukyusa obutiba mu kiseera ky’okuzaalukana nga buyita mu nkola eya “koppa-kyolonzeeko”.

sourceString: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
targetString: Mu kibeerako akawuka ekikola ng’ekikompe ekitabula, enkyukakyuka ebaawo nnyo mu kiseera kya CoV RNA transcription.

sourceString: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
targetString: Endagabutonde (RNAs) ezifaanagana ennyo wamu ne subgenomic RNAs zisobola okwegattagatta okufunamu bu CoV obulala.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
targetString: Obubaka bw’enfuukafuuka y’obuwuka ey’okwegattagatta okw’obutonde erabiddwa mu HCoV-HKU1 ne mu HCoV-OC43, wamu ne CoV ow’ensolo gamba nga bat SL-CoV ne batCoV-HKU9.

sourceString: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
targetString: Enkolagana y’akawuka n’ekibeerako akawuka mu nsaasaana y’obulwadde

sourceString: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ensonga z’akawuka essatu ezoogeddwako waggulu, enkolagana y’akawuka n’ekibeerako akawuka nayo nsonga nkulu ekola mu nsaasaanya y’obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
targetString: Mu kiwandiiko kino, okwegattagatta kwa SARS-CoV kutwalibwa ng’ekyokulabirako ekimanyiddwa ekyalaba n’obubaka mu kiseera ky’okusaasaanya obulwadde ekiyitibwa positive selection.

sourceString: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
targetString: Okusinziira ku kwekenneenya wakati w’ebyawuliddwa okwekalirizibwa eby’abantu n’eby’effumbe SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV kalowoozebwa okufuna amangu okumanyiira ebibeerako obuwuka, naddala mu kufuukafuuka ku RDB mu S protein.

sourceString: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
targetString: Okutwaliza awamu, RBD mu S protein eya CoV ekolagana n’ekifuna obutaffaali era nga kirondebwa nnyo abasirikale b’omubiri mu kibeerako obuwuka.

sourceString: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
targetString: Mu SARS-CoV, RBD eri mu amino acid owa 318 okutuuka ku 510 ku S1 fragment, eyeekwata ku ACE2 mu bantu wamu n’ebyo ebifuna obuwuka okuyingirirako.

sourceString: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
targetString: RBD eya SARS-CoV esobola okukenga ebifuna obuwuka ACE2 mu nsolo ez’enjawulo, omuli akawundo, effumbe, emmese n’embwa (raccoon dog), ekkiriza okusaasaana kw’akawuka mu bika eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
targetString: Mu butuufu, ebisigalira bya amino acid 6 byalabibwa nga bya njawulo okuva ku ebyo ebyawulibwa mu bantu n’effumbe mu RBD ate nga 4 ku byo bisangibwa mu nfaanana y’ebifuna obuwuka olw’okukolagana n’ekifuna obuwuka ACE2.

sourceString: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
targetString: SARS-CoV ow’effumbe alimu okufuukafuuka kwa K479N ne S487T RBD we, ekiyinza okwongeza enkwatagana y’enkolagana ya spike protein ne ACE2 ey’ekifuna akwuka mu bantu.

sourceString: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
targetString: Kwe kugamba, ebika bya amino acid ebibiri ebisikira ebirala biyinza okuba nga bya maanyi nnyo mu kumanyiira kw’akawuka mu bantu.

sourceString: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
targetString: Kikulu okumanya nti SARS-CoV-2 kagabana ekifuna obulwadde eky’obutaffaali obufaanagana ne SARS-CoV.

sourceString: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
targetString: Enjawulo ey’ebitundu 30% wakati wa SARS-CoV-2 ne SARS-CoV mu kigero ekya S1 ekya S protein kitegeeza nti y’enyweza oluganda eya S protein ne ACE2 mu bantu eyinza okuba nga yakyuka.

sourceString: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
targetString: Mu butuufu, okunoonyereza kwa cryo-EM kulaga 10- ku-20 kulimu oluganda lwa maanyi mu kunyweza kuno okusinga ACE2 mu bantu ne SARS-CoV S protein.

sourceString: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
targetString: Kijja kuba kirungi era okulaba oba nga ekintu ekirala ekifuna obuwuka kiyinza okwetaagisa mu kusaasaanya SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
targetString: Mu ngeri eyeewuunyisa, HCoV-NL63 nakyo kinyweza ACE2 naye nga kikozesa akatundu ka S akalala.

sourceString: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
targetString: Waliwo n’ebifuna HCoV ebirala bingi, gamba nga aminopeptidase N ku HCoV-229E, ne 9-O-acetylated sialic acid ku HCoV-OC43.

sourceString: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
targetString: Busobola era okunnyonnyola okumanyiira obulungi okw’obuwuka bwa CoV mu bantu oluvannyuma lw’okusaasaanira mu bika ebyenjawulo nga buva ku nsolo kwe bubeera.

sourceString: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ebifuna obuwuka eby’obutaffaali, ekiva mu HCoV okusaanasaanira mu bika eby’enjawulo kifugibwa ensonga endala ezeesigama ku kibeerako obuwuka n’ebikugira.

sourceString: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
targetString: Enjawulo mu host proteins wakati w’abantu n’ebitonde ebisaasaanya HCoVs gamba ng’obuwundo, eŋŋamiya n’emmese ( rodents) biyinza okukola ng’omuziziko mu kusaasaanya obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
targetString: HCoVs bunaayiza ekibeerako obuwuka era ne kyewala ebikugira by’ekibeerako obuwuka olw’okusaasaanya obulungi obulwadde mu bika eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
targetString: Mu ngeri eyo, ebisalawo ku molecule mu kitundu kino ekikulu eky’akawuka-ekibeerako obuwuka kikyetaaga okulengerwa n’okunnyonnyola.

sourceString: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
targetString: Okusunsula mu genome okw’awamu okutaliimu kyekubiira (genome-wide screening) okw’ekibeerako obuwuka n’ebikugira bya SARS-CoV-2 omuli okukozesa tekinologiya ow’ekika ekya waggulu kiyinza okuvaamu ebibala.

sourceString: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
targetString: Okubalukawo kwa HCoVs abadde tamanyiddwa: okuddayo ku ntandikwa

sourceString: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
targetString: Enjawulo mu CoVs ow’obuwundo aleetawo emikisa gya maanyi mu kubalukawo kwa HCoVs obubadde tebumanyiddwa.

sourceString: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
targetString: Mu ngeri eno, CoV ow’obuwundo bukolanga ng’ensibuko ya giini eza HCoVs.

sourceString: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, okufuukafuuka okw’amangu n’okwegattagatta kwa giini nabyo bifuga enkula ya HCoV era bikola ng’emitendera ebiri emikulu mu nkwajja eno.

sourceString: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
targetString: Okugeza, okufuna oba okufiirwa entereeza ya giini za protein (protein-coding genes) okubadde kutamanyiddwa kulimu obusobozi bw’okukyusiza ddala enfaanana y’obuwuka.

sourceString: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
targetString: Mu SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 zirowoozebwa okubeera enkulu mu kumanyiira abantu, ng’obuwuka bwa SARS-CoV obwekwanya ku buwundo bwayawulibwa naye ate ne busangibwa nga bulina divergent ORF8 proteins.

sourceString: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
targetString: Akabonero ka 29-nucleotide deletion aka SARS-CoVs kasangiddwa mu bwawuzi obwayawulibwa ku ntandikwa ya nawookeera w’ekirwadde kino mu bantu.

sourceString: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
targetString: Okusangula kuno kwawulamu ORF8 mu ORF8a ne ORF8b era nga kirowoozebwa okubeera enfuukafuuka y’okumanyiira etumbula okukyusakyusa ekibeerako obuwuka.

sourceString: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ekyo, SARS-CoV kalina ebyafaayo by’obusobozi bw’okwegattagatta mu nnyiriri za alpha- ne gamma-CoVs, omwalabibwa omuwendo gw’okwegattagatta mu nkula omutono mu RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

sourceString: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
targetString: Ebifo ebimu eby’okwegattagatta byalengerwa mu nsp9, ebisinga mu nsp10, n’ebitundu bya nsp14.

sourceString: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, kiragiddwa nti nawookeera w’ekirwadde kya MERS-CoV yalimu okwegattagatta wakati w’ennyiriri ez’enjawulo, okwaliwo mu ŋŋamiya mu Saudi Arabia.

sourceString: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV, emirundi gy’okwegattagatta era girabiddwa mu HCoVs obulala, HCoVs mwe bwegattira ne CoVs ez’ensolo mu giini zaazo eziyitibwa non-structural genes.

sourceString: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
targetString: Kisaana era okulabula nti okulondoba okukolebwa abantu kusobola okuleetawo enkyukakyuka ezitalabiddwa mu viral genomes, ng’okusinga ennyo kiva ku kuwewula ku buwuka ku kunyigirizibwa kw’okulondoba, gamba ng’okwo okuva ku busibage bw’ekibeerako obuwuka.

sourceString: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
targetString: Ekyokulabirako ky’okukosebwa kuno kwe kufiirwa okw’amaanyi okwa ORF4 mu HCoV-229E prototype strain, nga kiva ku kusangula kwa nucleotide kwa mirundi ebiri.

sourceString: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
targetString: Weewaawo nga ORF4 atafuusefuuse asobola okulabibwa mu buwuka bw’obuwundo ne mu ŋŋamiya obwekwanya ku HCoV-229E, alpaca alpha-CoV kooleka okusonsekebwa kwa nucleotide, okuva ku frameshift.

sourceString: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
targetString: Ekisembayo naye nga si kye kisemberayo ddala, okukula kwa HCoVs akabadde tekamanyiddwa era kufugibwa okusindiikirizibwa kw’okulonda mu kibeerako obuwuka.

sourceString: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
targetString: Obutalaga bubonero oba obubonero obutono bwalabibwa ng’obuwundo bulwadde CoVs, nga kiraga okumanyiira okw’awamu wakati wa CoVs n’obuwundo.

sourceString: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
targetString: Kyalabika nti obuwundo bwamanyidde bulungi CoVs mu nkula yaabwo (anatomically) ate ne mu mbeera z’obulamu obwa bulijjo.

sourceString: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
targetString: Okugeza, obunafu mu kuzimba okujjawo mu buwundo bukendeeza embeera etali ya bulijjo ereetebwa CoVs.

sourceString: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, okufa kw’obutaffaali okw’obutonde mu buwundo kuzibikirwa nga kiva ku kukendeeza kwa butaffaali bw’obutonde obw’ekifuna obuwuka NKG2/CD94 wamu n’okweyoleka okwa wansi okw’amaanyi okw’obukolaganyi bwa molecules ez’ekibinja I.

sourceString: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
targetString: So ng’ate, ebika bya oxygen species (ROS) ava mu kukola emmere mu mubiri mu buwundo kuyinza okunyigiriza okuzaalukana kwa CoV n’okukosa proofreading by exoribonuclease, ne kivaamu okunyigiriza kw’okulonda okuleeta ebika by’akawuka ebireeta ennyo endwadde nga biteereddwa mu kitundu ekirala ekibeerako obuwuka.

sourceString: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
targetString: Obuwuka bwa CoV obulala nabwo buyinza okukula nga bwegattagatta, ne kireetawo protein ezibadde tezimanyiddwa oba obubonero bwa protein obusobozesa ekibeerako obuwuka okumanyiira.

sourceString: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
targetString: Awo nno, si kya mukisa bukisa nti HCoVs obubadde tebumayiddwa bubaluseewo mu myaka abiri egiyise.

sourceString: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
targetString: CoVs tebuleeta ndwadde oba buleeta obubonero butono mu ekyo ekisaasaanya gamba ng’obuwundo n’eŋŋamiya.

sourceString: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
targetString: Buzaalukana nnyo ate nga tebuleeta busibage bwa maanyi ku kintu ekibeerako endwadde.

sourceString: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
targetString: Muno mwe muli ekyama ekireetera ebisaasaanya endwadde ebitalina bubonero okulabibwa n’ekireetawo obulwadde obw’akabi ennyo mu bantu.

sourceString: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
targetString: Obubonero obw’akabi businga kuva ku kutanula obusibage n’obubonero obw’akabi ennyo (cytokine storm) ne kiba nti obusibage gye bukoma okuba obw’amaanyi, n’okukosebwa kw’amawuggwe gye kukoma okuba okw’omutawaana.

sourceString: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya n’abantu abatalabikirako bubonero, obusibage bulemesebwa okwekubisaamu mu kuzaalukana kwa CoV.

sourceString: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
targetString: Akakodyo ke kamu ak’okuggyawo obukwatane bw’obusibage kuyinza okuba n’emiganyulo mu kujjanjaba SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
targetString: Enkola ya interferon ya maanyi nnyo mu buwundo.

sourceString: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
targetString: Awo nno, okukola ku type I interferon waakiri ng’okukosebwa kwa SARS-CoV-2 kwakalabika mu bantu kuteekwa oba nga kuvaamu ebirungi.

sourceString: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, okuleetera okukola kwa NLRP3 inflammasome mu buwundo tekivaamu kantu.

sourceString: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
targetString: Mu ntegeera eno, okukugira kwa NLRP3 inflammasome nga kuli wamu ne MCC950 kuyinza okuyamba mu bujjanjabi bwa COVID-19.

sourceString: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
targetString: Okubalukawo kwa SARS-CoV-2 kugoberera omulamwa ogw’awamu omwasibukira SARS-CoV ne MERS-CoV.

sourceString: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Weewaawo kizuuliddwa nti beta-CoV kagabana ebitundu 95% ebya nucleotide ne SARS-CoV, waliwo era ka CoV k’akawundo akagabana ebitundu 96% ebya nucleotide ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
targetString: Weewaawo effumbe n’ensolo endala ezitundibwa mu butale zizuuliddwa okukweka obuwuka obufaananako ne SARS-CoV, ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya SARS-CoV-2 tekinnazuulibwa.

sourceString: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Pangolin beta-CoVs obwewuunyisa okufaanagana ne SARS-CoV-2 buzuuliddwa, ekiraga nti pangolin ziyinza okukola ng’ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya oba pangolin beta-CoVs kayinza okuba nga kalina obutundutundu bwa giini bwe kaleeta ku nkula ya SARS-CoV-2 esembayo.

sourceString: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
targetString: Weewaawo nga wakyaliwo ebibuuzo, tewali bubaka bulaga nti SARS-CoV-2 yakolebwa muntu mu bugenderevu oba mu ngeri etali ŋŋenderere.

sourceString: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: CoVs bukomyewo okumanyika mu bantu olw’okubalukawo kwa SARS-CoV-2 okuzzeewo emabegako.

sourceString: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
targetString: Okunoonyereza ku CoVs mu buwundo n’ensolo endala kukyusizza mu ngeri ey’amangu entegeera y’omugaso gw’endwadde eziva mu nsolo n’ensolo ezibeerako obuwuka bwa HCoVs mu kusaasaanya endwadde mu bantu.

sourceString: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
targetString: Obubaka obw’amaanyi bulaze nti SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV ne SARS-CoV-2 buva mu buwundo era nga busaasaanyizibwa mu bantu nga buyitira ku bintu ebibeerako obuwuka ebitasaasaanya.

sourceString: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
targetString: Olw’okuba nti obulwadde bwa SARS-CoV buva mu nkwatagana wakati w’abantu n’amafumbe mu butale, okuggala obutale obutundibwamu ebintu ebibisi n’okutta amafumbe kyandiyambye nnyo mu kukomya nawookeera wa SARS.

sourceString: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, pangolins zirina okuggyibwa mu butale obutundibwamu ebintu ebibisi olw’okuziyiza okusaasaanya endwadde eziva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu, nga tutunuulira okuzuula ennyiriri ez’enjawulo eza pangolin beta-CoVs ezeekwanya ennyo ku SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
targetString: Wabula, oba nga SARS-CoV-2 asaasaanyibwa mu bantu ng’ayitira mu pangolins n’ensolo endala eziringa abantu n’engeri gy’asaasaanyizibwamu kijja kuzuulibwa eyo mu kunoonyereza okujja eyo mu maaso.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
targetString: Ku ludda olulala, MERS-CoV kabadde mu ŋŋamiya okumala ebbanga eriwera.

sourceString: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
targetString: Eŋŋamiya za mugaso nnyo mu ntambula ate ng’era zivaako nnyo ennyama, amata, amaliba n’ebyoya eri abantu.

sourceString: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
targetString: Ziri nnyo mu bitundu bya Middle East ne Afrika.

sourceString: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Awo nno kizibu nnyo okutta eŋŋamiya zonna olw’okuziyiza MERS, ng’ekyakolebwa mu butale bw’ensolo ez’omu nsiko mu China okuziyiza okusaasaana kwa SARS-CoV ne SARS-CoV-2.

sourceString: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
targetString: Okusobola okuziyiza okubalukawo kwa MERS okutatadde, enkwata y’obulwadde buno erina okukulaakulanyizibwa okukola eddagala erigema MERS-CoV ery’eŋŋamiya, nga likolera wamu n’engeri endala eziziyiza obulwadde.

sourceString: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
targetString: Olw’okuba nti tetusobola kumalawo buwuka buno, ekika ky’obuwuka obulala kisobola okubalukawo okuleeta nawookeera omulala.

sourceString: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
targetString: Obuwuka obw’enjawulo obwa CoV obusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu bubunye mu nsiko.

sourceString: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
targetString: N’okusingira ddala, bu CoV obw’obuwundo obulina obusobozi bw’okusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsoolo okudda mu bantu bwa ngeri nnyingi.

sourceString: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
targetString: Waliwo emikisa mingi nti bu CoV obusaasaanya endwadde okuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu bwegattagatta nga kiva mu kubalukawo bu CoV obupya obutambuzibwa amangu ne/oba mu bantu eyo gye bujja.

sourceString: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
targetString: Empisa y’okulya ensolo ez’omu nsiko mu bifo ebimu mu China erina okusuulibwa okukendeeza ku nkwatagana eteetaagisa wakati w’abantu n’ensolo.

sourceString: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
targetString: Nga tuli mu katyabaga ka SARS, MERS ne COVID-19, okweteekateeka okusingako obulungi n’enteekateeka ey’okubyaŋŋanga zirina okubeerawo.

sourceString: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
targetString: Mu butuufu, obuwuka bungi bubaddewo mu nsi okumala ebbanga ddene ddala.

sourceString: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
targetString: Bubeera mu bifo byabwo eby’obutonde okutuusa lwe walabikawo omukisa ne bubuukayo okugenda ewalala.

sourceString: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
targetString: Newankubadde ng’obuwundo bulina obukole bungi obubusobozesa okusaasaanya obuwuka, omukisa gw’abantu okukwatagana n’obuwundo n’ebika ebirala eby’omu nsiko gusobola okukendeezebwa abantu bwe bategeezebwa okwewala okubisemberera.

sourceString: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
targetString: Okwekaliriza entakera kwetaagisa mu nsolo eziringa abantu olw’okutegeera enkula ya CoVs mu ngeri esingako wamu n’ebyo ebibeerako obuwuka ebyobutonde ebijja okulabika nga bya mugaso mu kuziyiza okusaasaanya endwadde okuva ku nsolo-okudda-mu-bantu wamu ne nawookeera ow’omu maaso.

sourceString: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
targetString: Mu kufundikira, engeri esinga obulungi ey’okuziyiza obuwuka obuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu be bantu okuva ku bintu eby’obutonde ebibeerako obuwuka obusaasaanya endwadde okuva ku nsolo okudda mu bantu.

sourceString: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
targetString: Waliwo ebintu bingi ebitannaba kutegeerekeka ku nsibuko y’obulwadde bwa SARS-CoV-2 obuva mu nsolo okudda mu bantu.

sourceString: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
targetString: Okusookera ddala, oba ng’obuwundo busaasaanya akawuka akasibukamu SARS-CoV-2 mu pangolin, kiba kisaana okulaba embeera obuwundo ne pangolin mwe bigabanira okubeerana mu bifo gye bibeera.

sourceString: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
targetString: Ekyokubiri, oba ng’obuwundo buzannya ekifo ky’okusaasaanya obulwadde obutereevu mu bantu, olwo nno engeri abantu gye bakwataganamu n’obuwundo erina okufiibwako.

sourceString: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
targetString: Ekyokusatu, ensolo eringa omuntu bw’eba nga y’ekola nga ekibeerako obuwuka ekitasaasaanya ekituufu, engeri gye kitabaganamu n’ebika ebirala omuli n’abantu, obuwundo ne pangolin erina okutangaazibwa.

sourceString: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
targetString: Ekisembayo, olw’okubanga ensolo nnyingi eziringa abantu omwo nga mwe muli n’ez’awaka ziyinza okuba nga zikwatibwa mangu SARS-CoV-2, okwekaliriza n’okugezesa kw’obulwadde byombi birina okukolebwa.

sourceString: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
targetString: Singa kanaaba kawundo, pangolin oba ensolo endala eringa omuntu, kisuubirwa nti SARS-CoV-2 oba obuwuka obulala obusibukako obulwadde nga kumpi bufaanagana bujja kuzuulibwa mu kibeerako obuwuka obwo eky’obutonde eyo gye bujja.

sourceString: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
targetString: Okunoonyereza entakera ku nsonga eno kujja kutangaaza omugendo gw’enkula ya SARS-CoV-2 mu nsolo, omuli n’ebivaamu eby’omugaso mu kutangira n’okuziyiza COVID-19 mu bantu.

sourceString: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
targetString: Okutuukanya ebisinziirwako okukakasa omulwadde “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa” okubeera ne COVID-19 kyetaagisa

sourceString: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Nga 6 Ogwokubiri 2020, tiimu yaffe yali efulumizza ebigobererwa eby’amangu mu kukebera n’okujjanjaba abantu abalina 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), era ng’ebigobererwa bino byali biraga obumanyirivu bwaffe n’okulaga engeri y’okulwanyisaamu obulungi nawookeera ono mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Wabula, obulwadde bwa coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) bulwadde bupya, bye tubumanyiiko bigenda byeyongera okusinziira ku bizuulibwa mu kunoonyereza okugenda mu maaso n’ebiyitibwamu mu kujjanjaba; noolwekyo, enkebera n’enzijanjaba nabyo bigenda bikyusibwamu.

sourceString: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.
targetString: Mu bbaluwa eno, twayanukula ekibuuzo kimu ku bigobererwa byaffe era ne tuwa ebigobererwa ebisinga obupya mu kusalawo “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa” okusinziira ku bigobererwa ebikyasembyeyo mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba CoVID-19 (Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version)) ebyayisibwa National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

sourceString: In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Mu Deesemba 2019, 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) yaleetawo obulwadde, kati mu butongole obwatuumibwa coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) era n’akawuka ne katuumibwa severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
targetString: Nga 11 Ogwokusatu 2020, WHO yalangirira nti COVID-19 kizibu kya byabulamu mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
targetString: Okusobola okulwanyisa SARS-CoV-2, tiimu yaffe ekulaakulanyizza ebigobererwa eby’amangu nga byafulumizibwa ku yintaneeti mu Military Medical Research nga 06 Ogwokubiri 2020.

sourceString: It has attracted a great attention since published.
targetString: Byettaniddwa nnyo okuva lwe byafulumizibwa.

sourceString: Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Wabula kisaanye okwetegerezebwa nti COVID-19 bulwadde bupya, bye tubumanyiiko bigenda byeyongera okusinziira ku bizuulibwa mu kunoonyereza okugenda mu maaso n’ebiyitibwamu mu kujjanjaba; noolwekyo, enkebera n’enzijanjaba nabyo bigenda bikyusibwamu.

sourceString: For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.
targetString: Okugeza Ebigobererwa mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba CoVID-19 ebyayisibwa National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), wakati wa 16 Janwali 2020 ne 3 Ogwokusatu 2020, yaakafulumya enfulumya musanvu mulamba ng’embeera ezimu zikyukidde ddala.

sourceString: Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
targetString: Ebigobererwa byaffe byayogerwako Zhou ne banne, baateesa enkola ennyangu ey’okwekenneenya nga basinziira ku bye bazudde mu kujjanjaba mu ddwaliro.

sourceString: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Omulimu gwabwe gwayongera obukakafu ku bigobererwa byaffe era boogera ne ku kizibu kino ekiri mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
targetString: Omulimu gwabwe omulungi tugukkiriza era tubeebaza.

sourceString: However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
targetString: Wabula, omulimu gwabwe nagwo gwetaaga okuzzibwa obuggya okusinziira ku Bigobererwa mu Kukebera n’Okujjanjaba COVID-19 ebipya (Olufulumya owomusanvu) n’okunoonyereza okupya.

sourceString: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:
targetString: Okusinziira ku lufulumya olwomusanvu (3 Ogwokusatu 2020), okukakasa omulwadde ateeberezebwa kyeetaagisa okugatta ekimu ku bigobererwa ebikwata ku byafaayo by’obulwadde n’ebigobererwa bibiri eby’ekisawo mu ddwaliro okusobola okukola okusalawo okw’enkomeredde, oba kyetaagisa okutuukiriza ebigobererwa bisatu eby’ekisawo mu ddwaliro singa waba tewali bikwata byafaayo bya bulwadde bitegeerekeka:

sourceString: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).
targetString: Ebyafaayo by’obulwadde: (1) okuba ng’omuntu yagendako oba yabeerako mu kibuga Wuhan n’ebitundu ebyetooloddewo, oba ebitundu ebirala ewaazuulwa abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu nnaku 14 ng’obubonero tebunneeyoleka; (2) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abantu abalina SARS-CoV-2 (mu kukebera kwa positive nucleic acid test); (3) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abalwadde b’omusujja oba abalina obuzibu bw’okussa okuva mu kibuga Wuhan n’ebitundu ebiriraanyeewo, oba ebitundu ebirala ewaazuulibwa abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu nnaku 14 ng’obubonero tebunneeyoleka; (4) okuba ng’omuntu yasemberera abalwadde abakakasiddwa (abalwadde ≥ 2 abalina omusujja ne/oba obuzibu mu kussa baazuulwa mu wiiki 2 mu bifo ebifunda, ng’awaka, woofiisi, ebibiina ku ssomero, n’ebirala).

sourceString: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.
targetString: Obubonero bw’ekisawo: (1) omusujja ne/ oba obuzibu mu kussa; (2) n’obubonero bw’okukubwa ekifaananyi obulaga okukosebwa COVID-19; (3) omuwendo gw’obutaffaali obulwanyisa endwadde (white blood cells) obulaga omuwendo gwa lymphocyte omulungi, oba ogukendedde mu kiseera ekisooka.

sourceString: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.
targetString: Okukakasa omulwadde kulina kukolebwa ku mulwadde ateeberezebwa ng’aliko obukakafu bw’obulwadde oba okukeberwa amazzi g’omubiri nga bwe kiragiddwa wammanga: (1) ng’okukebera kwa PCR okw’embagirawo kulaze nti omuntu alina SARS-CoV-2; (2) nga viral whole genome sequencing eraze okufaanana okw’amaanyi n’obuwuka bwa coronaavirus obupya; (3) ng’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri kulaze nti omuntu alina IgM antibody ne IgG antibody zennyini ezirwanyisa SARS-CoV-2; oba okukyuka kwa lgG antibody za SARS-CoV-2 zennyini okuva ku negative okudda ku positive, oba titer rising ez’emirundi ≥4 mu kiseera ky’okuwona okusinga ku ezo ez’omu kiseera ky’okubeera obubi.

sourceString: We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
targetString: Tulaba nti okukebera kwa PCR okw’embagirawo okuzuula nucleic acid mu mussizo oba omusaayi kwagattibwa ku lufulumya olwokubiri (18 Janwali 2020) n’olw’okusatu (22 Janwali 2020).

sourceString: The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
targetString: Okuzuula obulwadde mu sampolo y’omusaayi kwagattibwa ku nfulumya olwokuna (27 Janwali 2020) n’olwokutaano (8 Ogwokubiri 2020); ate obukakafu bw’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri bwagattibwa ku lufulumya olwomusanvu.

sourceString: These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.
targetString: Okukyusaamu kuno kwesigamizibwa ku mirimu gy’abanoonyereza okugezaako okufuna ekintu ekiyinza okukenga obulungi nucleic acid olw’okukebera okw’amangu, awamu ne sampolo okuva mu mussizo omuli sampolo z’omusaayi, nga kino kyayongera ku busobozi bw’okufuna ebikeberwa eby’enjawulo, era ne kiwagira eky’okubeera ne antibody zennyini ng’ekimu ku bisinziirwako okukakasa omulwadde.

sourceString: Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ekyo, waliwo obukakafu obulala bungi obutujjukiza okwegendereza abalwadde abalaga n’abatalaga bubonero mu ngeri etali ya bulijjo.

sourceString: Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
targetString: Noolwekyo, ekipande kya Zhou ne banne kisaanye okuzzibwa obuggya, kubanga kyalaga omuntu atalina bubonero bwa bulwadde nga “alina emikisa emitono (low risk)”.

sourceString: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
targetString: Enkebera eno (score system) era yeetaaga okukakasibwa mu kujjanjaba okulala mu malwaliro ne mu kunoonyereza okulala.

sourceString: To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
targetString: Mu kuwumbawumba, tusuubira nti obukakafu obulala obulabikirawo bujja kulabikawo era tusaba abasomi okubwogerako.

sourceString: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
targetString: Mu kumanya “ateeberezebwa” ne “akakasiddwa”, tuteesa eky’okulondoola n’okugondera ebiragiro ebikyasembyeyo eby’amawanga gaawe.

sourceString: Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
targetString: Tiimu yaffe ejja kuzza obuggya mu budde ebigobererwa byaffe okusobola okuyambako.

sourceString: Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
targetString: Bangladesh etegeezezza nti abantu bataanu abalala bafudde olwa COVID-19, nga gwe muwendo omunene ogusinga ku bafa buli lunaku

sourceString: Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
targetString: Eggulo, Bangladesh yakakasizza nti abantu bataano abalala baafudde olwa COVID-19 ku lunaku olwo.

sourceString: This is the highest number of fatalities in a day due to the virus.
targetString: Guno gwe muwendo ogusingayo obunene mu lunaku abafudde olw’akawuka kano.

sourceString: As of yesterday, Bangladesh's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) reported the number of recorded infected cases included 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases who were staying home.
targetString: We bwatuukidde eggulo, Ekitongole kya Bangladesh Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) kyawandiise abalwadde 114 ate abawonye 33 nga bo bali waka.

sourceString: A total of 17 deaths have been recorded.
targetString: Omugatte gw’abantu 17 abafudde.

sourceString: In an online news briefing, the director of IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, said the fatalities included four males and one female.
targetString: Mu mawulire agaaweereddwa ku yintaneeti, omukungu wa IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, yagambye nti abaafudde baabaddemu abasajja bana n’omukyala omu.

sourceString: According to Dr Meerjady, two cases were aged above 60, two between 51 and 60, and one 41-50 years old.
targetString: Okusinziira ku Dr Meerjady, abaafudde ababiri baabadde n’emyaka egisukka mu 60, ababiri nga bali wakati wa 51 ne 60, ate omu ng’ali wakati wa 41-50 egy’obukulu.

sourceString: She also said two of the victims were from Dhaka.
targetString: Era yagambye nti ababiri ku bantu abo bava Dhaka.

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.
targetString: Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, Ekitongole kya World Health Organization (WHO) kyalangirira COVID-19 ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi (pandemic).

sourceString: A hospital official told Anadolu Agency, a local news outlet, that one of the deceased was Jalal Saifur Rahman, a director of Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, who was cared for at the Kuwait Maitree Hospital.
targetString: Omukungu mu ddwaliro yategeeza Anadolu Agency, nga kitongole ky’amawulire, nti omu ku baafa ye yali Jalal Saifur Rahman, omukungu wa Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, eyali ajjanjabibwa mu Kuwait Maitree Hospital.

sourceString: On Saturday, in an online video announcement, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader said public transport would be shut down for longer than initially planned, until this coming Saturday.
targetString: Ku Lwomukaaga, Minista w’Ebyentambula mu Bangladeshi Obaidul Quader bwe yabadde ng’ayisa ekirango ekyalabikidde mu viidiyo yagambye nti entambula yonna ey’olukale egenda kuyimirizibwa okumala ebbanga ggwanvuko okusinga bwe baasooka okutegeka, okutuusa ku Lwomukaaga oluddako.

sourceString: This public transport shutdown had initially started on March 26 and was planned to end on Saturday, April 4.
targetString: Okuyimiriza entambula y’olukale kwali kutandise nga 26 Ogwokusatu era nga kwali kutegekeddwa kukoma nga 4 Ogwokuna.

sourceString: Transport of essential goods -- medical, fuel and food -- was still allowed.
targetString: Entambula y’ebyamaguzi ebikulu -- eddagala, amafuta n’emmere - yo yali ekyakkirizibwa.

sourceString: The first recorded incidents of COVID-19 infection in Bangladesh were on March 8, in two people who returned from Italy and also the wife of one of them.
targetString: Abalwadde ba COVID-19 abaasooka mu Bangladesh baalabika nga 8 Ogwokusatu, nga baali bantu babiri abadda mu ggwanga eryo nga bava Italy ate n’omukyala w’omu ku bantu abo.

sourceString: As of March 19, these three had already recovered.
targetString: Nga 19 Ogwokusatu 19, abasatu abo baali bamaze okuwona.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 yasussa abantu abalwadde akakadde kamu mu nsi yonna

sourceString: On Thursday, the total number of cases of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infections surpassed one million worldwide, Johns Hopkins University data indicated.
targetString: Ku Lwokuna, omugatte gw’abalwadde ba SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus baasusse akakadde akamu mu nsi yonna nga bwe kyalagiddwa mu bubaka bwa Johns Hopkins University.

sourceString: At least 52 thousand deaths were linked to COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
targetString: Waakiri abantu emitwalo 52 baagambibwa okuba nga bafudde COVID-19, obulwadde obuleetebwa coronavirus.

sourceString: The milestone came the same day Malawi confirmed its first coronavirus infections and Zambia had its first coronavirus-related death.
targetString: Kino kyatuukibwako ku lunaku lwe lumu Malawi lwe yakakasa omulwadde waayo asooka ate mu kiseera kye kimu Zambia n’efunayo omuntu omu afa olwa coronavirus.

sourceString: North Korea claimed, as of Thursday, it was one of the few countries remaining free of coronavirus infections.
targetString: North Korea yo yagambye nti ku Lwokuna y’emu ku nsi ezaali zikyasigadde nga tezinnalumbibwa bulwadde bwa coronavirus.

sourceString: By yesterday, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases, including 79,332 cases in the twenty four hours preceding 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4.
targetString: Ku lunaku lw’eggulo Ekibiina ky’Ebyobulamu mu nsi yonna (World Health Organization) kyategeezezza nti waabaddewo abalwadde 1,051,635 omuli abalwadde 79,332 abaafunise mu bbanga lya ssaawa 24 obutasukka ssaawa nnya ez’oku makya, mu mbala y’essaawa eya Central European Time (0800 UTC) nga 4 Ogwokuna.

sourceString: In the United States, over 244 thousand coronavirus cases were recorded, linking to at least 5,900 deaths.
targetString: Mu United States, abalwadde abasukka mu 244,000 be baategeezebwa ate ng’abafudde bali waakiri 5,900.

sourceString: CBS News reported, citing Johns Hopkins University data, there were over 1,000 US deaths on Wednesday caused by coronavirus infections.
targetString: CBS News kyajulizza Johns Hopkins University ne kigamba nti, mu US mwalimu abantu abasukka 1,000 abaafudde ku Lwokusatu nga bafudde lwa bulwadde bwa coronavirus.

sourceString: Around the world, countries announced stricter measures to inhibit the disease from spreading.
targetString: Mu nsi yonna, amawanga gaalangirira ebirina okukolebwa ebikakali olw’okuziyiza obulwadde obutasaasaana.

sourceString: On Thursday, Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, extended the city lockdown to May 1.
targetString: Ku Lwokuna, Sergei Sobyanin, meeya wa Moscow, yayongezzaayo omuggalo gw’ekibuga okutuusa nga 1 Ogwokutaano.

sourceString: Nationally, President Vladimir Putin declared Russians would continue to be paid without going to work until April 30.
targetString: Mu ggwanga lyonna, Pulezidenti Vladimir Putin yalangirira nti Abarasha bajja kusasulwa wadde nga tebagenda ku mirimu gyabwe okutuusa nga 30 Ogwokuna.

sourceString: The parliament of Portugal voted to extend the national state of emergency by 15 days; the vote passed with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and one vote against.
targetString: Paliyamenti ya Portugal yakuba akalulu akongezaayo akaseera k’obwerende ka nnaku 15; abasinga obungi 215 baakawagira, kkumi ne batakuba ate omuntu omu n’atakiwagira.

sourceString: Saudi Arabia extended curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina to last the entire day; previously, the curfew was only in effect between 3 p.m. and 6 a.m.
targetString: Saudi Arabia yayongezaayo ekiseera kya kaafiyu mu bibuga ebitukuvu ebya Mecca ne Medina nga kimala olunaku lulamba; mu kusooka, kaafiyu yaliwo wakati wa ssaawa 9 ez’olweggulo ne 12 ez’oku makya.

sourceString: Thailand planned to implement a curfew between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m.
targetString: Thailand yateekateeka kaafiyu wakati w’essaawa 4 ez’ekiro ne 10 ez’ekiro.

sourceString: The governor of Ohio, Mike DeWine, announced the state had extended its stay-at-home order until May 1.
targetString: Gavana wa Ohio, Mike DeWine, yalangirira nti ekitundu ekyo kyongezzaayo ekiseera ky’okubeera ewaka okutuuka nga 1 Ogwokutaano.

sourceString: Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
targetString: Amaduuka g’omu Australia gassa ekkomo ku muwendo gw’ebikookooma omuntu by’alina okugula omulundi ogumu

sourceString: On Sunday and Saturday evening, Australian store chains Woolworths and Coles lowered their purchase restrictions on toilet paper to two and one package per transaction in all stores on national level, respectively.
targetString: Ku Ssande ne ku Lwomukaaga olweggulo, amaduuka g’omu Australia agabuna eggwanga lyonna, Woolworths ne Coles bassa ekkomo lyabwe ku bigulibwa ku bikookooma ng’omuntu agula obuganda bubiri oba kamu wonna mu ggwanga mu maduuka ago gombiriri.

sourceString: ALDI also introduced a one-pack limit, on Monday.
targetString: ALDI nayo yassaawo ekkomo lya kaganda kamu ku Lwokusooka.

sourceString: These limitations were posted as messages on the checkouts, and on the chains' Facebook pages.
targetString: Okukugira kuno kwalagibwa ng’obubaka eri abantu ku miko gya Facebook egy’amakampuni ago.

sourceString: Buyers were reportedly stocking up due to fears of COVID-19 in case people need to self-isolate.
targetString: Abaguzi baagambibwa okubeera nga beeterekera olw’okutya COVID-19 ng’abantu kibeetaagisizza okweyawula.

sourceString: On Wednesday, Woolworths also limited toilet paper purchases for home delivery to one pack per order.
targetString: Ku Lwokusatu, Woolworths nayo yassa ekkomo ku kugula ebikookooma ebigulibwa ne biweerezebwa ewaka ng’omuntu afuna akaganda kamu buli lunaku.

sourceString: These changes followed the previous four-pack per transaction restriction introduced by Woolworths and Coles on March 4 and 5 respectively.
targetString: Enkyukakyuka zino zigoberera okukugira okwasooka okw’akaganda ak’obuna ku buli lugula okwaleetebwa Woolworths ne Coles nga 4 ne 5 Ogwokusatu mu makampuni gombi mu ngoberegana eyo.

sourceString: Coles, in its March 8 media release, reported that with the four-pack restriction in place, "many stores are still selling out within an hour of delivery", and called the demand "unprecedented", while ALDI, in a Facebook post on Tuesday, called it "unexpected".
targetString: Mu kiwandiiko kya Coles ekya nga 8 Ogwokusatu, yategeeza nti okukugira okw’akaganda ak’ebina, "amaduuka mangi gamazaawo mu ssaawa emu yokka we babireetera", era ne bagamba nti obwetaavu obwo “tebubangawo”, so ng’ate yo ALDI, bwe yawandiika ku Facebook ku Lwokubiri yagamba nti kyali "tekisuubirwa".

sourceString: Sales went up in a "sharp increase" last week, according to a Woolworths spokesperson.
targetString: Obutunzi “bwalinnyira ddala waggulu” mu wiiki ewedde okusinziira ku mwogezi wa Woolworths.

sourceString: Costco's store in Canberra also limited the allowed amount to two packs last week.
targetString: Edduuka lya Costco mu Canberra nalyo lyakugira omuwendo ogukkirizibwa ku buganda bubiri mu wiiki ewedde.

sourceString: To further alleviate the shortage, Coles ordered bigger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequency, Woolworths ordered extra stock, while ALDI made stocks for a planned Wednesday special available early.
targetString: Okusobola okukendeeza ku bbula, Coles yasaba ababaweereza bakole obuganda obuneneko era ne bongeza ne ku mirundi gye babaweereza, Woolworths yalagira eyongerwe ku bye yalina, ate ALDI yaleeta ebirala nga bwe yateekateeka ku Lwokusatu olw’enjawulo bituuke nga bukyali.
