targetString: Embeera endala okunaaba mu ngalo obulungi mwe kwetaagisiza olw’okwewala okusaasaanya obulwadde mulimu nga tonnaba oba oluvannyuma lw’okukola ku musale oba ebbwa; oluvannyuma lw’okwasimula, okukolola, oba okunyiza; oluvannyuma lw’okukwata ku bubi bw’ensolo oba okukwata ku nsolo; n’oluvannyuma lw’okukwata ku kasasiro.

sourceString: In many countries, there is a low rate of hand washing with soap.
targetString: Mu mawanga mangi, okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni kuli wansi.

sourceString: A study of hand washing in 54 countries in 2015 found that on average, 38.7% of households practiced hand washing with soap.A 2014 study showed that Saudi Arabia had the highest rate of 97 percent; the United States near the middle with 77 percent; and China with the lowest rate of 23 percent.Several behaviour change methodologies now exist to increase uptake of the behaviour of hand washing with soap at the critical times.Group hand washing for school children at set times of the day is one option in developing countries to engrain hand washing in children's behaviors.
targetString: Okunoonyereza ku kunaaba mu ngalo mu mawanga 54 mu 2015 kwazuula nti okutwaliza awamu, ebitundu 38.7% eby’amaka bye baanaabanga mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni. Okunoonyereza okwakolebwa mu 2014 kwalaga nti Saudi Arabia ye yasingamu okunaaba mu ngalo n’ebitundu 97 ku kikumi; Amerika yali awo mu makkati n’ebitundu 77 ku kikumi; ate China yo yali wansi ddala ku bitundu 23 ku kikumi. Mu kiseera kino waliwo enkola nnyingi ez’okukyusa mu nneeyisa z’abantu okwongera ku mpisa y’okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni mu kaseera kano akazibu. Okunaabira mu ngalo awamu mu kibinja ku baana b’essomero mu biseera ebigere mu lunaku kye kimu ku bikolebwa mu mawanga agakyakula okuyingiza empisa y’okunaaba mu ngalo mu bwongo bw’abaana.

sourceString: The "Essential Health Care Program" implemented by the Department of Education in the Philippines is an example of at scale action to promote children's health and education.
targetString: Enteekateeka ya "Essential Health Care Program" essibwa mu nkola aba Department of Education mu Philippines kye kimu ku byokulabirako by’ebikolwa by’okutumbula ebyobulamu n’ebyenjigiriza by’abaana.

sourceString: Deworming twice a year, supplemented with washing hands daily with soap, brushing teeth daily with fluoride, is at the core of this national program.
targetString: Okumira eddagala ly’ebiwuka emirundi ebiri mu mwaka, nga kuno kw’otadde okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni buli lunaku, okusenya amannyo buli lunaku ne fluoride, bye biri ku mwanjo mu nteekateeka y’eggwanga eno.

sourceString: It has also been successfully implemented in Indonesia.
targetString: Enteekateeka eno era yassibwa bulungi mu nkola mu Indonesia.

sourceString: Removal of microorganisms from skin is enhanced by the addition of soaps or detergents to water.
targetString: Okuggya obuwuka obusirikitu ku lususu kyongerezebwako n’okugatta ssabbuuni mu mazzi.

sourceString: The main action of soaps and detergents is to reduce barriers to solution, and increase solubility.
targetString: Omulimu gwa ssabbuuni ogusinga kwe kukendeeza ebiziyiza amazzi, n’okusobozesa okumulunguka amangu.

sourceString: Water alone is an inefficient skin cleanser because fats and proteins, which are components of organic soil, are not readily dissolved in water.
targetString: Amazzi gokka tegasobola kutukuza lususu kubanga amasavu ne puloteni, nga bino bye bimu ku biba mu ttaka ery’obutonde, tebimulungulirwa mu mazzi.

sourceString: Cleansing is, however, aided by a reasonable flow of water..
targetString: Wabula, okutukula kuyambibwako amazzi agatambula..

sourceString: Solid soap, because of its reusable nature, may hold bacteria acquired from previous uses.
targetString: Ssabbuuni ow’ekitole, olw’okuba ng’addamu okukozesebwa, ayinza okusigalako obuwuka okuva ku baba basoose okumukozesa.

sourceString: A small number of studies which have looked at the bacterial transfer from contaminated solid soap have concluded transfer is unlikely as the bacteria are rinsed off with the foam.
targetString: Waliwo okunoonyereza okutonotono okwakolebwa ku kutambuza obuwuka (bacteria) obuba busigadde ku ssabbuuni ow’ekitole nga kwalaga nti kizibu obuwuka okutambuzibwa olw’okuba nga bugendera mu byovu.

sourceString: The CDC still states "liquid soap with hands-free controls for dispensing is preferable".
targetString: CDC era ekyagamba nti "ssabbuuni ow’amazzi ng’ayiika nga takwatiddwako y’asinga".

sourceString: Antibacterial soaps have been heavily promoted to a health-conscious public.
targetString: Abantu abafaayo eri obulamu bakubiriziddwa nnyo okukozesa ssabbuuni atta obuwuka (Antibacterial soaps).

sourceString: To date, there is no evidence that using recommended antiseptics or disinfectants selects for antibiotic-resistant organisms in nature.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, tewannabaawo bukakafu nti okukozesa antiseptics oba disinfectants kitta obuwuka.

sourceString: However, antibacterial soaps contain common antibacterial agents such as triclosan, which has an extensive list of resistant strains of organisms.
targetString: Wabula, ssabbuuni atta obuwuka alimu eddagala erirwanyisa obuwuka nga triclosan, eririmu ebintu ebingi ebitta obuwuka.

sourceString: So, even if antibiotic resistant strains aren't selected for by antibacterial soaps, they might not be as effective as they are marketed to be.
targetString: Noolwekyo, ne kiba ng’ebiremesa antibiotics tebirondeddwa ssabbuuni wa buwuka, era tebisobola kukola bulungi nga bwe bigambibwa okukola.

sourceString: Besides the surfactant and skin-protecting agent, the sophisticated formulations may contain acids (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) as pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid and further skin conditioners (aloe vera, vitamins, menthol, plant extracts).A comprehensive analysis from the University of Oregon School of Public Health indicated that plain soaps are as effective as consumer-grade anti-bacterial soaps containing triclosan in preventing illness and removing bacteria from the hands.
targetString: Ng’oggyeeko ekirungo ekikuuma olususu, eddagala ery’enjawulo eririmu liyinza okubaamu acid (acetic acid, ascorbic acid, lactic acid) nga pH regulator, antimicrobially active benzoic acid n’ebirala ebiweweeza olususu (aloe vera, vitamiini, menthol, ebiggyibwa mu bimera). Okwekenneenya okw’amaanyi okuva mu University of Oregon School of Public Health kwalaga nti ssabbuuni owa bulijjo akolera ddala nga ssabbuuni w’obuwuka alimu triclosan mu kutangira obulwadde n’okuggya obuwuka mu ngalo.

sourceString: Hot water that is comfortable for washing hands is not hot enough to kill bacteria.
targetString: Amazzi agookya omuntu g’asobola okunaaba mu ngalo gaba tegookya kimala kutta buwuka.

sourceString: Bacteria grow much faster at body temperature (37 °C).
targetString: Obuwuka bwa bacteria bukula mangu nnyo mu bbugumu ly’omubiri (37 °C).

sourceString: However, warm, soapy water is more effective than cold, soapy water at removing natural oils which hold soils and bacteria.
targetString: Wabula, amazzi agabuguma, ag’olusabbuuni gakola okusinga ku gannyogoga, agalimu olusabbuuni mu kuggyamu oluzigozigo olukwata ettaka ne bacteria.

sourceString: Contrary to popular belief however, scientific studies have shown that using warm water has no effect on reducing the microbial load on hands.
targetString: Wabula, okwawukana ku kitera okulowoozebwa, okunoonyereza kw’ekinnassaayansi kulaze nti okukozesa amazzi agabuguma tekirina kye kikyusa ku muwendo gwa buwuka obubeera ku ngalo.

sourceString: A hand sanitizer or hand antiseptic is a non-water-based hand hygiene agent.
targetString: Hand sanitizer oba hand antiseptic kye kirongoosa engalo ekiteesigamiziddwa ku mazzi.

sourceString: In the late 1990s and early part of the 21st century, alcohol rub non-water-based hand hygiene agents (also known as alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, or hand sanitizers) began to gain popularity.
targetString: Ku nkomerero y’egya 1990 n’ekitundu ekisooka eky’ekyasa ekya 21, ebirongoosa engalo ebikolebwa mu mwenge (era ebiyitibwa alcohol-based hand rubs, antiseptic hand rubs, oba hand sanitizers) byatandika okufuna ettutumu.

sourceString: Most are based on isopropyl alcohol or ethanol formulated together with a thickening agent such as Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) into a gel, or a humectant such as glycerin into a liquid, or foam for ease of use and to decrease the drying effect of the alcohol.
targetString: Ebisinga bikolebwa mu isopropyl alcohol oba ethanol nga biteereddwamu ekintu ekikaluba nga Carbomer (polymer of acrylic acid) okubifuula eby’ekizigo, oba humectant nga glycerin ne bifuuka eby’amazzi, oba ekyovu okusobola okwanguyiza ababikozesa n’okukendeeza ku kukaza kw’omwenge.

sourceString: Adding diluted hydrogen-peroxide increases further  the antimicrobial activity.Hand sanitizers containing a minimum of 60 to 95% alcohol are efficient germ killers.
targetString: Okugattamu hydrogen-peroxide ajunguluddwa kyongera ku busobozi bwakyo obw’okutta obuwuka. Hand sanitizers ezirimu omwenge ogutakka wansi wa bitundu 60 ku 95% zitta bulungi obuwuka (germs).

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers kill bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA and VRE), tuberculosis, and some viruses (including HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, and hepatitis) and fungi.
targetString: Alcohol rub sanitizers zitta bacteria, multi-drug resistant bacteria (MRSA ne VRE), tuberculosis, ne virus ezimu (omuli HIV, herpes, RSV, rhinovirus, vaccinia, influenza, ne hepatitis) ne fungi.

sourceString: Alcohol rub sanitizers containing 70% alcohol kill 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, similar to 35 decibel reduction) of the bacteria on hands 30 seconds after application and 99.99% to 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) of the bacteria on hands 1 minute after application.Hand sanitizers are most effective against bacteria and less effective against some viruses.
targetString: Alcohol rub sanitizers ezirimu omwenge ogw’ebitundu 70% zitta ebitundu bya bacteria 99.97% (3.5 log reduction, bw’okugeraageranya ne 35 decibel reduction) mu ngalo nga wayise obutikitiki 30 nga zikozeseddwa n’ebitundu 99.99% okutuuka ku 99.999% (4 to 5 log reduction) ebya bacteria mu ngalo oluvannyuma lw’eddakiika 1 nga zikozeseddwa. Hand sanitizers zikola nnyo ku bacteria naye nga tezikola bulungi ku virus ezimu.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are almost entirely ineffective against norovirus (or Norwalk) type viruses, the most common cause of contagious gastroenteritis.Enough hand antiseptic or alcohol rub must be used to thoroughly wet or cover both hands.
targetString: Hand sanitizers ezikolebwa mu mwenge kyenkana tezikolera ddala ku kika kya virus ekya norovirus (oba Norwalk), nga zino ze zisinga okuleeta ssenyiga w’omu lubuto (gastroenteritis) asiigibwa. Hand antiseptic oba alcohol rub amala ateekwa okukozesebwa okutobya oba okubunya engalo zombi.

sourceString: The front and back of both hands and between and the ends of all fingers are rubbed for approximately 30 seconds until the liquid, foam or gel is dry.
targetString: Mu maaso n’emabega w’engalo zonna ne mu mpataanya n’engalo zonna gye zisembera wakunyibwa okumala obutikitiki nga 30 okutuusa amazzi, ekyovu oba ekizigo bwe kikala.

sourceString: Finger tips must be washed well too, rubbing them in both palms.The US Center for Disease Control and Prevention recommends hand washing over hand sanitizer rubs, particularly when hands are visibly dirty.
targetString: Obusongezo bw’engalo nabwo buteekwa okunaazibwa obulungi, nga bukunyibwa mu bibatu byombi. US Center for Disease Control and Prevention egamba nti okunaaba mu ngalo kusinga okukozesa sanitizer, naddala ng’engalo zirabika nga nkyafu.

sourceString: The increasing use of these agents is based on their ease of use and rapid killing activity against micro-organisms; however, they should not serve as a replacement for proper hand washing unless soap and water are unavailable.
targetString: Eky’okuba ng’ebintu bino byongedde okukozesebwa kyesigamizibwa ku kuba nti byangu okukozesa era bitta mangu obuwuka obusirikitu; wabula, tebiteekeddwa kusikira nkola ya kunaaba mu ngalo obulungi okuggyako nga ssabbuuni n’amazzi tebiriiwo.

sourceString: Frequent use of alcohol-based hand sanitizers can cause dry skin unless emollients and/or skin moisturizers are added to the formula.
targetString: Okukozesa ennyo sanitizer ezikolebwa mu mwenge kisobola okukaza olususu okuggyako nga mugattiddwamu ebigonza ne/oba ebiweweeza olususu.

sourceString: The drying effect of alcohol can be reduced or eliminated by adding glycerin and/or other emollients to the formula.
targetString: Okukaza olususu kusobola okukendeezebwa oba okuggyibwawo nga sanitizer zigattibwamu ebizigo oba ebigonza olususu ebirala.

sourceString: In clinical trials, alcohol-based hand sanitizers containing emollients caused substantially less skin irritation and dryness than soaps or antimicrobial detergents.
targetString: Mu kunoonyereza kw’ekisawo, sanitizer ezikoleddwa mu mwenge nga zigattiddwamu ebigonza olususu zaaleeta okukala kw’olususu kutono nnyo okusinga ssabbuuni oba ebisabbuunisabbuuni ebitta obuwuka.

sourceString: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome or hypersensitivity to alcohol or additives present in alcohol hand rubs rarely occur.
targetString: Allergic contact dermatitis, contact urticaria syndrome oba obutakolagana na mwenge oba n’ebigattibwa mu sanitizer ezikolebwa mu mwenge tebitera kubeerawo.

sourceString: The lower tendency to induce irritant contact dermatitis became an attraction as compared to soap and water hand washing.
targetString: Eky’obutaleeta nnyo kukosebwa kwa lususu (irritant contact dermatitis) kyasikiriza abantu bw’ogeraageranya n’okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni n’amazzi.

sourceString: Despite their effectiveness, non-water agents do not cleanse the hands of organic material, but simply disinfect them.
targetString: Newankubadde nga zikola bulungi, ebirongoosa engalo ebitakolebwa mu mazzi tebitukuza mangu, bitta buwuka bwokka.

sourceString: It is for this reason that hand sanitizers are not as effective as soap and water at preventing the spread of many pathogens, since the pathogens still remain on the hands.
targetString: Eno ye nsonga lwaki sanitizer tezikola bulungi kwenkana ssabbuuni n’amazzi mu kulwanyisa okusaasaana kw’obuwuka bungi, olw’okuba ng’obuwuka busigala mu ngalo.

sourceString: Alcohol-free hand sanitizer efficacy is heavily dependent on the ingredients and formulation, and historically has significantly under-performed alcohol and alcohol rubs.
targetString: Sanitizer ezitaliimu mwenge okukola kwazo kusinziira nnyo ku birimu, era mu byafaayo tezikola kwenkana mwenge ne sanitizer ezirimu omwenge.

sourceString: More recently, formulations that use benzalkonium chloride have been shown to have persistent and cumulative antimicrobial activity after application, unlike alcohol, which has been shown to decrease in efficacy after repeated use, probably due to progressive adverse skin reactions.
targetString: Emabegako katono, ebirungo ebikozesa benzalkonium chloride byazuulibwa ng’obukozi bwabyo tebukendeera era nga bweyongera mu kutta obuwuka obusirikitu nga bikozeseddwa, okusinga ku mwenge, ogwazuulibwa ng’obukozi bwagwo bukendeera buli lwe gweyongera okukozesebwa, oboolyawo olw’obuzibu bwe gutuusa ku lususu.

sourceString: Many people in low-income communities cannot afford soap and use ash or soil instead.
targetString: Abantu bangi mu bitundu ebikyakula tebasobola kufuna ssabbuuni nga noolwekyo bakozesa vvu na ttaka.

sourceString: Ash or soil may be more effective than water alone, but may be less effective than soap.
targetString: Evvu oba ettaka liyinza okukola obulungiko okusinga amazzi ameereere, naye nga liyinza obutakola bulungi kwenkana ssabbuuni.

sourceString: One concern is that if the soil or ash is contaminated with microorganisms it may increase the spread of disease rather than decrease it.
targetString: Ekizibu ekiriwo kiri nti singa ettaka oba evvu libaamu obuwuka obusirikitu kiyinza okwongera ku kusaasaana kw’obulwadde mu kifo ky’okubukendeeza.

sourceString: Like soap, ash is also a disinfecting agent because in contact with water, it forms an alkaline solution.
targetString: Nga bwe kiri ku ssabbuuni, evvu nalyo litta obuwuka kubanga bwe lyegatta n’amazzi likola alkaline.

sourceString: WHO recommended ash or sand as alternative to soap when soap is not available.
targetString: WHO yakkiriza okukozesa evvu oba omusenyu mu kifo kya ssabbuuni singa ssabbuuni tabaawo.

sourceString: Correct handwashing technique recommended by the US Centers for Disease Control  for prevention of transmission of disease includes the following steps:
targetString: Okunaaba mu ngalo okutuufu okulagibwa US Centers for Disease Control olw’okutangira okusaasaana kw’obulwadde kulimu emitendera gino:

sourceString: Wet hands with warm or cold running water.
targetString: Tobya engalo n’amazzi agabuguma oba agannyogoga nga gatambula.

sourceString: Running water is recommended because standing basins may be contaminated, while the temperature of the water does not seem to make a difference.
targetString: Amazzi agatambula ge galagirwa kubanga amazzi agatatambula gayinza okugendamu obuwuka, so ng’ebbugumu ly’amazzi terireetawo njawulo.

sourceString: Lather hands by rubbing them with a generous amount of soap, including the backs of hands, between fingers, and under nails.
targetString: Leeta ekyovu mu ngalo ng’ozikuuba ne ssabbuuni amala, omuli n’emabega w’engalo, mu mpataanya, ne wansi w’enjala.

sourceString: Soap lifts germs from the skin, and studies show that people tend to wash their hands more thoroughly when soap is used rather than water alone.
targetString: Ssabbuuni aggya obuwuka ku lususu, era okunoonyereza kulaze nti abantu banaaba bulungi engalo zaabwe nga bakozesezza ssabbuuni okusinga amazzi ameereere.

sourceString: Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
targetString: Naaba okumala waakiri obutikitiki 20.

sourceString: Scrubbing creates friction, which helps remove germs from skin, and scrubbing for longer periods removes more germs.
targetString: Okunaaba mu ngalo kuzireetera okukuubagana, ekiyamba okuggya obuwuka ku lususu, era okukubira ekiseera ekisingako kiggyamu obuwuka bungi.

sourceString: Rinse well under running water.
targetString: Munyunguza bulungi mu mazzi agatambula.

sourceString: Rinsing in a basin can recontaminate hands.
targetString: Okumunyunguza mu mazzi agatatambula kiyinza okuleetera engalo okuddamu okufuna obuwuka.

sourceString: Dry with a clean towel or allow to air dry.
targetString: Engalo zikaze ne ka tawulo akakalu oba zireke zikale zokka.

sourceString: Wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated.The most commonly missed areas are the thumb, the wrist, the areas between the fingers, and under fingernails.
targetString: Engalo embisi ziddamu mangu okufuna obuwuka. Ebifo ebisinga okwerabirwa kye kinkumu, ekiseke, empataanya, ne munda w’enjala.

sourceString: Artificial nails and chipped nail polish may harbor microorganisms.
targetString: Enjala empaatiike n’ebisiigibwa ku njala biyinza okukweka obuwuka.

sourceString: Moisturizing lotion is often recommended to keep the hands from drying out; dry skin can lead to skin damage which can increase the risk for the transmission of infection.
targetString: Ebizigo ebiweweeza bisembebwa okukuuma engalo obutakala; olususu olukalu lusobola okuviirako obuvune ku lususu nga kino kisobola okwongeza ku bulabe bw’okufuna endwadde.

sourceString: Various low-cost options can be made to facilitate hand washing where tap-water and/or soap is not available e.g. pouring water from a hanging jerrycan or gourd with suitable holes and/or using ash if needed in developing countries.In situations with limited water supply (such as schools or rural areas in developing countries), there are water-conserving solutions, such as "tippy-taps" and other low-cost options.
targetString: Waliwo enkola endala nnyingi eziyinza okusobozesa okunaaba mu ngalo ng’amazzi ga taapu/ne oba ssabbuuni taliiwo okugeza okuyiwa amazzi okuva mu kidomola ekiwanikiddwa oba ekita ekiteereddwamu obutuli ne/oba okukozesa evvu bwe kiba kyetaagisizza mu mawanga agakyakula. Mu mbeera omutali mazzi gamala (ng’amasomero oba mu byalo mu mawanga agakyakula), waliwo ebikolebwa okukendeeza amazzi agakozesebwa, nga "tippy-taps" n’enkola endala ezitatwala ssente nnyingi.

sourceString: A tippy-tap is a simple technology using a jug suspended by a rope, and a foot-operated lever to pour a small amount of water over the hands and a bar of soap.
targetString: Tippy-tap ye nkola ennyangu ey’okukozesa akadomola akasibiddwako omuguwa, ne lusibwako akati omuntu kw’alinnya amazzi amatonotono ne gayiika ku ngalo n’ekitole kya ssabbuuni.

sourceString: Effective drying of the hands is an essential part of the hand hygiene process, but there is some debate over the most effective form of drying in public washrooms.
targetString: Okukaza engalo obulungi kitundu kikulu mu kuyonja engalo, naye nga waliwo obutakkaanya ku ngeri esinga obulungi ey’okukazaamu engalo mu kaabuyonjo ez’olukale.

sourceString: A growing volume of research suggests paper towels are much more hygienic than the electric hand dryers found in many washrooms.
targetString: Okunoonyereza kungi kugamba nti tawulo z’empapula zikola bulungi nnyo okusinga ebikaza eby’amasannyalaze ebisangibwa mu kaabuyonjo eziwerako.

sourceString: In 2008, a study was conducted by the University of Westminster, London, and sponsored by the paper-towel industry the European Tissue Symposium, to compare the levels of hygiene offered by paper towels, warm-air hand dryers and the more modern jet-air hand dryers.
targetString: Mu 2008, okunoonyereza kwakolebwa University of Westminster, London, era ne kusasulirwa ekkolero lya tawulo z’empapula eriyitibwa European Tissue Symposium, okugeraageranya obuyonjo obuva mu kukozesa tawulo z’empapula, ebikaza engalo eby’empewo ebuguma n’ebikaza engalo ebipya eby’empewo ey’amaanyi (jet-air hand dryers).

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with the warm-air dryer, the total number of bacteria was found to increase on average on the finger pads by 194% and on the palms by 254%.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’okunaaba n’okukaza engalo n’ekikaza eky’empewo ebuguma, omuwendo gwa bacteria gwasangibwa nga gweyongera ku ngalo n’ebitundu 194% ate ku bibatu n’ebitundu 254%.

sourceString: Drying with the jet-air dryer resulted in an increase on average of the total number of bacteria on the finger pads by 42% and on the palms by 15%.
targetString: Okukaza engalo n’empewo ey’amaanyi kyaviirako okweyongera kw’omuwendo gwa bacteria ku ngalo n’ebitundu 42% ate ku bibatu n’ebitundu 15%.

sourceString: After washing and drying hands with a paper towel, the total number of bacteria was reduced on average on the finger pads by up to 76% and on the palms by up to 77%.The scientists also carried out tests to establish whether there was the potential for cross contamination of other washroom users and the washroom environment as a result of each type of drying method.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’okunaaba n’okukaza engalo ne tawulo y’olupapula, omuwendo gwa bacteria gwakendeezebwa ku ngalo n’ebitundu 76% ate ku bibatu n’ebitundu 77%. Bannassaayansi era baakola okukebera okuzuula oba nga waaliwo obusobozi bw’abakozesa kaabuyonjo okusiigana obuwuka awamu n’embeera y’ekifo kya kaabuyonjo nga kiva ku bika by’okukaza engalo eby’enjawulo.

sourceString: The jet-air dryer, which blows air out of the unit at claimed speeds of 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), was capable of blowing micro-organisms from the hands and the unit and potentially contaminating other washroom users and the washroom environment up to 2 metres away.
targetString: Ekikaza eky’empewo ey’amaanyi, nga kino kifuuyira empewo ku misinde gya 180 m/s (650 km/h; 400 mph), kyali kisobola okufuuwa obuwuka okuva mu ngalo ne mu kyo era nga kiyinza okubusiiga abakozesa ba kaabuyonjo abalala n’okubusaasaanya mu kaabuyonjo mu bbanga lya mita 2 okuva we kiri.

sourceString: Use of a warm-air hand dryer spread micro-organisms up to 0.25 metres from the dryer.
targetString: Okukozesa ekikaza eky’empewo ebuguma kyafuuwa obuwuka mu bbanga lya mita 0.25 okuva we kiri.

sourceString: Paper towels showed no significant spread of micro-organisms.In 2005, in a study conducted by TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, different hand drying methods were evaluated.
targetString: Tawulo z’empapula tezaalaga busobozi bwa kusaasaanya buwuka. Mu 2005, mu kunoonyereza okwakolebwa TÜV Produkt und Umwelt, enkola z’okukaza engalo ez’enjawulo zeekenneenyezebwa.

sourceString: The following changes in the bacterial count after drying the hands were observed:
targetString: Enkyukakyuka zino wammanga mu muwendo gwa bacteria oluvannyuma lw’okukaza engalo zaazuulibwa:

sourceString: Many different hand dryer manufacturers exist, and hand driers have been compared against drying with paper towels.
targetString: Waliwo abakola ebikaza engalo bangi, era ebikaza engalo byageraageranyizibwa n’okukaza engalo ne tawulo z’empapula.

sourceString: Hand washing using hand sanitizing wipes is an alternative during traveling in the absence of soap and water.
targetString: Okunaaba engalo n’obupapula obuweweevu kikozesebwa mu kutambula nga tewali ssabbuuni na mazzi.

sourceString: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer should contain at least 60% alcohol.
targetString: Sanitizer ezirimu omwenge zirina okubaamu waakiri ebitundu 60% eby’omwenge.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing became mandatory long after Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis discovered its effectiveness (in 1846) in preventing disease in a hospital environment.
targetString: Okunaaba mu ngalo olw’okwewala obulwadde kyafuuka kya buwaze nga wayise ekiseera kinene omusawo Omuhangare Ignaz Semmelweis ng’azudde nti kikola bulungi (mu 1846) mu kwewala endwadde mu malwaliro.

sourceString: There are electronic devices that provide feedback to remind hospital staff to wash their hands when they forget.
targetString: Waliwo ebyuma ebyeyambisibwa okujjukiza abakozi mu malwaliro okunaaba engalo zaabwe nga beerabidde.

sourceString: One study has found decreased infection rates with their use.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okumu kwazuula nti okukwatibwa obulwadde kwakendeera ng’ebyuma byo bikozeseddwa.

sourceString: Medical hand-washing is for a minimum of 15 seconds, using generous amounts of soap and water or gel to lather and rub each part of the hands.
targetString: Okunaaba mu ngalo olw’okwewala endwadde kumala obutikitiki obutakka wansi wa 15, ng’okozesa ssabbuuni amala n’amazzi okutobya n’okukuuba buli kitundu kya ngalo.

sourceString: Hands should be rubbed together with digits interlocking.
targetString: Engalo zirina okukuubibwa wamu n’ezo ze zigombagana nazo.

sourceString: If there is debris under fingernails, a bristle brush may be used to remove it.
targetString: Bwe wabaawo obucaafu obuli mu njala, ka bulaasi ak’obusanso kayinza okukozesebwa okubuggyamu.

sourceString: Since germs may remain in the water on the hands, it is important to rinse well and wipe dry with a clean towel.
targetString: Olw’okuba ng’obuwuka buyinza okusigala mu mazzi agali ku ngalo, kikulu okumunyunguza obulungi n’okusiimuula ne tawulo ennyonjo.

sourceString: After drying, the paper towel should be used to turn off the water (and open any exit door if necessary).
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’okukaza, tawulo y’olupapula erina okukozesebwa okusiba amazzi (n’okuggulawo awafulumya amazzi bwe kiba kyetaagisizza).

sourceString: This avoids re-contaminating the hands from those surfaces.
targetString: Kino kitaasa engalo okuddamu okufuna obuwuka okuva ku bintu ebyo.

sourceString: The purpose of hand-washing in the health-care setting is to remove pathogenic microorganisms ("germs") and avoid transmitting them.
targetString: Omugaso gw’okunaaba engalo mu mbeera y’eddwaliro kwe kuggyawo obuwuka obusirikitu ("germs") n’okwewala okubusaasaanya.

sourceString: The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a lack of hand-washing remains at unacceptable levels in most medical environments, with large numbers of doctors and nurses routinely forgetting to wash their hands before touching patients, thus transmitting microorganisms.
targetString: New England Journal of Medicine egamba nti obutanaaba mu ngalo kikyali kizibu kya maanyi mu malwaliro agasinga obungi, ng’abasawo bangi nnyo ne ba nansi beerabira okunaaba engalo zaabwe nga tebannakwata ku balwadde, ne kibaleetera okubasiiga obuwuka.

sourceString: One study showed that proper hand-washing and other simple procedures can decrease the rate of catheter-related bloodstream infections by 66 percent.The World Health Organization has published a sheet demonstrating standard hand-washing and hand-rubbing in health-care sectors.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okumu kwalaga nti okunaaba mu ngalo obulungi n’emitendera emirala emyangu bisobola okukendeeza okuyingiza obuwuka mu musaayi okwekuusa ku kuyingiza obuseke mu mubiri n’ebitundu 66 ku kikumi. World Health Organization yafulumya olupapula olwoleka ennaaba y’engalo n’enkuuba y’engalo mu malwaliro.

sourceString: The draft guidance of hand hygiene by the organization can also be found at its website for public comment.
targetString: Ekiwandiiko ekiruŋŋamya ennaaba y’engalo eky’ekitongole kino era kisobola okusangibwa ku mutimbagano gwakyo abantu basobole okukyogerako.

sourceString: A relevant review was conducted by Whitby et al.
targetString: Okukyekenneenya okulungi kwakolebwa Whitby ne banne.

sourceString: Commercial devices can measure and validate hand hygiene, if demonstration of regulatory compliance is required.
targetString: Waliwo ebyuma ebisobola okupima n’okukakasa obuyonjo, bwe kiba nga kyetaagisa okukakasa nti butuukana n’ebikkizirizibwa mu mateeka.

sourceString: The World Health Organization has "Five Moments" for washing hands:
targetString: World Health Organization erina "Embeera Ttaano" ez’okunaabiramu engalo:

sourceString: after exposure to blood/body fluids
targetString: oluvannyuma lw’okukwata ku musaayi/amazzi g’omu mubiri

sourceString: before an aseptic task, and
targetString: ng’ogenda okukola ku kintu ekitaliimu buwuka, ne

sourceString: after patient care.The addition of antiseptic chemicals to soap ("medicated" or "antimicrobial" soaps) confers killing action to a hand-washing agent.
targetString: oluvannyuma lw’okukola ku mulwadde. Okuteeka eddagala eritta obuwuka mu ssabbuuni (ssabbuuni ali "medicated" oba "antimicrobial") kisobozesa ssabbuuni oyo okuba ng’atta obuwuka.

sourceString: Such killing action may be desired prior to performing surgery or in settings in which antibiotic-resistant organisms are highly prevalent.To 'scrub' one's hands for a surgical operation, it is necessary to have a tap that can be turned on and off without touching it with the hands, some chlorhexidine or iodine wash, sterile towels for drying the hands after washing, and a sterile brush for scrubbing and another sterile instrument for cleaning under the fingernails.
targetString: Okutta obuwuka okwo kuyinza okuba nga kwetaagisa ng’okulongoosa omulwadde tekunnakolebwa oba mu mbeera omubeera ennyo obuwuka obwamanyiira eddagala eritta obuwuka. Okukuuba engalo ng’ogenda okulongoosa omulwadde, kyetaagisa okubeera ne taapu esobola okusumululwa n’okusibwa nga tekwatiddwako na ngalo, okunaaba ne chlorhexidine oba iodine, bu-tawulo obufumbiddwa okukazisa engalo oluvannyuma lw’okuzinaaba, ne bulaasi ey’okukuuta n’ekintu ekirala ekifumbiddwa okulongoosa mu njala.

sourceString: All jewelry should be removed.
targetString: Ebyokwewunda byonna birina okuggyibwako.

sourceString: This procedure requires washing the hands and forearms up to the elbow, usually 2–6 minutes.
targetString: Omulimu guno gwetaaga okunaaba mu ngalo n’ekitundu ky’emikono okutuuka mu nkokola, okumala eddakiika 2–6.

sourceString: Long scrub-times (10 minutes) are not necessary.
targetString: Okukuuba engalo okumala obudde obungi (eddakiika 10) tekwetaagisa.

sourceString: When rinsing, water on the forearms must be prevented from running back to the hands.
targetString: Mu kumunyunguza, amazzi agava ku mikono tegateekwa kukulukutira ku ngalo.

sourceString: After hand-washing is completed, the hands are dried with a sterile cloth and a surgical gown is donned.
targetString: Okunaaba mu ngalo bwe kuggwa, engalo zikazibwa n’akagoye akafumbiddwa olwo akakanzu akalongoosebwamu ne kambalwa.

sourceString: To reduce the spread of germs, it is better to wash the hands or use a hand antiseptic before and after tending to a sick person.
targetString: Okukendeeza okusaasaana kw’obuwuka, kirungi okunaaba mu ngalo oba okukozesa eddagala eritta obuwuka ng’ogenda okukola ku mulwadde n’oluvannyuma.

sourceString: For control of staphylococcal infections in hospitals, it has been found that the greatest benefit from hand-cleansing came from the first 20% of washing, and that very little additional benefit was gained when hand cleansing frequency was increased beyond 35%.
targetString: Okuziyiza okufuna obuwuka (staphylococcal infections) mu malwaliro, kyazuulibwa nti okuganyulwa okusinga mu kulongoosa engalo kwava mu bitundu by’okunaaba ebisooka 20%, nti era okuganyulwa okulala kutono nnyo okwafunibwa ng’emirundi gy’okunaaba mu ngalo gyeyongedde okusukka mu bitundu 35%.

sourceString: Washing with plain soap results in more than triple the rate of bacterial infectious disease transmitted to food as compared to washing with antibacterial soap.Comparing hand-rubbing with alcohol-based solution with hand washing with antibacterial soap for a median time of 30 seconds each showed that the alcohol hand-rubbing reduced bacterial contamination 26% more than the antibacterial soap.
targetString: Okunaaba ne ssabbuuni omwereere kyongera obulwadde obuva ku bacteria okugenda mu mmere emirundi egisukka mu esatu bw’ogeraageranya n’okunaaba ne ssabbuuni alimu eddagala eritta bacteria. Okugeraageranya okukuuba engalo ne sanitizer alimu omwenge n’okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni alimu eddagala eritta bacteria okumala obutikitiki 30 ku buli kimu kwalaga nti okukuuba engalo ne sanitizer alimu omwenge kyakendeeza bacteria n’ebitundu 26% okusinga ssabbuuni alimu eddagala eritta bacteria.

sourceString: But soap and water is more effective than alcohol-based hand rubs for reducing H1N1 influenza A virus and Clostridium difficile spores from hands.Interventions to improve hand hygiene in healthcare settings can involve education for staff on hand washing, increasing the availability of alcohol-based hand rub, and written and verbal reminders to staff.
targetString: Wabula ssabbuuni n’amazzi bikola okusinga okukuuba ne sanitizer alimu omwenge mu kukendeeza akawuka ka H1N1 influenza A virus ne Clostridium difficile spores okuva mu ngalo. Ebikolebwa okutumbula obuyonjo bw’engalo mu malwaliro bisobola okuzingiramu okusomesa abakozi ku kunaaba mu ngalo, okwongera ku sanitizer ezirimu omwenge, n’okujjukiza abakozi mu buwandiike oba mu kwogera.

sourceString: There is a need for more research into which of these interventions are most effective in different healthcare settings.
targetString: Waliwo obwetaavu bw’okwongera okunoonyereza ku kiki ku bikolebwa bino ekisinga okukola mu mbeera z’amalwaliro ez’enjawulo.

sourceString: In developing countries, hand washing with soap is recognized as a cost-effective, essential tool for achieving good health, and even good nutrition.
targetString: Mu mawanga agakyakula, okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni kirabibwa ng’enkola ekendeeza ku ssente, mu kufuna ebyobulamu ebirungi, era ne mu ndya ennungi.

sourceString: However, a lack of reliable water supply, soap or hand washing facilities in people's homes, at schools and at the workplace make it a challenge to achieve universal hand washing behaviors.
targetString: Wabula, ebbula ly’amazzi, ssabbuuni oba ebikozesebwa okunaaba mu ngalo mu maka g’abantu, ku masomero ne ku mirimu kya kusoomooza mu kubunyisa n’okwagazisa empisa y’okunaaba mu ngalo wonna.

sourceString: For example, in most of rural Africa hand washing taps close to every private or public toilet are scarce, even though cheap options exist to build hand washing stations.
targetString: Okugeza, mu bitundu bya Africa eby’ebyalo ebisinga taapu ezikozesebwa okunaaba mu ngalo okuliraana buli kaabuyonjo ya bwannannyini oba ey’olukale za bbula, newankubadde ng’enkola ezitali za buseere ez’okuzimba ebifo ebinaabirwamu engalo weeziri.

sourceString: However, low hand washing rates rather can also be the result of engrained habits rather than due to a lack of soap or water.
targetString: Wabula, okunaaba mu ngalo ekitono era kisobola okubeera empisa z’omuntu ezaamukuliramu edda nga si bubulwa bwa mazzi na ssabbuuni.

sourceString: The promotion and advocacy of hand washing with soap can influence policy decisions, raise awareness about the benefits of hand washing and lead to long-term behavior change of the population.
targetString: Okulanga n’okukubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni kisobola okukyusa ebisalibwawo mu ggwanga, okusomesa abantu ku miganyulo egiri mu kunaaba mu ngalo n’okukyusiza ddala empisa z’abantu obulamu bwabwe bwonna.

sourceString: For this to work effectively, monitoring and evaluation are necessary.
targetString: Naye kino okukola obulungi, okulondoola n’okwekaliriza abantu bye bakola kyetaagisa nnyo.

sourceString: A systematic review of 70 studies found that community-based approaches are effective at increasing hand washing in LMICs, while social marketing campaigns are less effective.One example for hand washing promotion in schools is the "Three Star Approach" by UNICEF that encourages schools to take simple, inexpensive steps to ensure that students wash their hands with soap, among other hygienic requirements.
targetString: Okwekenneenya obulungi okw’emirundi 70 kwazuula nti enkola ezeesigamiziddwa ku bitundu abantu gye babeera mu nsi ezikyakula (LMICs) zikola bulungi mu kukubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo; wabula, ye kakuyege w’okulanga ebyamaguzi ate ye takola mu ngeri eyo. Ekyokulabirako ky’okukubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo mu masomero kye kya UNICEF "Enkola ey’Emmunyeenye Essatu (Three Star Approach)"; enkola eno erimu okukubiriza amasomero okukozesa enkola ennyangu ate ezitali za bbeeyi mu kukubiriza abayizi okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni, ng’ekimu ku byetaago by’obuyonjo.

sourceString: When minimum standards are achieved, schools can move from one to ultimately three stars.
targetString: Omutindo ogusookerwako bwe gutuukibwako, amasomero gasobola okuva ku mmunyenye emu ne geeyongera ku mmunyeenye essatu.

sourceString: Building hand washing stations can be a part of hand washing promotion campaigns that are carried out in order to reduce diseases and child mortality.
targetString: Okutegekawo ebifo by’okunaabiramu engalo kisobola okubeera omu ku kakuyege akolebwa okukendeeza ku ndwadde n’abaana okufa.

sourceString: Global Hand washing Day is another example of an awareness-raising campaign that is trying to achieve behavior change.As a result of the 2019-20 coronavirus pandemic, UNICEF promoted the adoption of a handwashing emoji.
targetString: Olunaku lw’Ensi yonna olw’Okunaaba mu ngalo (Global Hand washing Day) nakyo kyakulabirako kirungi ekiyinza okukozesebwa okukubiriza abantu okukyusa empisa. Olw’obulwadde bwa coronavirus 2019-2020, UNICEF yayiiya akafaananyi akakozesebwa ku yintaneeti okukubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo.

sourceString: Few studies have considered the overall cost effectiveness of hand washing in developing countries in relationship to DALYs averted.
targetString: Waliwo okunoonyereza okutonotono okwekenneenyezza obusobosi mu byensimbi obw’awamu obw’okunaaba mu ngalo mu mawanga agakyakula bw’ogeraageranya n’olupimo lwa DALYs averted.

sourceString: However, one review suggests that promoting hand washing with soap is significantly more cost-effective than other water and sanitation interventions.
targetString: Wabula, okwekaliriza okumu okwakolebwa kulaga nti okutumbula okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssaabuuni kisingirako ddala enkola endala ez’okukozesa ku byamazzi n’obuyonjo (sanitation).

sourceString: The importance of hand washing for human health – particularly for people in vulnerable circumstances like mothers who had just given birth or wounded soldiers in hospitals – was first recognized in the mid 19th century by two pioneers of hand hygiene: the Hungarian physician Ignaz Semmelweis who worked in Vienna, Austria and Florence Nightingale, the English "founder of modern nursing".
targetString: Obukulu bw’okunaaba mu ngalo eri obulamu bw’omuntu naddala eri abantu abali mu mbeera ey’okwegendereza ng’abakyala abaakasumulukuka oba abasirikale abafunye ebisago mu malwaliro – bwasooka kukengebwa wakati w’ekyasa kya 19, Omusawo w’omu Hungary Ignaz Semmelweis eyakoleranga mu ddwaliro ly’omu Vienna, Austria ne Florence Nightingale, Omungereza "eyazuula enzijanjaba ey’omulembe".

sourceString: At that time most people still believed that infections were caused by foul odors called miasmas.
targetString: Mu kiseera ekyo abantu baali bakkiriza nti obulwadde bwali buva ku kivundu ekiyitibwa miasmas.

sourceString: In the 1980s, foodborne outbreaks and healthcare-associated infections led the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to more actively promote hand hygiene as an important way to prevent the spread of infection.
targetString: Mu myaka gya 1980, endwadde ezisaasaanira mu byokulya n’endwadde ezitambulira mu nkola z’obujjanjabi obw’enjawulo, zaaleetera ekitongole kya Amerika Ekinoonyereza ku Ndwadde (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) okufungiza ne kisomesa abantu omugaso gw’okunaaba mu ngalo olw’okuziyiza okusaasaanya endwadde.

sourceString: The outbreak of swine flu in 2009 and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to increased awareness in many countries of the importance of washing hands with soap to protect oneself from such infectious diseases.
targetString: Okubalukawo kw’omusujja gw’embizzi (swine flu) mu 2009 ne COVID-19 mu 2020 byaleetedde amawanga mangi okutegeera omugaso gw’okunaaba mu ngalo ne ssabbuuni olw’okwerinda obulwadde obusiigibwa ng’obwo obwogeddwako.

sourceString: For example, posters with "correct hand washing techniques" were hung up next to hand washing sinks in public toilets and in the toilets of office buildings and airports in Germany.
targetString: Okugeza, ebiwandiiko ebitimbibwa ebiriko ebigambo nga "obukodyo bw’okunaaba mu ngalo obutuufu" bugenze buwanikibwa ewanaabirwa engalo mu kaabuyonjo z’olukale ne mu kaabuyonjo z’omu bizimbe omuli woofiisi ne ku bisaawe by’ennyonyi mu Bigirimaani.

sourceString: The phrase "washing one's hands of" something, means declaring one's unwillingness to take responsibility for the thing or share complicity in it.
targetString: Ebigambo bino "omuntu okunaaba mu ngalo" bitegeeza omuntu okulangirira nti omuntu yeggyeeko obuvunaanyizibwa oba okwenyigira mu kintu.

sourceString: It originates from the bible passage in Matthew where Pontius Pilate washed his hands of the decision to crucify Jesus Christ, but has become a phrase with a much wider usage in some English communities.
targetString: Ebigambo ebyo biri mu Bayibuli mu Matayo mwe tulabira Ponsio Piraato ng’anaaba mu ngalo olw’okusalawo okukomerera Yesu Kristo; wabula, ebigambo bino kati bikozesebwa nnyo mu bitundu ebirimu Abangereza.

sourceString: In Shakespeare's Macbeth, Lady Macbeth begins to compulsively wash her hands in an attempt to cleanse an imagined stain, representing her guilty conscience regarding crimes she had committed and induced her husband to commit.
targetString: Mu kitabo kya Shakespeare, Macbeth, Omukyala Macbeth akakibwa okunaaba mu ngalo ng’agezaako okulowooza ku kko lye yali alowoozaako obulowooza, kino nga kikiikirira okulumirizibwa kwe yali awulira olw’emisango gye yali azzizza ne gireetera ne bba okweggya mu budde.

sourceString: It has also been found that people, after having recalled or contemplated unethical acts, tend to wash hands more often than others, and tend to value hand washing equipment more.
targetString: Kizuuliddwa era nti abantu bwe bajjukira oba bwe balowooza ku bikolwa ebitali birungi bye bakoze, batera okunaaba ennyo mu ngalo okusinga abalala, era batera okussa ekitiibwa mu byuma ebikozesebwa okunaaba mu ngalo okusinga bwe baali bakola okusooka.

sourceString: Furthermore, those who are allowed to wash their hands after such a contemplation are less likely to engage in other "cleansing" compensatory actions, such as volunteering.
targetString: Ekirala, abo abakkirizibwa okunaaba mu ngalo oluvannyuma lw’okulowooza bwe batyo emikisa mitono nti bayinza obutaddamu kwenyingira mu bikolwa bya “kweyonja” gamba ng’obwannakyewa.

sourceString: Religions prescribe hand washing for both hygienic and symbolic purposes.Symbolic hand washing, using water but no soap to wash hands, is a part of ritual hand washing featured in many religions, including Bahá'í Faith, Hinduism, tevilah and netilat yadayim in Judaism, Lavabo in Christianity, and Wudhu in Islam.Religions also prescribe hygienic hand washing, especially after certain actions.
targetString: Enzikiriza zikubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo olw’okweyonja ate era ng’akabonero. Okunaaba mu ngalo ng’akabonero, kwe kugamba okukozesa amazzi omutali ssabbuuni okunaaba mu ngalo, kimu ku nnono z’okunaaba mu ngalo ekikolebwa mu nzikiriza eziwerako, omuli eya Bahai, Abahindu, tevilah ne netilat yadayim mu nzikiriza y’Abayudaaya, Lavabo mu Bagoberezi ba Kristo, ne Wudhu mu Basiraamu. Enzikiriza era zikubiriza okunaaba mu ngalo naddala oluvannyuma lw’ebikolwa ebimu.

sourceString: Hinduism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands after using the toilet.
targetString: Enzikiriza y’Abahindu, ey’Ekiyudaaya n’ey’Ekisiraamu zikubiriza okunaaba mu ngalo ng’omuntu avudde mu kaabuyonjo.

sourceString: And, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism, Judaism and Islam mandate washing of hands before and after every meal.
targetString: Era, Abahindu, Babudda, Abasiiki, Abayudaaya n’Abasiraamu bakubiriza okunaaba mu ngalo ng’omuntu tannalya ate ne bw’aba amaze okulya.

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19
targetString: Ebikugira ebizibu ku mirimu ebiva ku COVID-19

sourceString: Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19 are the application of occupational safety and health methodologies for hazard controls to the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
targetString: Ebikugira ebizibu mu mirimu ebiva ku COVID-19 kwe kussaawo enkola z’okwetangira obubenje n’engeri z’okwetangira okukwatibwa obulwadde bwa coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19).

sourceString: The proper hazard controls in the workplace depend on the worksite and job task, based on a risk assessment of sources of exposure, disease severity in the community, and risk factors of individual workers who may be vulnerable to contracting COVID-19.
targetString: Engeri ennungi ez’okutangira obulabe ku mirimu zisinziira ku kifo ewakolerwa n’omulimu ogukolebwa era okusoomooza okwo kusinziira ku kwekaliriza ensibuko y’obulabe, obunene bw’ekizibu ky’obulwadde mu kitundu, n’obulabe obwekwanya n’abakozi kinnoomu abayinza okwanguyirwa okukwatibwa COVID-19.

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers, for which basic infection prevention measures are recommended, including hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Okusinziira ku U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), emirimu egirina obulabe obutono girina enkwatagana ntono eyeekwanya n’emirimu n’abantu wamu n’abakozi abalala, era ng’obulabe obw’engeri eyo busobola okukolebwako n’obujjanjabi obutono obusookerwako, okukubiriza abakozi okusigala ewaka bwe baba nga balwadde, empisa ku bikwata ku ngeri y’okussa, wamu n’okufuba okuyonja buli kiseera ekifo ewakolerwa emirimu n’okutta obuwuka mu bifo ebyo.

sourceString: Medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact with people who are not known or suspected with COVID-19, but may be infected due to ongoing community transmission or international travel.
targetString: Emirimu egirina obulabe obutali bwa maanyi nnyo mwe muli egyo egirimu abantu okukwatagana ennyo n’abantu abatamanyiddwa oba abateeberezebwa okuba ne COVID-19, naye nga bayinza okukwatibwa obulwadde obwo olw’okusaasaana kw’obulwadde obwo mu kitundu oba olw’okutambula mu mawanga amalala.

sourceString: This includes workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.
targetString: Muno muzingiramu abakozi abakwatana n’abantu abalala, gamba ng’amasomero, ebifo omukolerwa emirimu nga mulimu abantu bangi, n’ebifo by’amaduuka omuli abantu abangi.

sourceString: Hazard controls for this group, in addition to basic infection prevention measures, include ventilation using high-efficiency air filters, sneeze guards, and having personal protective equipment available in case a person with COVID-19 is encountered.
targetString: Okutangira obulabe mu bantu bwe batyo okwo nga kw’otadde n’obukodyo obusookerwa obw’okutangira obulwadde, omuli okukozesa obumooli obusengejja obulungi empewo, n’okubeera n’ebyambalo eby’okwesabika omubiri singa wabaawo omulwadde wa COVID-19 awo okumpi.

sourceString: OSHA considers healthcare and mortuary workers exposed to known or suspected person with COVID-19 to be at high exposure risk, which increases to very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected person with COVID-19.
targetString: Enkola ya OSHA efaayo ku basawo/abajjanjabi n’abakolera mu bifo ebikola ku bateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19 kubanga babeera mu bulabe bwa maanyi, era ng’obulabe obwo bweyongera okubeera obw’amaanyi ennyo abakozi abo bwe babaako sampolo ze baggya ku mulambo ogw’omuntu afudde oba ateeberezebwa okuba ng’afudde COVID-19.

sourceString: Hazard controls appropriate for these workers include engineering controls such as negative pressure ventilation rooms, and personal protective equipment appropriate to the job task.
targetString: Ebikolebwa okutangira obulabe ku bakozi bano mulimu obukodyo mu kuzimba ebizimbe, gamba ng’okutangira empewo okuva mu kisenge ekimu okudda mu kirala, n’ebyokwesabika omubiri ebituukira ku mulimu omuntu gw’akola.

sourceString: COVID-19 outbreaks can have several effects within the workplace.
targetString: Okubalakulawo kwa COVID-19 kusobola okuvaamu okukosebwa kwa ngeri nnyingi ku mirimu.

sourceString: Workers may be absent from work due to becoming sick, needing to care for others, or from fear of possible exposure.
targetString: Abakozi basobola okubula ku mirimu olw’obulwadde, olw’obwetaavu bw’okulabirira abalala, oba nga batya okukwatibwa obulwadde obwo.

sourceString: Patterns of commerce may change, both in terms of what goods are demanded, and the means of acquiring these goods (such as shopping at off-peak hours or through delivery or drive-through services).
targetString: Ebyobusuubuzi bisobola okukyuka, ku bintu abantu bye baagala ate n’engeri y’okugulamu ebintu ebyo (gamba ng’okugula mu budde obwawuka ku obwo obusinga okugulirwako oba okwagala okubatwalira ebintu gye babyetaaga oba okubeera nga tebava mu bidduka nga batuuse mu bifo ebintu we biri).

sourceString: Lastly, shipments of items from geographic areas severely affected by COVID-19 may be interrupted.An infectious disease preparedness and response plan can be used to guide protective actions.
targetString: Ekisembayo, okusaabaza ebyamaguzi okuva mu bifo ebikoseddwa COVID-19 kuyinza okutaataaganyizibwa. Okweteekerateekera obulwadde obusiigibwa n’engeri y’okubulwanyisa kyetaagisa okuyamba okuluŋŋamya ebikolebwa okubwetangira.

sourceString: Plans address the levels of risk associated with various worksites and job tasks, including sources of exposure, risk factors arising from home and community settings, and risk factors of individual workers such as old age or chronic medical conditions.
targetString: Enteekateeka zitunuulira emitendera gy’obulabe egyekwanya n’ebifo ebikolerwamu eby’enjawulo wamu n’emirimu gyennyini, omwo nga mwe muli n’ebivaako okusiiga obulwadde, obulabe obuva ewaka ne mu kitundu, n’ebirala ebivaako obulabe ng’emyaka oba obulwadde obw’olukonvuba.

sourceString: They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
targetString: Bateekawo n’ebikugira ebyetaagisa okukola ku bulabe obwo, n’enteekateeka ey’okwerinda olw’embeera eyinza okubaawo olw’okubalakawo kw’obulwadde.

sourceString: Infectious disease preparedness and response plans may be subject to national or subnational recommendations.
targetString: Okweteekateekera obulwadde obusiigibwa kuyinza okusiziira ku bisembebwa eggwanga lyonna oba ekitundu.

sourceString: Objectives for response to an outbreak include reducing transmission among staff, protecting people who are at higher risk for adverse health complications, maintaining business operations, and minimizing adverse effects on other entities in their supply chains.
targetString: Ebigendererwa by’okulwanyisa obulwadde obuba bubaluseewo mulimu okukendeeza okusaasaanira mu bakozi, okukuuma abantu abali mu bulabe bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde ne bafuna obuzibu obw’amaanyi, okugenda mu maaso n’emirimu egikolebwa, n’okukendeeza okukosebwa eri abo bizinensi b’ekolagana nabo mu kajegere k’obuweereza bwabwe.

sourceString: The disease severity in the community where the business is located affects the responses taken.
targetString: Obukaali bw’obulwadde mu kitundu bizinensi mw’ebeera eri bukosa engeri y’okubulwanyisa.

sourceString: The hierarchy of hazard controls is a framework widely used in occupational safety and health to group hazard controls by effectiveness.
targetString: Ensengeka y’okuziyiza obuzibu nkola ekozesebwa ennyo mu nsi mu kwetangira obuzibu ku mirimu ne mu boobulamu mu kubinjawaza enkola ezikozesebwa okusinziira ku bulungi obuzirimu.

sourceString: Where COVID-19 hazards cannot be eliminated, the most effective controls are engineering controls, followed by administrative controls, and lastly personal protective equipment.
targetString: Obuzibu bwa COVID-19 we butasobolera kumalibwawo, okutangira okusinga okukola obulungi kwekwo okw’obuyiiya (engineering controls), okwo n’ossaako okutangira okw’obukulembeze (administrative controls) ate n’ekisembayo kwe kw’ebikozesebwa mu kutangira omuntu kinnoomu.

sourceString: Engineering controls involve isolating employees from work-related hazards without relying on worker behavior, and can be the most cost-effective solution to implement.
targetString: Okukugira okw’obuyiiya (Engineering controls) kulimu okuggya abakozi mu buzibu obwekwanya n’emirimu awatali kwesigama ku mpisa ya mulimu era kuno kwe kusinga okubeera obutaba kwa bbeeyi okussa mu nkola.

sourceString: Administrative controls are changes in work policy or procedures that require action by the worker or employer.
targetString: Okukugira okw’obukulembeze (Administrative controls) z’enkyukakyuka mu nkola y’emirimu oba mu nseetuka y’emirimu ezeetaagisa omukozi oba omukozesa okubaako ky’akola.

sourceString: Personal protective equipment (PPE) is considered less effective than engineering and administrative controls, but can help prevent some exposures.
targetString: Ebyokwesabika (Personal protective equipment, PPE) bitwalibwa obutakola bulungi kwenkana kutangira okw’obuyiiya oba okw’obukulembeze naye nga kusobola okuyambako mu kutangira okukwatibwa obulwadde.

sourceString: All types of PPE must be selected based upon the hazard to the worker, properly fitted as applicable (e.g., respirators), consistently and properly worn, regularly inspected, maintained, and replaced, as necessary, and properly removed, cleaned, and stored or disposed of to avoid contamination.
targetString: Ebika bya PPE byonna birina okulondebwa okusinziira ku bulabe omukozi bw’ayinza okufuna, birina okuteekebwa we bisaanye okuteekebwa ate bulungi (gamba ng’ebissizzibwamu), okwambalwa obudde bwonna era obulungi, okukeberwako buli kiseera, okulabirirwa, okuzzaawo ebituuse okusikiza, birina okuggyibwa we birina okuggyibwa bulungi nga bwe kyetaagisa, okulongoosebwa, n’okuterekebwa oba okusuulibwa olw’okwewala okuvaako obulwadde.

sourceString: According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers.
targetString: Okusinziira ku U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), emirimu egitaliimu nnyo bulabe girimu enkwatagana y’abantu b’ebweru ne bakozi bannaabwe ntono.

sourceString: Basic infection prevention measures recommended for all workplaces include frequent and thorough hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette including covering coughs and sneezes, providing tissues and trash receptacles, preparing for telecommuting or staggered shifts if needed, discouraging workers from using others' tools and equipment, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.
targetString: Ebikolebwa ebisookerwako ebisembebwa ku mirimu gyonna bizingiramu okunaaba mu ngalo ate bulungi, okukubiriza abakozi okubeera ewaka bwe baba nga balwadde, empisa mu kunyiza oba okwasimula omuli okubikka ku mimwa ng’oli akolola oba ayasimula, okuwa abantu obupapula obw’okwerongoosa n’ebisuulibwamu obupapula bw’okwerongoosa, okwetegekera okuwuliziganyiza ku ssimu oba okuwaanyisiganya mu mirimu bwe kiba nga kyetaagisa, okukubiriza abakozi obutakozesa bikozesebwa bannaabwe, n’okulongoosa ekifo ewakolerwa buli kiseera ate n’okufuba okutta obuwuka.

sourceString: Prompt identification and isolation of potentially infectious individuals is a critical step in protecting workers, customers, visitors, and others at a worksite.
targetString: Okuzuula amangu abantu abateeberezebwa okuba abalwadde ate n’okubaawula mu balala kiyamba okutaasa abakozi, bakasitooma, abagenyi n’abalala mu bifo ebikolerwamu.

sourceString: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness are to stay home until they are free of fever, signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines, and that sick leave policies are flexible, permit employees to stay home to care for a sick family member, and that employees are aware of these policies.
targetString: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC) esemba abakozi abalina obubonero bw’obulwadde obukwata omussizo (acute respiratory illness) basigale ewaka okutuusa ng’omusujja gubaamuse, nga baweddeko obubonero bw’omusujja, n’obubonero obulala okumala waakiri essaawa 24 nga tebakozesezza ddagala likkakkanya musujja era nti enkola z’okuwummuza abakozi ku mirimu zirina okuba nga zisobola okukyusibwakyusibwa, okukkiriza abakozi okusigala ewaka okulabirira abalwadde, era nti abakozi balina okubeera nga bamanyi bulungi enkola zino.

sourceString: According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.
targetString: Okusinziira ku OSHA, emirimu egirimu obulabe obutonotono mulimu egyo egyetaagisa abantu okusemberegana buli kiseera mu bbanga ery’effuuti omukaaga (1.8 m) ku bantu abatamanyiddwa nti balina oba bateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19, naye nga bayinza okuba nga balina SARS-CoV-2 olw’okusaasaana kw’obulwadde obwo mu kitundu bizinensi eyo mw’eri oba olw’okuba omuntu oyo yagendako mu nsi ez’ebweru mu kifo ekimanyiddwa nga kikoseddwa COVID-19.

sourceString: These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers’ concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.
targetString: Muno mulimu abakozi abakwatagana n’abantu abalala gamba ng’ab’omu masomero, ebifo ebikolerwamu emirimu abantu abangi, n’ebifo by’amaduuka ebirimu omujjuzo. Okutangira okw’obuyiiya (Engineering controls) ku bifo bino n’ebibinja ebiri mu bulabe obw’amaanyi mulimu okuteeka obutimba obusengejja ennyo empewo ku bizimbe, okwongeza ku bunene bw’obumooli, okuteekawo obuntu obulinga obusenge obusiikiriza omuntu ng’akuba emyasi, n’okuteekawo eddirisa abajja okugula nga bali mu mmotoka mwe baweererezebwa nga tebavuddeemu. Okutangira okw’obukulembeze (Administrative controls) ku kibinja kino ekirimu obuzibu obuneneko mulimu okukubiriza abakozi okusigala ewaka, okusikiza enkiiko ezirimu okulabagana maaso-ku-maaso ne zizzibwa ku yintaneeti, okuteekawo okukolera mu mpalo, okusazaamu okutambula okuteetaagisa nnyo mu bifo ebirimu ennyo obulwadde bwa COVID-19, okutondawo enteekateeka y’empuliziganya ey’amangu omuli n’okukola ku nsonga z’abakozi, okuwa abakozi amawulire agakwata ku COVID-19 wamu n’okubasomesa ku bulwadde obwo wamu n’engeri gye bayinza okubwekuuma, okusomesa abakozi abeetaaga okukozesa engoye ez’okwesabika n’okubalaga engeri y’okukozesa ebyuma bye baba balina okukozesa, okuwa abakozi eby’okukozesa n’okubassa mu bifo ebisobola okuyonjebwa obulungi n’abantu kinnoomu okubeereramu abayonjo, okukubiriza abakozi okunaaba mu ngalo buli kiseera, okukugira bakasitoma n’abantu abalala okutuuka mu kiro ewakolerwa, n’okuteekawo ebipande ebikubiriza abantu okunaaba mu ngalo n’obubaka obulala obw’okwekuuma COVID-19. Okusinziira ku mulimu nga bwe guba gufaanana, abakozi ababa mu buzibu bw’okusiigibwa obulwadde basaana ne beesabika omuli okwambala giraavu, egganduula, akakookolo n’ebigaalubindi.

sourceString: Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
targetString: Abakozi abali mu kibinja ekirina obuzibu eky’engeri eno tebatera kwetaaga kukozesa bikozesebwa kussa.

sourceString: If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.
targetString: Omuntu bw’alwalira ku nnyonyi, engeri ennungi ez’okutangira abakozi n’abasaabaze abalala mulimu okwawula omuntu omulwadde okuva ku balala ne bamuwa ebbanga lya fuuti 6, okufuna omu ku bakozi okulabirira omulwadde oyo, n’okuwa akakookolo omuntu oyo omulwadde oba okusaba omuntu oyo omulwadde okubikka omumwa n’ennyindo n’obupapula obukozesebwa okwerongoosa ng’akolola oba okwasimula.

sourceString: Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.
targetString: Abakozi b’oku nnyonyi balina okwambala giraavu ezikozesebwa omulundi ogumu nga baweereza omusaabaze omulwadde oba nga bakwata ku luzzizzi oluva mu mubiri oba ku kintu ekirabika nga kigenzeeko obuwuka, n’okwesabika singa omuntu gwe baweereza alabika ng’alina omusujja, akolola olutata, oba ng’azibuwalirwa mu kussa.

sourceString: Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.
targetString: Giraavu n’ebirala ebikozesebwa omulundi ogumu bisaanye okussibwa mu kaveera akasuulibwamu ebintu ng’ebyo (biohazard bag), n’ebintu ebiddugaziddwa ne birongoosebwa era ne bifuuyirwako eddagala oluvannyuma. Ate amaato agasaabaza ebyamaguzi omuli n’emmeeri z’abasaabaze, ebitangira obulabe bye bino, okwongezaayo okutambula ng’oli mulwadde, okweyawula n’okutegeeza abakozi b’oku lyato bw’owulira omusujja oba obubonero obulala ng’oli ku lyato.

sourceString: Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Ekituufu kiri nti, okulondoola omulwadde kulina okukolebwa mu kasenge omulwadde mw’aba ateereddwa. Ate ku masomero ne mu bifo ebirabirirwamu abaana, CDC esemba okuggalawo okumala akaseera katono ekifo kisobole okuyonjebwa n’okutta obuwuka singa omuntu omulwadde aba abadde mu kizimbe ky’essomero ne bwe kiba nti mu kitundu ekyo bubadde tebusaasaanye.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: Bwe waba nga waliwo okusaasaana kw’obulwadde okusaamusaamu mu kitundu, obukodyo bw’okweyawula busobola okukozesebwa, gamba ng’okusazaamu okulambula, okusimba ennyiriri ku ssomero, n’enkuŋŋaana endala ennene gamba ng’okukola dduyiro oba ebibiina ebya kkwaya oba okuliira awamu mu ddiiro ly’essomero, okwongeza ku mabanga ku ntebe z’abayizi, okukyusakyusa mu budde abaana mwe bajjira ne bwe baddirayo ewaka, okukendeeza ku bagenyi abateetaagisa nnyo, n’okukozesa woofiisi ey’enjawulo ey’ebyobulamu ku baana abalina obubonero obulinga obwa ssenyiga.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.
targetString: Bwe wabaawo okusaasaana okw’amaanyi mu kitundu, ku kakodyo k’okwewa amabanga, kisaana okwongerako n’okuggala amasomero okumala ebbanga eriwera. Eri abakuumaddembe abakola emirimu gya buli lunaku, obulabe bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde butwalibwa CDC okuba nga butono nnyo ddala.

sourceString: Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.
targetString: Abakuumaddembe abalina okukwatagana n’abantu abakakasiddwa nti balina COVID-19 baweebwa amagezi okugoberera enkola ze zimu ng’abajjanjabi ab’amangu, omuli n’okukozesa ebyokwesabika omubiri gwonna.

sourceString: If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.
targetString: Okukwatagana bwe kubaawo ng’omuntu akwatibwa, abakozi balina okulongoosa n’okufuuyira obuwuka ku byambalo byabwe nga tebannaddamu kubikozesa nga bakozesa eddagala erifuuyira mu nju oba okusiimula, n’okugoberera emitendera egimanyiddwa wonna mu kulongoosa ebyokwesabika wamu n’okwoza engoye.

sourceString: OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
targetString: OSHA kitwala abakozi b’ebyobulamu abamu n’abakola mu mawanika okubeera mu buzibu obw’amaanyi ennyo ddala ku kukwatibwa obulwadde.

sourceString: High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Emirimu egireetera abantu okubeera mu mbeera ey’obulabe ennyo mulimu abalabirira abalwadde ewaka, ababawanirira, abakola mu magezeserezo, n’abagoba b’abebyobulamu abasemberera abalwadde abamanyiddwa oba abateeberezebwa okuba nti balina COVID-19.

sourceString: These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Bano babeera mu bulabe obw’amaanyi ddala, abakozi bwe beenyigira mu mitendera egirimu okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) ku balwadde, oba bwe bakwata ku sampolo okuva ku bantu abamanyiddwa oba abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19.

sourceString: Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.
targetString: Mu mitendera gy’okupika omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) mulimu okuleetera omuntu okukolola, bronchoscopies, emitendera egirimu okukola n’okukebera amannyo (dental procedures), oba invasive specimen collection.

sourceString: High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.
targetString: Emirimu egirimu obulabe obw’amaanyi egy’okukola ku bafu mulimu egy’okutegeka emibiri gy’abantu ababadde bamanyiddwa nti balwadde oba nga bateeberezebwa okuba ne COVID-19 mu kiseera we baafiira; bano babeera mu bulabe bwa maanyi ddala bwe bakebera omulambo. Okutangira kw’obuyiiya (engineering controls) ku bibinja by’abantu bano abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi mulimu okukozesa ebisenge okwawula abalwadde abamanyiddwa nti balwadde oba abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19, omwo nga mwe muli n’emirundi okupika omukka (aerosol-generating procedures) lwe kuba kukoleddwa.

sourceString: Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
targetString: Enkola eya specialized negative pressure ventilation eyinza okuba ennungi mu mbeera z’ebyobulamu ezimu n’enkwata y’emirambo.

sourceString: Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
targetString: Sampolo eziggyibwa ku bantu zirina kukwatibwa n’obwegendereza obw’amaanyi ddala (Biosafety Level 3 precautions).

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.
targetString: WHO esemba abalwadde abapya okwawulibwa nga bassibwa mu bifo ebirindirwamu eby’enjawulo bwe baba nga bateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19. Okwongereza ku nkola endala eza PPE, OSHA esemba okukozesa ebyuma ebissizibwamu eri abo abakolera mu bbanga erya fuuti 6 nga baliraanye abalwadde ba SARS-CoV-2 oba abateeberezebwa okuba nabwo wamu n’abo abakola ku mitendera gy’okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedures).

sourceString: In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.
targetString: Mu America, obukookolo bwa N95 obwakakasibwa NIOSH oba obusingawo bulina kukozesebwa mu mbeera etegekeddwa obulungi omuli okusooka okubugezesa, okutendeka ababukozesa, okutendekebwa, ne mu kukebera kw’ekisawo.

sourceString: Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.
targetString: Ebika by’ebissizibwamu ebirala bisobola okuyamba mu ngeri esingako n’okugumya abakozi nga bakola egyabwe. WHO tesemba kukozesa ovulo kubanga COVID-19 bulwadde bwa mu mussizo so tebutambulizibwa mu luzzizzi lwa mu mubiri.

sourceString: WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
targetString: WHO esembe okukozesa akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa abalwadde eri abakola ku kusunsula abalwadde.

sourceString: For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.
targetString: Eri abo abaggya sampolo z’omu mussizo ku bantu, abalabiriraa, oba abatambuza abalwadde ba COVID-19 awatali kukozesa aerosol-generating procedures, WHO esemba okukozesa akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa, gaalubindi oba ekibikka ku maaso, ne giraavu.

sourceString: If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
targetString: Omutendera gw’okupima omukka (aerosol-generating procedure) bwe gukolebwa, akakookolo akakozesebwa mu kulongoosa kasikizibwa N95 oba FFP2 respirator.

sourceString: Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.
targetString: Olw’okuba nti ebyokwesabika (PPE) tebimala, WHO esemba okukendeeza ku kukozesa ebyokwesabika nga bakozesa okujjanjaba naye ng’omusawo n’omulwadde tebasisinkanye (telemedicine), okukozesa ebisiikiriza gamba ng’amadirisa agatangaala, okukkiriza abo bokka abajjanjaba obutereevu okuyingira ekisenge n’omulwadde wa COVID-19, okukozesa ebyokwesabika ebyo byokka ebyetaagisa ku ekyo ekikolebwa, okukozesa ekissizibwamu ekimu ng’olabirira abalwadde abawera abalina obulwadde obw’engeri emu, okulondoola n’okukwanaganya embunyisa y’ebyokwesabika, n’obutakkiriza kukozesa bukookolo eri abalwadde abatalabikirako bubonero.

sourceString: FROM: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
targetString: OKUVA EWA: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO

sourceString: TO: All Wikimedia Foundation staff
targetString: ERI: Abakozi ba Wikimedia Foundation

sourceString: SUBJECT LINE: [Covid-19] Lightening the load and preparing for the future
targetString: ENSONGA: [Covid-19] Okukendeeza ku mirimu n’okwetegekera ebiseera eby’omu maaso

sourceString: SEND DATE/TIME: 14 March, 2020, 00:24 UTC
targetString: ENNAKU Z’OMWEZI/ESSAAWA LW’ESINDIKIDDWA: 14 Ogwokusatu, 2020, 00:24 UTC

sourceString: LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
targetString: LAYISINSI: CC0: Tewali ddembe lyesigaliziddwa

sourceString: We find ourselves in remarkable circumstances this month.
targetString: Tuli mu mbeera etali nnyangu omwezi guno.

sourceString: The COVID-19 epidemic is something that makes clear our global human interconnectedness and the responsibilities we have to one another.
targetString: Nawookeera wa COVID-19 atulaze bulungi nti abantu bonna mu nsi bakolagana era babeerana era buli omu alina obuvunaanyizibwa eri munne.

sourceString: We don’t have precedent for its challenges, but we do know that our best response relies on the sort of global empathy, cooperation, and community building that sits at the heart of this organization.
targetString: Tetulina kyakulabirako ku kusoomoozebwa kuno, naye tumanyi nti okwanukula kwaffe kusinziira ku kulumirirwa wonna mu nsi, enkolagana, n’obukolaganyi mu bantu obuzimbirwamu ekitongole kino.

sourceString: The camaraderie and care we have seen among all of our colleagues over email, calls, and chats is a remarkable validation of the incredible humans we are fortunate enough to work with.
targetString: Obwasseruganda n’okufaayo kwe tulabye mu bannaffe nga batuwandiikira email, nga bakuba amasimu, n’okunyumya ku ssimu kiraga bulungi nti abantu be tukolagana nabo balumirirwa era tuli ba mukisa okukolagana nabo.

sourceString: I couldn’t be more grateful and proud to count you all as colleagues.
targetString: Sirina ngeri ya njawulo gye nnyinza kubeebazaamu mikwano gyange.

sourceString: Last week, someone shared with me their appreciation for our work.
targetString: Wiiki ewedde, waliwo omuntu eyanneebazizza olw’emirimu gye tukola.

sourceString: They reminded me how meaningful it is for the world to be able to turn to Wikipedia right now, and what a powerful symbol it is for this critical resource to remain online and available to all.
targetString: Kyanzijukizizza obukulu bw’ensi okuddukira ku Wikipedia mu kiseera kino, nti era kano kabonero ka maanyi akalaga nti Wikipedia ya muwendo nnyo era esaana ebeere ku yintaneeti buli muntu emugase.

sourceString: Your work makes this possible, whether you keep the sites stay up or our colleagues paid or our communities safe.
targetString: Omulimu gwo gw’okola gutusobozesa okutuuka ku buwanguzi buno, ng’oyamba okubeezaawo omukutu ku yintaneeti, ng’oyamba okusasula abakozi baffe oba abantu okubeera mu mbeera etaliimu bulabe.

sourceString: The world needs the information that Wikipedia provides, now more than ever.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, ensi yeetaaga obubaka obuli ku Wikipedia okusinga obwedda bwonna.

sourceString: This is a moment in which not only what we do, but how we do it, will make a meaningful impact on the world.
targetString: Kino kye kiseera mwe tulabira nti ebintu bye tukola n’engeri gye tubikolamu biyamba okubaako kye bikola mu nsi.

sourceString: Because of the importance of this mission and your role in it, we will be making some significant adjustments to how we work together, starting this coming week.
